headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, February 2, 2016. Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain f
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, February 2, 2016. Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain forward-looking statements, including the company's outlook for the remainder of the year. Information on factors that could cause actual results to vary materially from those discussed today is available at Emerson's most recent annual report on Form 10-K as filed by the SEC. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Craig Rossman, Director of Investor Relations at Emerson. Please go ahead.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alicia. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; and Frank Dellaquila, Executive VP and Chief Financial Officer. Today's call will summarize Emerson's first quarter of 2016 results. A conference call slid
componenttext:
Thank you, Alicia. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; and Frank Dellaquila, Executive VP and Chief Financial Officer. Today's call will summarize Emerson's first quarter of 2016 results. A conference call slide presentation will accompany my comments and is available on Emerson's website. A replay of this conference call and slide presentation will be available on the website for the next 90 days. 
I will start with the first quarter summary, as shown on Page 2 of the slide presentation. Net sales in the quarter decreased 16% to $4.7 billion with underlying sales down 9%. Our results reflected a continuation of the difficult economic conditions of that were experienced during most of fiscal 2015. We continue to find ourselves in the midst of a global industrial recession, and recent economic data suggests that capital spending by industrial businesses weakened during the course of the fourth calendar quarter. 
In the energy sector, lower, but equally as important, uncertain oil prices continue to impact both operational and capital spending by our end customers. 
Reported earnings per share in the first quarter decreased 29% to $0.53. Adjusted earnings per share, which exclude $24 million in separation costs, were better than our previous expectation of $0.50. The separation costs relate to our portfolio repositioning actions, specifically the planned spin-off of Network Power and the potential divestitures of the Motors and Drives and Power Generation businesses. 
Overall, the first quarter results were slightly better than our expectations, and the company remains well positioned for a challenging 2016. 
Turning to Slide 3. Gross profit margin in the quarter decreased 70 basis points to 40.1%, primarily due to volume deleverage and unfavorable mix. EBIT reflects the impacts of unfavorable currency transaction of $27 million and portfolio repositioning separation cost of $24 million. Additionally, the aggressive restructuring actions initiated in 2015 are beginning to have a positive impact on profitability. 
During the quarter, approximately 12 million shares were repurchased for $554 million. The company still plans for fiscal year share repurchase to reach approximately $1.2 billion. 
Turning to Slide 4. Underlying sales were down in all regions, except Europe, where our euro-based businesses are becoming more globally competitive. 
Turning to Slide 5. Business segment margin declined 170 basis points to 13.3%, primarily due to volume deleverage and unfavorable mix, partially offset by the savings from restructuring actions. 
Operating cash flow was down 15%, reflects the impact of lower earnings. 
Similar to many industrial manufacturers, capital spending was reduced due to lower global demand. Capital spending was down 30%. 
Turning to Slide 6. Process Management underlying sales declined 11% in the quarter. Energy sector spending remained at challenging levels as lower and increasingly uncertain oil prices further pressure spending, particularly in upstream market. Upstream projects underway will continue to completion, but new projects are facing potentially further delays. Downstream markets remain favorable in the U.S., Europe and Middle East, mainly in small- to medium-size projects in the chemical and power markets. We will continue to shift our resources to capitalize on more favorable business activity levels in downstream and life sciences markets. 
Turning to Slide 7. Industrial Automation first quarter underlying sales declined 15%, reflecting continued weakness from a global industrial recession and reduced levels of spending in upstream oil and gas customers. These conditions are expected to continue into the second quarter with improvement expected in the second half of the fiscal year. 
Turning to Slide 8. Network Power underlying sales declined 1% in the quarter as global demand for data center and telecommunications infrastructure spending was mixed. From a regional perspective, Asia had growth in Australia, India and Southeast Asia, while Latin America reflected favorable data center activity levels, particularly in Mexico. Segment margins increased 90 basis points to 8%, benefiting from restructuring actions. Recent order trends have reflected improving conditions in both data center and telecommunications investment. 
Turning to Slide 9. Climate Technologies underlying sales declined 10% as global air conditioning sales decreased, driven by higher U.S. residential demand in the prior year resulting from regulatory changes. Global refrigeration markets grew modestly as growth in the United States and Asia was up, partially offset by softness in Europe. Demand in the air conditioning and refrigeration markets remained favorable, supporting our outlook for modest levels of growth in 2016. 
Turning to Slide 10. Underlying sales in the commercial and residential solutions segment were down 2%. Favorable activity levels in U.S. construction markets resulted in growth in both the wet-dry vacuums and food waste disposal businesses. Segment margins improved 20 basis points to 21.7 from the favorable impact of the divestiture of the InterMetro business. The favorable trends in U.S. residential and commercial construction continue to support our outlook for modest levels of growth in the segment. 
Turning to Slide 11. As we have indicated, we expect difficult market conditions to persist throughout the fiscal year, but we do still see a bottom forming in both sales and earnings by the middle of 2016. We will continue to execute on our operational plans while diligently working to complete the important portfolio repositioning actions that were announced last June. 
Taking into account our first quarter results and recent order trends, we are reaffirming our fiscal year 2016 guidance. Underlying sales are expected to be down approximately 2% to 5%, excluding negative currency translation and a deduction from completed divestitures of approximately 2% each. We continue to expect adjusted earnings per share of $3.05 to $3.25, excluding estimated separation cost of approximately $250 million to $350 million, which are approximately $50 million lower than our previous expectations. For the second quarter, underlying sales are expected to be down approximately 4% to 6%, excluding negative currency translation and a deduction from completed divestitures of approximately 2% each. Adjusted earnings per share of $0.60 to $0.65 are expected, excluding estimated separation costs of approximately $75 million or approximately 11% -- $0.11 per share. 
Our long-standing commitment to return cash flow to our shareholders will be supported by an expected increase in 2016 operating cash flow to approximately $3 billion. 
And with that, I will now turn it over to Mr. David Farr.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Craig. Thank you very much to everyone joining us today. I appreciate that. We are looking for to seeing our investors and analysts in Austin next week, and we'll talk a little bit more about that in a second, but looking really forwa
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Craig. Thank you very much to everyone joining us today. I appreciate that. We are looking for to seeing our investors and analysts in Austin next week, and we'll talk a little bit more about that in a second, but looking really forward to seeing everyone down there and sharing our plans and ideas to the group. 
I also want to thank everybody across Emerson relative to the execution in the first quarter. Clearly, this is only the first quarter, and we have a very detailed undertaking ahead of us relative to sequentially improving our sales, our profitability, our earnings and cash flow from [indiscernible] this year. And as I look at the plans we started back from restructuring back in February, and I look at the announcement of repositioning that we announced in June, we continue to make very good progress, but it is clearly all about executing around those plans that we put in place and making sure we get it done from a standpoint of driving costs, standpoint of repositioning this company and looking forward to how, as we go through a very challenging global economy, very challenging industrial recession that we see today and coming out of this a stronger company and one that can continue to add assets once we've repositioned to a new Emerson platform. 
Looking forward to giving you insight of how we see the 2016  [ph] unfolding from an economic standpoint. How we see the numbers happening from the cost of the repositioning, how we see the issues that we may see from a risk standpoint and what we're going to have to do about those if we see additional risks. Those are all things that we'll be talking about. I will defer those until we get together next week. Also looking forward to having Bob Sharp and also Steven Sonnenberg talk about the 2 key business segments -- business platforms that we'll be moving into: the commercial residential solutions and and then also the automation solutions. Those 2 individuals will give you insights into what we see, the strength of these platforms, what we can do with those platforms and where we're going to invest going forward. Clearly, we have a challenging oil and gas industrial marketplace right now, but it's nothing new. We've been there before. We know what to do -- deal with this issue. It's why we started the aggressive restructuring last year. As we talk amongst the business leaders, the OC, the board, if the market continues to get challenging, we will continue to do additional restructuring. We'll continue to make sure that the cost structure of this company stays competitive in that we can deliver the highest level of profitability that our shareholders expect from us. That is our -- that is what we're all about right now, executing around that and getting things forward. 
As I look at our current marketplace, the last 30 days have been what I would call the most unusual in my time at Emerson. I've never seen a marketplace go so volatile from the standpoint of the end markets, the stock markets, the interest rates, the -- I guess, the attitude. It's just a very amazing marketplace right now and one that clearly global CEOs like myself have to deal with and be prepared for whatever comes at us. But we are now basically in our fourth quarter of the recession. I'd see -- we'll talk about it next week, I see at least one more quarter, maybe another quarter. But sequentially, our game plan is to improve the business cycle, the business backup and start improving the profitability. And that's what we're all about here. 
So with that, I'll open the floor. I'm glad to have the first quarter behind us. I want again to thank the organization. They did a great job executing around the plans we put out there. We're making great progress. And clearly, it's only one quarter. We know that. And our game plan is sequentially improve the sales, the profitability, the earnings and the cash flow to our shareholders and establish the premium valuation that this company deserves. 
With that, I'll open the floor.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I noticed you said something in earnings call today, [indiscernible] you talked about orders stabilizing with the oil move below kind of $30. All bets were off [indiscernible] to that effect. So here we are. Oil is around $30. I'm just wondering how yo
componenttext: So I noticed you said something in earnings call today, [indiscernible] you talked about orders stabilizing with the oil move below kind of $30. All bets were off [indiscernible] to that effect. So here we are. Oil is around $30. I'm just wondering how you see that playing out for process [indiscernible] these levels both this year and then [indiscernible] FY '17?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me see. Chevron reported a loss. BP reported a loss. I would say the market's stressed work. So far my perspective right now, I would say the capital market in oil and gas is going to be lower. Our expectation for our process business will be lower, a
componenttext: Let me see. Chevron reported a loss. BP reported a loss. I would say the market's stressed work. So far my perspective right now, I would say the capital market in oil and gas is going to be lower. Our expectation for our process business will be lower, and we'll have to do additional restructuring. We are looking at situation, in my opinion, oil and gas marketplaces that will now recover until well past the middle of '17, maybe late '17. Fortunately, we have 75% of the business that doesn't serve oil and gas marketplace. So even though we'll talk about this next week, oil and gas being down, it's not going to 0. It will be a tougher marketplace, and we'll have to work harder at it. And clearly, there's a lot of uncertainty around this, but the game is, we're going to have to figure out how to get the sales, how to get the business and get our costs down. And it will clearly be a tougher year in '16 than we thought. That's the game. Pretty straightforward.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then in the quarter, I guess, in January, you announced product with [indiscernible] I think $150 million. Just interested to see you guys taking a preferred equity investment in that customer. Was wondering is that reflective of the comp
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then in the quarter, I guess, in January, you announced product with [indiscernible] I think $150 million. Just interested to see you guys taking a preferred equity investment in that customer. Was wondering is that reflective of the competitive environment where alongside price you're not going to have to think of other ways to win business. Or how do you think about that? And how should we think about it going forward on other kind of big, large projects?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've done some things in the past. This is unique. This is very strategic for the country of Egypt, and we felt that, as did other people, we're not doing who did this. We're probably going public with it. But I think that you'll see this happening from
componenttext: We've done some things in the past. This is unique. This is very strategic for the country of Egypt, and we felt that, as did other people, we're not doing who did this. We're probably going public with it. But I think that you'll see this happening from time to time. It is a huge opportunity for us, and it really also about forming a relationship because I think once this projects that are successful, it will be a future projects and it will happen. But it's not for every customer. Is that for every marketplace. But this one, we worked on it a long time and I'm met with the CEO, and we had a long conversation in a feel that this makes a lot of sense for us relative to strategic relationship going forward. So I don't think -- it's not -- it's just our commitment to making sure that these guys are successful, and we're going to have a lot of business with them for many years to come.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Josh Pokrzywinski from Buckingham Research.
componenttext: We'll go next to Josh Pokrzywinski from Buckingham Research.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Dave, just looking at the order trends here in process. In December, obviously, the month-to-month can be volatile with different project activity and what stays and goes around the comp book. But maybe just comment on how that month looked and any kin
componenttext: So Dave, just looking at the order trends here in process. In December, obviously, the month-to-month can be volatile with different project activity and what stays and goes around the comp book. But maybe just comment on how that month looked and any kind of body language you've gotten just with the last $10 move. Obviously, projects don't go forward for even a month of oil prices, but maybe what is -- what the psychology has been with this last move down?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, to be honest, I think the psychology is very nervous and tense within the big oil and gas investors at this point in time. I think that we see, from our perspective, what we're looking is that we'll talk to you next week. We'll try and encompass w
componenttext: I mean, to be honest, I think the psychology is very nervous and tense within the big oil and gas investors at this point in time. I think that we see, from our perspective, what we're looking is that we'll talk to you next week. We'll try and encompass what we think the downside will be relative to oil and gas in the process businesses. But I would say, the December quarter for orders for process were not that bad. We pretty well have that factored in what's going on. I would say that my concern is the psyche of a Chevron or a psyche of a Exxon Mobil, psyche of these Shells and BPs and things like that will -- are going to again freeze up some of that spending level. They can't go to 0, but I think it's going to get tougher. So my gut tells me that it is going to be more challenging in the near term, and our oil and gas -- I mean, our oil process work pace will be a drag on this, and the other businesses will start pulling back up. So that's where we're at this point in time. I think I've always -- we'll give you an update of what I think the process segment is going to do, but I would -- it's going to be -- there'll be more negative based on just some of the first question, I did say that when the price of oil got to down to that level will be an impact. And I think, right now, our underlying sales will be more negative in the process than we thought originally. And hence, we're going to have to go after more caution there. So that the psyche not been in the space right now. Fortunately, there's more investments going on in the other parts of the marketplace, and it's a big part of the marketplace, but oil and gas investment is not very good right now. And I think it's going to hurt us for the second half this year.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And obviously, I'll touch more on this next week. But I think looking at the last quarter, the expectation on being to hold the line in price somewhat and being able to hold the line on margins this year, assuming all that plays out, what we're seeing tod
componenttext: And obviously, I'll touch more on this next week. But I think looking at the last quarter, the expectation on being to hold the line in price somewhat and being able to hold the line on margins this year, assuming all that plays out, what we're seeing today, I would imagine, those 2 items are also part of that discussion that maybe goes out the window as well.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not going out the window. I mean from the standpoint of -- the pricing right now is -- when we make a forecast forward, we look at ranges. We have ranges. There's a reason why we go 2 to 5 or other ranges in underlying sales. We look also pricing env
componenttext: It's not going out the window. I mean from the standpoint of -- the pricing right now is -- when we make a forecast forward, we look at ranges. We have ranges. There's a reason why we go 2 to 5 or other ranges in underlying sales. We look also pricing environment changing, too. So the pricing environment today is still within the range that we laid out when we put our plan together back in August and September and just talk to you all in November. And then material inflation has continued to drop down. So we're going to give you a forecast. We'll give you a range of what it looks like right now. But it's well within the range. I would say the one negative would be the sales -- underlying sales in process will be more negative, and the profitability will still be very good. And we're going to have to take some additional restructuring, both for the '16 and '17 in that space because the recovery will be long. And it's -- we're going to see what our customer base does right now. As you said, they don't move that fast, but I know the psyche is not good. I mean, you just have to look at the report that came out of the last 3 days or 4 days relative to 2 major oil and gas providers.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Andrew Kaplowitz from Citigroup.
componenttext: We'll go next to Andrew Kaplowitz from Citigroup.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, so on the last quarter's call, you talked about expectation that we might see one more quarter where inventory in the channel could be worked down. And then by 2Q, destocking could be behind Emerson. Did you see -- I think you saw continued destocki
componenttext: Dave, so on the last quarter's call, you talked about expectation that we might see one more quarter where inventory in the channel could be worked down. And then by 2Q, destocking could be behind Emerson. Did you see -- I think you saw continued destocking in the quarter. Do you think inventory in the channels are low enough or that destocking for the whole combination and as we go through fiscal 2Q and then the second half of '16?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, what my knowledge is right now, inventory levels within the channel for the -- including ourselves, are levels that -- they're pretty good levels, low. And so the pace of business right now and the run rates where I see, I would say the inven
componenttext: I would say, what my knowledge is right now, inventory levels within the channel for the -- including ourselves, are levels that -- they're pretty good levels, low. And so the pace of business right now and the run rates where I see, I would say the inventory levels are pretty good for us. I don't see much of a downward draft on that now. I think it's pretty well over with, probably very minor downward draft. I think it's pretty well there around on the world, I've been in Asia, and been around the world, and I don't see the inventory being a big issue for us right now. So that's a good thing.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just asking about China. You talked about China in '16 [ph] maybe being down mid-single digits on your last call and maybe down 15% in 1Q, but you actually did down 13%. Do you think China stabilized a little bit for you in terms of the d
componenttext: Got it. And then just asking about China. You talked about China in '16 [ph] maybe being down mid-single digits on your last call and maybe down 15% in 1Q, but you actually did down 13%. Do you think China stabilized a little bit for you in terms of the decline? And you still expect mid-single digits for '16 to hold down to single digits?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, I'd call down 15 and down 13. I'd say that's a pretty good forecast call right there, without knowing what was going to happen. So if I could do that, maybe should I should go into investment mode. Just joking, clearly. I think the Chi
componenttext: Well, first of all, I'd call down 15 and down 13. I'd say that's a pretty good forecast call right there, without knowing what was going to happen. So if I could do that, maybe should I should go into investment mode. Just joking, clearly. I think the China, in my opinion today, the forecast either -- when you put that out there, I still think that's still going to be that mid-single-plus digit. I think it's going to be in the 5%, 6%, 7% range negative. don't see it changing. I would say my China organization is more optimistic than that. They're less negative. But I think that looking at what I see going on in China in the marketplace around the world, that's going to be a tough one for them to do. Though they are working through the inventory that was built up in 20 -- first part of 2015, but my gut tells me that I would not be surprised if we don't finish that minus 7% or 8% in China when it's all said and done. [indiscernible] then you can see me how the forecast [indiscernible]

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- so maybe focusing a little bit on your commentary about the last 30 days being so volatile. And then just look at -- taking a look at the order trends. It is interesting. As you look at the trends, you think about the last 30 days, it's interesting
componenttext: The -- so maybe focusing a little bit on your commentary about the last 30 days being so volatile. And then just look at -- taking a look at the order trends. It is interesting. As you look at the trends, you think about the last 30 days, it's interesting that you haven't really updated your guidance for the underlying growth rate for the year. Recognize the comps are going to get easier as we get through the year. But why not maybe be a little bit more, I guess, conservative with the underlying order trends -- with the underlying organic growth trends for 2016?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Because I think that when we put our plan together, we had certain assumptions relative to the volatility in the marketplace and what the market is going to look like. And as I look at all analysis and I look at the upsides and downsides, I think, right n
componenttext: Because I think that when we put our plan together, we had certain assumptions relative to the volatility in the marketplace and what the market is going to look like. And as I look at all analysis and I look at the upsides and downsides, I think, right now, we're still well within that boundary. And to come out and on to widen that boundary right now is not really acceptable. I think our organization, at this point in time, were well within that even with the 30-day risk. I mean the risk in the 30 days is more around one piece of the company. I mean, and the standpoint -- I mean, Europe's not that case. It's primarily around the oil and gas, the price of oil and gas investments. So it's not the whole economy, but -- I mean we -- we encompass what we thought could possibly happen to us now, and [indiscernible] and I'll a talk a little bit about that in Austin. But right now, I think we're well inside the boundaries of what we put out there.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Okay. All right. Fair enough. And maybe about [indiscernible]

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that the -- we see right now, around $80 million improvement came through in the first quarter. They'll be -- from the standpoint of restructuring, there's still a big number, the second quarter. My gut tells me that we'll probably around be restr
componenttext: I think that the -- we see right now, around $80 million improvement came through in the first quarter. They'll be -- from the standpoint of restructuring, there's still a big number, the second quarter. My gut tells me that we'll probably around be restructuring around $20 million in the second quarter and then we're going to be increasing this. The question is, "Can I get it done in the third or fourth quarter? Is it more an early part of next year?" But clearly, I think you're going to be looking at the 20-page for each quarter now as we start pushing in anticipation of concerns that we may have in the marketplace out there. Savings-wise, you're going to be building for this 80 [ph] and incrementally be coming up towards the, I would say, the 90 level by the time to get that fourth quarter. And that's basically how we see that happening fourth [ph] quarter.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Mike Wood of Macquarie Securities Group.
componenttext: We'll go next to Mike Wood of Macquarie Securities Group.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good job executing in a very tough backdrop. I'd like to follow up -- an earlier question the price, have you actually began to see the increased price competition in process? And has that been rational and just given the fact that very little project act
componenttext: Good job executing in a very tough backdrop. I'd like to follow up -- an earlier question the price, have you actually began to see the increased price competition in process? And has that been rational and just given the fact that very little project activity out there, I'm just curious how you actually measure that price change.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've made the price change, obviously, on the contracts. We also mentioned price change that we have to give on short-term actions from the standpoint of a day-to-day business. So it's very measurable because we see the average pricing within the s
componenttext: Well, we've made the price change, obviously, on the contracts. We also mentioned price change that we have to give on short-term actions from the standpoint of a day-to-day business. So it's very measurable because we see the average pricing within the structure of the business. But you're right. There's not been a lot of big bids around what I would say the oil and gas or the bigger -- the other big projects. So the pricing has been rational. The other issue is right now, like our European competitors, were also major players in the process roll out of Europe. So we're not -- we get the best of that, too. So what I see going to happen is we're going to be seeing sales shift to our European operations because we've been working for this the last 12 months. The dollar really started appreciating last year, a little over a year ago. So we've been working together, a rebound cost structure which will continue to do. Our European organization right now is seeing the benefit of a lower cost structure. So they're winning, and I would say, you're going to see other regions the world do. So we're pushing around the world, just like our European competitors do and that's one of the -- that's one of the things we do have relatively having a broad manufacturing or basis in all these businesses. So I feel reasonably comfortable right now in the forecast we gave you for price. I mean we track this extremely hard. I don't know how long you've been following us, but [indiscernible] first one to mention in the early 2000, 2002, 2003 time, I can't remember exactly when that was, [indiscernible] on how fast is single but now we created a lot of tough attracting process. And I can tell what's going on across the company. It's tracking -- it's going to be a little more negative this year than last year, but well within what I thought we're going to see and well within material inflationary level. So and people are acting irrational. Going to be an interesting to see. A lot of people are trying to improve their profitability on down volume and dropping price kind it down volume to try and prove your profitability did not work. Economics 101. It does not work.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And given the recent volatility that you mentioned in crude, how does that impact the downstream businesses and MRO and your investments that you're making?
componenttext: Understood. And given the recent volatility that you mentioned in crude, how does that impact the downstream businesses and MRO and your investments that you're making?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things. I am concerned as why I think we're talking about we need to get a reaction together think about if it takes longer to recover as we go into late '16, early '17 in the process side, because I personally think what will happen is, there will be
componenttext: Two things. I am concerned as why I think we're talking about we need to get a reaction together think about if it takes longer to recover as we go into late '16, early '17 in the process side, because I personally think what will happen is, there will be a freeze a little bit right now around relative to our customers as they say, "Okay, we're allocating capital. We're cutting capital again 10%, where the number is going to be, we'll see the next 30 to 60 days." And that will create pressure I know on our base relative to smaller projects and MRO projects. So the initial reaction is, I think, we're going to see a slowdown. But hopefully, as we get into the year will start seeing that capital debt -- free back up again. You can't go to 0. Is not going to go to 0. But they're clearly going to reallocate, and they're doing that really fast right now from our customer base. So I'd -- my concern right now is, we're looking at downward pressure relative to our total sales underlying process. We need to take capacity off-line. So from my perspective, right now, we -- initial phase in the last 12 months is very much focused on people, restructuring overall -- overhead cost. And now, when I want to look out the chauffeur going to look out a longer recovery here in this particular part of the process world, we got to look at taking fixed assets off-line. And so now, that's Frank and Ed Purvis and the business leaders at their upcoming reviews would start -- I mean, a week or 2 from now, look at what extra capacity that we may need to take off permanently, if we're looking at a different environment and the capacity be and not be. So that -- -- I think that will lead to a higher level of restructuring later this year, early '17.

componenttext: I don't have orders for January yet. This is February 2. So I don't have that yet. A little bit quick for me and the company. But relative to IA, I think IA got hit harder sooner relative to the space they're in. And so, yes, there might be a little downside to this, but not that much but in thing these guys are sitting really down right now and -- things can always go down for the but my gut tells me they're pretty close to that cycle right now. The process guys, because of the type of business they have, they're still coming off some of the wins and things they won last couple of years. I think that they will continue to slide a little bit here. And that's my biggest concern right now. If I look at the '16 forecast, I always have a little concern, but my biggest concern will be the process guys at this point in time.

componenttext: Yes, yes. I think if you look at the underlying order pace of our Network Power business is -- actually, nose is up. And as of right now, even when [indiscernible] Scott Barbour today and his team is doing a great job out there. The nose is up, continues to move the right way. Profitability continues moving the right way. These guys took some serious actions, hard actions the last 12, 18 months. And right now, I feel good about this broad base, and I feel good that these guys are heading the right way. As of right today, that's what I feel, and so I feel good about that. I think they had a very good first quarter. I mean, it's a long way to go, but if the nose is up right now, and that's a good place to be in any business, as you know.

How is that -- is that delayed in any way?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Network Power, there's no delay going on. I mean, we have a dual path looking at strategic buyers within that business. We also have the fuel path of moving it right down towards the spin. So that path is well underway. On the industrial assets -- aut
componenttext: The Network Power, there's no delay going on. I mean, we have a dual path looking at strategic buyers within that business. We also have the fuel path of moving it right down towards the spin. So that path is well underway. On the industrial assets -- automation assets, I would say that based on what we see right now, we're probably 2 to 3 months behind where I want to be relative to the discussions with strategic buyers. So I would say Network Power had okay. Industrial Automation, given potential customer base, a lot of potential customers, the buyers are clearly seeing some tough times, too. I would say that one is a little bit delayed by a couple of months, but that's as of right now, today, as I report to the board. So that's how I feel.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: We are -- I'm being very careful here. Relative to this business, we are taking some actions early on the combination and not totally across the board, but in certain select areas in preparation of itself. So that will be, by the time we get into the middle of this year, those actions will be well on its way. On the commercial residential solutions business, we are embarking upon that as we speak. And so the -- I think that you're -- both are well underway. I made a commitment to the board. I made a commitment to the individuals, probably even you guys that, by the end of the second -- halfway to the third quarter, we're going to have these things structured properly. Now doesn't mean everything's done, but that's how -- that's what the game plan is at this point in time.

componenttext: No, I meant -- my perspective of Middle East hadn't changed. The risk I see today in the world for spending in -- and you talk about, say, the oil and gas, kind of spending that goes on and just the process pending, North America, China and Latin America. Obviously, some major crisis is going to erupt in the Middle East and things blowing up and stuff like that. But right now, I feel good about that. But my concerns are North American investments and the concerns were going to have on companies that may not make it or if consolidated. And then China, clearly -- I think concerns that as you doesn't my forecast for trying is worse than probably -- most people [indiscernible] a little concerned about that one.

componenttext: That makes sense. David, a year ago at the analyst meeting, you made comments that you thought Canada's petroleum industry was probably going to be better than people expected because there were a lot of obviously reasons for efforts to support domestic businesses, that sort of thing. You think that's changed? I mean the dollar's collapsed a lot. I guess that makes that country a little bit more export competitive or whatnot. But I'm just wondering if you think -- because it's such an important trading partner with the United States, if you think outlook for Canada is kind of sort of where you thought it was before it sort of a similar question on the Middle East only for Canada?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say it's worse. One, they have a new type of government there that doesn't care for this industry. And secondly, the price where it is right now is not good. I would say, from our perspective, what we're doing is we've been restructuring and downsizin
componenttext: I'd say it's worse. One, they have a new type of government there that doesn't care for this industry. And secondly, the price where it is right now is not good. I would say, from our perspective, what we're doing is we've been restructuring and downsizing in Canada. So I mean it's an important market, but strategically, it's going to be a tough market for the next 2 years.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean what's it going to take to get us out of this mess, is my question, really, Dave. Again unless, everybody capitulates, which we saw in 2012. We saw it in 2009, it doesn't do start to bleed into different components of the economy and different busi
componenttext: I mean what's it going to take to get us out of this mess, is my question, really, Dave. Again unless, everybody capitulates, which we saw in 2012. We saw it in 2009, it doesn't do start to bleed into different components of the economy and different businesses that you sell into that aren't being impacted right now start to see impact as we get later on in the, call it, cycle?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can't speak for that people. I mean they've got to be looking at the same issues from the standpoint of too much cost, too much capital, fix investments and investment. We're going to be looking at that in the -- and so eventually they're going to have
componenttext: I can't speak for that people. I mean they've got to be looking at the same issues from the standpoint of too much cost, too much capital, fix investments and investment. We're going to be looking at that in the -- and so eventually they're going to have to say, "Look, we got to take action." A good leader -- if you don't take action, I think some -- there will be some other people coming in and work on that issue. But from our standpoint, I feel quite. Strongly, as you know, we're trying to deal with this issue. I'm trying to call -- we made calls. I make calls. You've known me for a long time. I make a call. Sometime call right. Sometimes the call wrong. But have to may cause and say, "We've got too much capacity. Things are going to be down longer. You got to deal with it." And we start seeing this happen last year. And I think other people are now maybe just turning to see it and starting to deal with it but if you don't have the capability of dealing with it, sometimes it's -- you just sit there and tread water and watch profitability get hit. I think the several companies out there in my opinion, the industry rather, doing your job and dealing with this issue. Some not. And you know that, you can see it. And I don't -- I don't have that magic call. I just know -- I can tell you what we can do. And so I'd know right now that certain things are going the right way. I have a feel for what things are. But I do know, given right now, given what the price of oil and gas is an potentially where to go, we fundamentally will have a capacity issue in that industry, which we didn't have, say, 12 months ago. And so we got to think about how we got to deal with that issue. And that, as you know, also takes time. And so -- but that's what it's on the table right now, and no one wants to deal with that because that's a really hard thing to deal with. But you got to deal with it. Period.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, understood. And I'm encouraged by your comment on price being relatively rational. It was in the last cycle as well. But there's always a little tidbits out there. Caterpillar's been talking about the alternator contract they have with you guys and t
componenttext: Yes, understood. And I'm encouraged by your comment on price being relatively rational. It was in the last cycle as well. But there's always a little tidbits out there. Caterpillar's been talking about the alternator contract they have with you guys and try to drive price down. I mean is that -- you view that act as more of a one-off? Or you have multiple situations going on like that you've been able to hold on price because the competing bids haven't been any better?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: From the standpoint, I think most people are being rational in this thing. Our contract with Caterpillar is a contract and the contract set and they can -- they have the right to go what they do what wanted to, but the contract is set. So from the standpo
componenttext: From the standpoint, I think most people are being rational in this thing. Our contract with Caterpillar is a contract and the contract set and they can -- they have the right to go what they do what wanted to, but the contract is set. So from the standpoint of the overall industry, I would say the biggest issue right now is because volumes are dropping for people and they have excess capacity, trying to fill up lineup for lower price is not a very smart thing to do because it doesn't work for you. So that's why I think it's been more rational here. And so I -- so far, I mean, I think we've mapped up and Frank and Ed Purvis and all the business has laid out a plan what they thought last summer, early fall and going -- we look at it again right now on the pricing. And it's pretty well in line, and I feel good about it. But like I said, 10 years ago, I think it was 12 years ago, I got really sideswiped, and so that's why we spend more time other than probably the average company.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: We'll go next to Shannon O'Callaghan of UBS.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, just within the process spending that you are seeing, I mean we went through this period, which seems like, in a lot of cases, [indiscernible] everything was getting cut upstream, midstream, downstream, maintenance spending. The spending that you ar
componenttext: Dave, just within the process spending that you are seeing, I mean we went through this period, which seems like, in a lot of cases, [indiscernible] everything was getting cut upstream, midstream, downstream, maintenance spending. The spending that you are seeing happening, whether it's some of the downstream stuff or the chemical, what other projects [indiscernible] people willing to spend on right now?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the big projects that are -- say, upstream is that the projects, to a certain point in time that, they see that spending -- I'll just -- I'll make a number. $1 billion more to get cash flow, the customer is going move forward with that. Because if you'
componenttext: On the big projects that are -- say, upstream is that the projects, to a certain point in time that, they see that spending -- I'll just -- I'll make a number. $1 billion more to get cash flow, the customer is going move forward with that. Because if you're stuck, 75% of your project, and you stop and, you got a problem, the project won't be that good, [indiscernible] come back to it in 5 years or whatever. So most people will see that [indiscernible] get spent. That every time they go through a process of having to cut capital within that industry that will fine-tune that. But most people are taking advantage of the environment right now to go out and improve their -- I say the efficiency of the facilities or spending on small capital projects, upgrades that will help them get more out of facility, higher quality, higher yield. So that's what are spending right now, to get more out of each facility. So I mean I still see them spending money. It's an interesting process. They're going through the process of being very selective where they have things going their away, they can throw a lot of money at everything. So the money still being spent. But it's definitely going to be a lot more selective. It's going to be much more on how can I improve the investments we made over the last 10 years to get me more money out of that given the fact that my oil prices are down or my inputs are down, what can we do, so that's being a lot more selective on mold lines and so, which is a good business for us, but it's clearly, you don't have other projects which give you a lot of top line growth with a big bang. But there is money being spent out there.

componenttext: I think that there's -- across Network Power, from the standpoint of the actions they started undertaking last summer and start flowing through and systematically been working in, it's really starting to come through in the final P&L. So I mean our expectation is that this will continue to take hold based on what we see happening in that market, so we should see sequential type of margin improvement in that business, which will be good because Scott and his team have really attacked this. They've become -- they get out of certain businesses, they're investing in other businesses. They did a great job of they want to be in the cost structure they have and other executing around that the flexibility, and my hats off to the team and a very dynamic marketplace. So I think they're heading the right way to feel good about that, and they did a great job executing in the first quarter.

componenttext: Yes, I would say the market -- I mean we have not seen it yet, Rich, from the order pattern that we saw in December. I don't know -- even the forecast for January, I didn't say anything. It could take a little while, but we don't see it yet. I think the marketplace has definitely been very volatile. I think the marketplace is starting to see numbers that we've been seeing. Now we've been -- if you look at the fourth calendar quarter, the third calendar quarter, they were pretty tough quarters for companies like Emerson. And so the market is now digesting that news as they saw out in the earnings report, and the comments people are making right now, and let's say, a little bit more negative about 2016. So I would say that we sort of -- we've been trying to get out of that. And at this point in time, I feel that we've got that size. I don't see the knockout effect what we saw the volatility both in the marketplace and then also the commodity place in January. We have to watch it very carefully unfold, and -- but I look at the construction residential construction and the residential spending for consumer spending in the areas that we are -- they're still holding up pretty well right now. So we'll see. I mean 30 days is pretty short. You got to give us a little -- a few more days here.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, February 2, 2016. Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, February 2, 2016. 
Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain forward-looking statements including the company's outlook for the remainder of the year. Information on factors that could cause actual results to vary materially from those discussed today is available at Emerson's most recent annual report on Form 10-K as filed by the SEC. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Craig Rossman, Director of Investor Relations at Emerson. Please go ahead.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alicia. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; and Frank Dellaquila, Executive VP and Chief Financial Officer. Today's call will summarize Emerson's first quarter 2016 results. A conference call slide
componenttext:
Thank you, Alicia. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; and Frank Dellaquila, Executive VP and Chief Financial Officer. 
Today's call will summarize Emerson's first quarter 2016 results. A conference call slide presentation will accompany my comments and is available on Emerson's website. A replay of this conference call and slide presentation will be available on the website for the next 90 days. 
I will start with the first quarter summary, as shown on Page 2 of the slide presentation. Net sales in the quarter decreased 16% to $4.7 billion with underlying sales down 9%. Our results reflected a continuation of the difficult economic conditions that were experienced during most of fiscal 2015. We continue to find ourselves in the midst of a global industrial recession, and recent economic data suggests that capital spending by industrial businesses weakened during the course of the fourth calendar quarter. 
In the energy sector, lower, but equally as important uncertain oil prices continue to impact both operational and capital spending by our end customers. 
Reported earnings per share in the first quarter decreased 29% to $0.53. Adjusted earnings per share, which exclude $24 million in separation costs, were better than our previous expectation of $0.50. These separation costs relate to our portfolio repositioning actions, specifically the planned spin-off of Network Power and the potential divestitures of the Motors and Drives and Power Generation businesses. 
Overall, the first quarter results were slightly better than our expectations and the company remains well positioned for a challenging 2016. 
Turning to Slide 3. Gross profit margin in the quarter decreased 70 basis points to 40.1%, primarily due to volume deleverage and unfavorable mix. EBIT reflects the impacts of unfavorable currency transactions of $27 million and portfolio repositioning separation costs of $24 million. Additionally, the aggressive restructuring actions initiated in 2015 are beginning to have a positive impact on profitability. 
During the quarter, approximately 12 million shares were repurchased for $554 million. The company still plans for fiscal year share repurchase to reach approximately $1.2 billion. 
Turning to Slide 4. Underlying sales were down in all regions, except Europe, where our euro-based businesses are becoming more globally competitive. 
Turning to Slide 5. Business segment margin declined 170 basis points to 13.3%, primarily due to volume deleverage and unfavorable mix, partially offset by the savings from restructuring actions. 
Operating cash flow was down 15%, reflects the impact of lower earnings. 
Similar to many industrial manufacturers, capital spending was reduced due to lower global demand. Capital spending was down 30%. 
Turning to Slide 6. Process Management underlying sales declined 11% in the quarter. Energy sector spending remained at challenging levels as lower and increasingly uncertain oil prices further pressured spending, particularly in upstream market. Upstream projects underway will continue to completion, but new projects are facing potentially further delays. Downstream markets remain favorable in the U.S., Europe and Middle East, mainly in small- to medium-sized projects in the chemical and power markets. We will continue to shift our resources to capitalize on more favorable business activity levels in downstream and life sciences markets. 
Turning to Slide 7. Industrial Automation first quarter underlying sales declined 15%, reflecting continued weakness from a global industrial recession and reduced levels of spending in upstream oil and gas customers. These conditions are expected to continue into the second quarter with improvements expected in the second half of the fiscal year. 
Turning to Slide 8. Network Power underlying sales declined 1% in the quarter as global demand for data center and telecommunications infrastructure spending was mixed. From a regional perspective, Asia had growth in Australia, India and Southeast Asia while Latin America reflected favorable data center activity levels, particularly in Mexico. Segment margins increased 90 basis points to 8%, benefiting from restructuring actions. Recent order trends have reflected improving conditions in both data center and telecommunications investment. 
Turning to Slide 9. Climate Technologies underlying sales declined 10% as global air conditioning sales decreased, driven by higher U.S. residential demand in the prior year resulting from regulatory changes. Global refrigeration markets grew modestly as growth in the United States and Asia was partially offset by softness in Europe. Demand in the air conditioning and refrigeration markets remains favorable, supporting our outlook for modest levels of growth in 2016. 
Turning to Slide 10. Underlying sales in the Commercial & Residential Solutions segment were down 2%. Favorable activity levels in U.S. construction markets resulted in growth in both the wet-dry vacuums and food waste disposers businesses. Segment margins improved 20 basis points to 21.7% from the favorable impact of the divestiture of the InterMetro business. The favorable trends in U.S. residential and commercial construction continue to support our outlook for modest levels of growth in this segment. 
Turning to Slide 11. As we have indicated, we expect difficult market conditions to persist throughout the fiscal year, but we do still see a bottom forming in both sales and earnings by the middle of 2016. We will continue to execute on our operational plans while diligently working to complete the important portfolio repositioning actions that were announced last June. 
Taking into account our first quarter results and recent order trends, we are reaffirming our fiscal year 2016 guidance. Underlying sales are expected to be down approximately 2% to 5% excluding negative currency translation and a deduction from completed divestitures of approximately 2% each. We continue to expect adjusted earnings per share of $3.05 to $3.25 excluding estimated separation costs of approximately $250 million to $350 million, which are approximately $50 million lower than our previous expectations. 
For the second quarter, underlying sales are expected to be down approximately 4% to 6% excluding negative currency translation and a deduction from completed divestitures of approximately 2% each. Adjusted earnings per share of $0.60 to $0.65 are expected excluding estimated separation costs of approximately $75 million or approximately 11% -- $0.11 per share. 
Our long-standing commitment to return cash flow to our shareholders will be supported by an expected increase in 2016 operating cash flow to approximately $3 billion. 
And with that, I will now turn it over to Mr. David Farr.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Craig. Thank you very much for everyone joining us today, I appreciate that. We are looking forward to seeing our investors and analysts in Austin next week and we'll talk a little bit more about that in a second, but looking really f
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Craig. Thank you very much for everyone joining us today, I appreciate that. We are looking forward to seeing our investors and analysts in Austin next week and we'll talk a little bit more about that in a second, but looking really forward to seeing everyone down there and sharing our plans and ideas to the group. 
I also want to thank everybody across Emerson relative to the execution in the first quarter. Clearly, this is only the first quarter and we have a very detailed undertaking ahead of us relative to sequentially improving our sales, our profitability, our earnings and cash flow from any part of this year. And as I look at the plans we started back from restructuring back in February and I look at the announcement of repositioning that we announced in June, we continue to make very good progress, but it is clearly all about executing around those plans that we put in place and making sure we get it done from the standpoint of driving costs, standpoint of repositioning this company and looking forward to how, as we go through a very challenging global economy, very challenging industrial recession that we see today and coming out of this a stronger company and one that can continue to add assets once we repositioned to a new Emerson platform. 
Looking forward to giving you insight of how we see the 2016  unfolding from an economic standpoint, how we see the numbers happening from the cost of the repositioning, how we see the issues that we may see from a risk standpoint and what we're going to have to do about those if we see additional risks. Those are all things that we'll be talking about. I will defer those until we get together next week. 
Also looking forward to having Bob Sharp and also Steve Sonnenberg talk about the 2 key business segments -- business platforms that we'll be -- that we're moving into: the Commercial & Residential Solutions and then also the Automation solutions. Those 2 individuals will give you insights to what we see, the strength of these platforms, what we can do with those platforms and where we're going to invest going forward. 
Clearly, we have a challenging oil and gas industrial marketplace right now, but it's nothing new. We've been there before. We know what to do to deal with this issue. It's why we started the aggressive restructuring last year. 
As we talk amongst the business leaders, the OC, the board, if the market continues to get challenging, we will continue to do additional restructuring. We'll continue to make sure that the cost structure of this company stays competitive and that we can deliver the highest level of profitability that our shareholders expect from us. That is our -- that is what we're all about right now: executing around that and getting things forward. 
As I look at our current marketplace, the last 30 days have been what I would call the most unusual in my time at Emerson. I've never seen a marketplace go so volatile from the standpoint of the end markets, the stock markets, the interest rates, the -- I guess, the attitude. It's just a very amazing marketplace right now and one that clearly global CEOs like myself have to deal with and be prepared for whatever comes at us. 
But we are now basically in our fourth quarter of the recession. I see, as we'll talk about it next week, I see at least one more quarter, maybe another quarter. But sequentially, our game plan is to improve the business cycle, the business backup and start improving the profitability and that's what we're all about here. 
So with that, I'll open the floor. I'm glad to have the first quarter behind us. I want again to thank the organization. They did a great job executing around the plans we put out there. We're making great progress. And clearly, it's only one quarter. We know that. And our game plan is sequentially improve sales, the profitability, the earnings and the cash flow to our shareholders and establish the premium valuation that this company deserves. 
With that, I open the floor.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Back in August, I think on the earnings call, Dave, you talked about process orders stabilizing, but if oil moved below kind of $30, all bets are off or words to that effect. So here we are, oil is around $30. I'm just wondering how you see that playing out for Process, if it will stay at these levels both this year and then into [indiscernible] FY '17?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me see. Chevron reported a loss, BP reported a loss, so I would say the market's stressed. So from my perspective right now, I would say the capital markets in oil and gas is going to be lower. Our expectation for our Process business will be lower an
componenttext: Let me see. Chevron reported a loss, BP reported a loss, so I would say the market's stressed. So from my perspective right now, I would say the capital markets in oil and gas is going to be lower. Our expectation for our Process business will be lower and we'll have to do additional restructuring. We are looking at a situation, in my opinion, the oil and gas marketplaces that will now recover until well past the middle of '17, maybe late '17. Fortunately, we have 75% of the business that doesn't serve the oil and gas marketplace. So even though we'll talk about this next week, oil and gas spinning down, it's not going to 0. It will be a tougher marketplace and we'll have to work harder at it. And clearly, there is a lot of uncertainty around this, but the game is we're going to have to figure out how to get the sales, how to get the business and get our costs down and it will clearly be a tougher year in '16 than we thought. That's the game. Pretty straightforward.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And in the call, so I guess, in January, you guys announced a big project with Tahrir Petrochem, I think, $150 million. I'm just interested to see you guys taking a preferred equity investment in that customer. I was wondering, is that reflec
componenttext: Okay, great. And in the call, so I guess, in January, you guys announced a big project with Tahrir Petrochem, I think, $150 million. I'm just interested to see you guys taking a preferred equity investment in that customer. I was wondering, is that reflective of the competitive environment where alongside price you're now kind of having to think of other ways to win business? Or how do you think about that and how should we think about it going forward on other kind of big, large projects?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've done similar things in the past. This is unique, which is very strategic for the country of Egypt and we felt that, as did other people, we're not the only that did this. We're probably the only one going public with it. But I think that you'll see
componenttext: We've done similar things in the past. This is unique, which is very strategic for the country of Egypt and we felt that, as did other people, we're not the only that did this. We're probably the only one going public with it. But I think that you'll see this happening from time to time. It is -- it's a huge opportunity for us and it really also about forming a relationship because I think once this project's done and is successful, there'll be future projects and it will happen. But it's not for every customer. It's not for every marketplace. But this one, we worked on a long time and I met with the CEO and we had a long conversations and I feel that this makes a lot of sense for us relative to a strategic relationship going forward. So I don't think -- it's not -- it's just our commitment to making sure that these guys are successful and we're going to have a lot of business with them for many years to come.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
