componenttext: We'll go next to Josh Pokrzywinski from Buckingham Research.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Dave, just looking at the order trends here in Process in December. Obviously, the month-to-month can be volatile with different project activity and what stays and goes throughout the comp books. But maybe just comment on how that month looked and any
componenttext: So Dave, just looking at the order trends here in Process in December. Obviously, the month-to-month can be volatile with different project activity and what stays and goes throughout the comp books. But maybe just comment on how that month looked and any kind of body language you've gotten just with the last $10 move. Obviously, projects don't go forward for even a month of oil prices, but maybe what is -- what the psychology has been with this last move down?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, to be honest, I think the psychology is very nervous and tense within the big oil and gas investors at this point in time. I think that we see -- from our perspective, what we're looking at is that what we'll talk to you next week we're trying to
componenttext: I think, to be honest, I think the psychology is very nervous and tense within the big oil and gas investors at this point in time. I think that we see -- from our perspective, what we're looking at is that what we'll talk to you next week we're trying to encompass what we think the downside will be relative to oil and gas in the Process businesses. But I would say, the December quarter for orders for Process were not that bad. We pretty well have that factored in, in what's going on. I would say that my concern is the psyche of a Chevron or a psyche of a Exxon Mobil, a psyche of these Shells and the BPs and things like that will -- are going to again freeze up some of that spending level. They can't go to 0, but I think it's going to make it tougher. So my gut tells me that it is going to be more challenging in the near term in our oil and gas -- I mean, our Process order pace will be a drag and the other businesses will start pulling back up. So that's where we are at this point in time. I think I've always -- we'll give you an update on what I think the Process segment's going to do, but it's going to be -- there'll be more negative based on -- because on the first question, I did say that when the price of oil has gotten to down to that level, there'll be an impact and I think, right now, our underlying sales will be more negative in the Process than we thought originally, and hence, we're going to have to go out with more caution there. So -- but the psyche's not good in that space right now. Fortunately, there's more investments going on in the other parts of the marketplace and it's a big part of the marketplace, but the oil and gas investment area is not very good right now and I think it's going to hurt us for the second half of this year.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And obviously, you'll touch more on this next week. But I think, maybe looking at the last quarter, the expectation on being able to hold the line on price somewhat and being able to hold the line on margins this year, assuming all that plays out, what we
componenttext: And obviously, you'll touch more on this next week. But I think, maybe looking at the last quarter, the expectation on being able to hold the line on price somewhat and being able to hold the line on margins this year, assuming all that plays out, what we're seeing today, I would imagine those 2 items are also part of that discussion that maybe goes out the window as well?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not going gone out the window. I mean, from the standpoint of -- the pricing right now is -- when we make a forecast for it, we look at ranges. We have ranges. There's a reason why we go 2% to 5% or other ranges in underlying sales. We look at also p
componenttext: It's not going gone out the window. I mean, from the standpoint of -- the pricing right now is -- when we make a forecast for it, we look at ranges. We have ranges. There's a reason why we go 2% to 5% or other ranges in underlying sales. We look at also pricing environment changing, too. So the pricing environment today is still within the range that we laid out when we put our plan together back in August and September and talked to you all in November and that material inflation has continued to drop down. So we're going to give you a forecast. We'll give you a range of what it looks like right now. But it's well within a range. I would say the one negative will be the sales -- underlying sales in Process will be more negative and the profitability will still be very good and we're going to have to take some additional restructuring, both for the '16 and '17 in that space because the recovery will be long. And it's -- we're going to see what our customer base does right now. As you said, man, they don't move that fast, but I know the psyche is not good. I mean, you just have to look at the reports that came out in the last 3 days or 4 days relative to 2 major oil and gas providers.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Andrew Kaplowitz from Citigroup.
componenttext: We'll go next to Andrew Kaplowitz from Citigroup.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, so on the last quarter's call, you talked about the expectation that we might see one more quarter where inventory in the channel could be worked down and then by 2Q destocking could be high -- it could be behind Emerson. Did you see -- I think you
componenttext: Dave, so on the last quarter's call, you talked about the expectation that we might see one more quarter where inventory in the channel could be worked down and then by 2Q destocking could be high -- it could be behind Emerson. Did you see -- I think you saw continued destocking in the quarter. Do you think inventories in the channels are low enough or that destocking for the whole company should end as we go through fiscal 2Q and then the second half of '16?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, what my knowledge is right now, inventory levels within the channel for the -- including ourselves, are levels that -- they're pretty good levels, low. And so the pace of business right now and the run rates where I see, I would say the inven
componenttext: I would say, what my knowledge is right now, inventory levels within the channel for the -- including ourselves, are levels that -- they're pretty good levels, low. And so the pace of business right now and the run rates where I see, I would say the inventory levels are pretty good for us. I don't see much of a downward draft on that now. I think it's pretty well over with, probably very minor downward draft. I think it's pretty well there around on the world. I mean, I've been in Asia, I've been around the world and I don't see the inventory being a big issue for us right now. So that's a good thing.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just asking about China. You talked about China in '16 maybe being down mid-single digits on your last call and maybe down 15% in 1Q, but you actually did down 13%. So do you think you can get China stabilized a little bit for you in term
componenttext: Got it. And then just asking about China. You talked about China in '16 maybe being down mid-single digits on your last call and maybe down 15% in 1Q, but you actually did down 13%. So do you think you can get China stabilized a little bit for you in terms of the decline? And do you still expect mid-single digits for '16 to hold down mid-single digits?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, I called down 15% and down 13%. I would say that's a pretty good forecast call right there without knowing what was going to happen. So I don't know, if I could do that, maybe should I should go into investment mode, but -- just joking
componenttext: Well, first of all, I called down 15% and down 13%. I would say that's a pretty good forecast call right there without knowing what was going to happen. So I don't know, if I could do that, maybe should I should go into investment mode, but -- just joking clearly. I think that China, in my opinion today, the forecast, when you put that out there, I still think that's still going to be that mid-single-plus digit. I think it's going to be in that 5%, 6%, 7% range negative. I don't see it changing. I would say my China organization is more optimistic than that. They're less negative. But I think that looking at what I see going on in China and the marketplace around the world, I think that, that's going to be a tough one for them to do. Though they are working through the inventory that was built up in 20 -- first part of 2015, but my gut tells me that I would not be surprised if we don't finish at minus 7% or 8% in China when it's all said and done. So write that down so you can see me how a good forecaster I was with it.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Joe Ritchie of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll go next to Joe Ritchie of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- so maybe focusing a little bit on your commentary about the last 30 days ever being so volatile and then just taking a look at the order trends. It's interesting. As you look at the trends, you think about the last 30 days, it's interesting that yo
componenttext: The -- so maybe focusing a little bit on your commentary about the last 30 days ever being so volatile and then just taking a look at the order trends. It's interesting. As you look at the trends, you think about the last 30 days, it's interesting that you haven't really updated your guidance for the underlying growth rate for the year. Recognize the comps are going to get easier as we get through the year. But why not maybe be a little bit more, I guess, conservative with the underlying order trends -- or with the underlying organic growth trends for 2016?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Because I think that when we put our plan together, we had certain assumptions relative to the volatility in the marketplace and what the market is going to look like. And as I look at all analysis and I look at the upsides or downsides, I think, right no
componenttext: Because I think that when we put our plan together, we had certain assumptions relative to the volatility in the marketplace and what the market is going to look like. And as I look at all analysis and I look at the upsides or downsides, I think, right now, we're still well within that boundary and to come out and to widen that boundary right now is not what I find acceptable. I think our organization, at this point in time, we're well within that even with a 30-day risk. I mean the risk in the 30 days is more around one piece of the company, I mean, and the standpoint -- I mean, Europe's not that case. It's primarily around the oil and gas, the price of oil and gas investments. So it's not the whole economy, but it's definitely -- I mean, we encompass what we thought could possibly happen to us and now it could get worse and I'll a talk a little bit about that in Austin. But right now, I think we're well inside the boundaries of what we put out there.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Okay, fair enough. And maybe about talk about...
componenttext: All right. Okay, fair enough. And maybe about talk about...

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We got ahead a little bit in the first quarter now, so it did help a little bit there that we've made progress better than I thought. So clearly, it helped me a little bit, but it's obviously our easiest quarter. I mean, I'm not a fool. I know that.
componenttext: We got ahead a little bit in the first quarter now, so it did help a little bit there that we've made progress better than I thought. So clearly, it helped me a little bit, but it's obviously our easiest quarter. I mean, I'm not a fool. I know that.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, that makes sense. Maybe talking about the cost actions then for a second, I just want to make sure I've got my numbers straight. You spent a little over $220 million in restructuring in 2015. I think there was another $13 million in 1Q...
componenttext: Sure, that makes sense. Maybe talking about the cost actions then for a second, I just want to make sure I've got my numbers straight. You spent a little over $220 million in restructuring in 2015. I think there was another $13 million in 1Q...

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct, correct.
componenttext: Correct, correct.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the benefits that came through this quarter? Clearly, they're helping the margins a little bit, and maybe your expectations on cadence as we progress through the year?
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the benefits that came through this quarter? Clearly, they're helping the margins a little bit, and maybe your expectations on cadence as we progress through the year?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that -- what we see right now, around $80 million improvement came through in the first quarter. They'll be -- from the standpoint of restructuring, there's still a big number in the second quarter. My gut tells me that we'll probably be arou
componenttext: Yes, I think that -- what we see right now, around $80 million improvement came through in the first quarter. They'll be -- from the standpoint of restructuring, there's still a big number in the second quarter. My gut tells me that we'll probably be around, in restructuring, around $20 million in the second quarter and then we're going to be increasing this. The question is, can I get it done in the third or fourth quarter? Is it going to be more in the early part of next year? But clearly, I think you're going to be looking at the 20-page for each quarter now as we start pushing in anticipation of concerns that we may have in the marketplace out there. Savings-wise, you're going to be building for this 80 and incrementally be coming up towards the, I would say, the 90 level by the time we get to that fourth quarter and that's basically how we see that happening per quarter.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Mike Wood of Macquarie Securities Group.
componenttext: We'll go next to Mike Wood of Macquarie Securities Group.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good job executing in a very tough backdrop. I'd like to follow up an earlier question the price. Have you actually began to see the increased price competition in Process? And has that been rational? And just given the fact there's very little project ac
componenttext: Good job executing in a very tough backdrop. I'd like to follow up an earlier question the price. Have you actually began to see the increased price competition in Process? And has that been rational? And just given the fact there's very little project activity out there, I'm just curious how you actually measure that price change.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've made the price change, obviously, on the contracts. We also mentioned price change that we have to give on short-term actions from the standpoint of day-to-day business. So it's very measurable because we see the average pricing within the str
componenttext: Well, we've made the price change, obviously, on the contracts. We also mentioned price change that we have to give on short-term actions from the standpoint of day-to-day business. So it's very measurable because we see the average pricing within the structure of the business. But you're right, there's not been a lot of big bids around what I would say the oil and gas or the bigger -- the other big projects. So the pricing has been rational. The other issue is right now, like our European competitors, we're also a major player in the Process flowing out of Europe and so we're not -- we get the benefit of that, too. So what I see going to happen is we're going to be seeing sales shift to our European operations because we've been working for this the last 12 months. The dollar really started appreciating last year, a little over a year ago. So we've been working to get our rebound cost structure, which we'll continue to do. So our European organization right now is seeing the benefit of a lower cost structure. So they're winning and I would say you're going to see other regions in the world lose. So we're pushing around the world, just like our European competitors do, and that's one of the benefits we do have relatively to having a broad manufacturing bases in all these businesses. So I feel reasonably comfortable right now on the forecast we're going to give you for price. I mean, we track this extremely hard. I don't know how long you've been following us, but I'll be the first one to mention in the early 2002-2003 time, I can't remember exactly when that was, we got line of sight on how fast this thing moved, but now we've created a lot tougher tracking process and so I can tell what's going on across this company. And it's tracking -- it's going to be a little more negative this year than last year, but well within what I thought we were going to see and well within the net material inflation level so -- and people are acting rational. It's going to be an interesting year to see. A lot of people are trying to improve their profitability on down volume and dropping price in a down volume to try to improve your profitability does not work. Economics 101. It does not work.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And given the recent volatility you mentioned in crude, how does that impact the downstream businesses and MRO and your investments that you're making?
componenttext: Understood. And given the recent volatility you mentioned in crude, how does that impact the downstream businesses and MRO and your investments that you're making?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things. I am concerned as to why I think we're talking about we need to get our action together and think about if it takes longer to recover as we go into late '16 or early '17 in the Process side because I personally think what will happen is there'
componenttext: Two things. I am concerned as to why I think we're talking about we need to get our action together and think about if it takes longer to recover as we go into late '16 or early '17 in the Process side because I personally think what will happen is there'll be a freeze a little bit right now to allow our customers as they say, okay, we're reallocating capital. We're cutting capital again 10% or where that number's going to be. We'll see here in the next 30 to 60 days. And that will create pressure on, I know, our base relative to smaller projects and the MRO projects. So the initial reaction is, I think, we're going to see a slowdown and then hopefully, as we get into the year, we'll start seeing that capital back -- free back up again. They can't go to 0. It's not going to go to 0. But they're clearly going to reallocate and they're doing that really fast right now from our customer base. So I -- my concern right now is we're looking at downward pressure relative to our total sales underlying process. We need to take capacity off-line. So from my perspective, right now, we -- initial phase is for the last 12 months is very much focused on people, on restructuring overall -- overhead costs. And now, what I want to look at -- if we're going to look at a longer recovery here in this particular part of the Process world, we've got to look at taking fixed assets off-line. And so now, that's Frank and Ed Purvis and the business leaders have their upcoming reviews, which start, I think, a week or 2 from now. Look at what extra capacity that we may need to take off permanently if we're looking at a different environment and where should that capacity be and not be. So that's -- I think that will lead to higher levels of restructuring later this year, early '17.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Julian Mitchell of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll go next to Julian Mitchell of Credit Suisse.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned earlier that you thought Process would lag in recovery than some of the other businesses. But I guess, if we look at Industrial Automation, it does seem it's got pretty bad there. So maybe just comment on how you see IA playing out. And rela
componenttext: You mentioned earlier that you thought Process would lag in recovery than some of the other businesses. But I guess, if we look at Industrial Automation, it does seem it's got pretty bad there. So maybe just comment on how you see IA playing out. And related to that, any color you can give on orders in January?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have orders for January yet. This is February 2, so I don't have that yet. It's a little bit quick for me and the company. But relative to IA, I think IA got hit harder sooner relative to the space they're in. And so, yes, there might be a little
componenttext: I don't have orders for January yet. This is February 2, so I don't have that yet. It's a little bit quick for me and the company. But relative to IA, I think IA got hit harder sooner relative to the space they're in. And so, yes, there might be a little downside risk in IA, but not that much. I think these guys are sitting really down pretty far right now and things can only go down further, but my gut tells me they're pretty close to that cycle right now. The Process guys, because of the type of business they have, they're still coming off some of the wins and things they won last couple of years. So I think that they will continue to slide a little bit here and that's my biggest concern right now. But if I look at the '16 forecast, I always have a little IA concern, but my biggest concern would be the Process guys at this point in time.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Network Power, orders looked a little less bad than a few months ago. Margins were up. You have a big project in Europe you're working on. But outside and beyond that, do you think you've succeeded now in sort of stabilizing the earnings in Netwo
componenttext: And then Network Power, orders looked a little less bad than a few months ago. Margins were up. You have a big project in Europe you're working on. But outside and beyond that, do you think you've succeeded now in sort of stabilizing the earnings in Network Power and the rest of the year we should see that stable margin play out?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. I think if you look at the underlying order pace of our Network Power business is -- actually nose is up. And as of right now, even -- when I saw Scott Barbour today and his team's doing a great job out there. The nose is up, continues to move t
componenttext: Yes, yes. I think if you look at the underlying order pace of our Network Power business is -- actually nose is up. And as of right now, even -- when I saw Scott Barbour today and his team's doing a great job out there. The nose is up, continues to move the right way. Profitability continues to move in the right way. These guys took some serious actions, hard actions the last 12, 18 months. And right now, I feel good about -- it's a broad base and I feel good that these guys are heading the right way. As of right today, that's what I feel. And so I feel good about that. I think they had a very good first quarter. I mean, it's a long way to go, but if the nose is up right now and that's a good place to be in any business, as you know.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Steven Winoker of Bernstein.
componenttext: We'll go next to Steven Winoker of Bernstein.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, given all the commentary in sort of how obvious the volatility is right now, what's going on with the process, the capital deployment process, or I should say, the sales process for Industrial Automation, some of those assets, and the separation act
componenttext: Dave, given all the commentary in sort of how obvious the volatility is right now, what's going on with the process, the capital deployment process, or I should say, the sales process for Industrial Automation, some of those assets, and the separation activities for Network Power? How is that -- is that delayed in any way?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Network Power assets, there's no delay going on. I mean, we have a dual path looking at strategic buyers within that business. We also have the build path of moving right down towards a spin. So that path is well underway. On the Industrial assets --
componenttext: The Network Power assets, there's no delay going on. I mean, we have a dual path looking at strategic buyers within that business. We also have the build path of moving right down towards a spin. So that path is well underway. On the Industrial assets -- Automation assets, I would say that based on what we see right now, we're probably 2 to 3 months behind where I want to be relative to the discussions with strategic buyers. So I would say Network Power, heading okay. Industrial Automation, given potential customer base, a lot of the potential customers or buyers of this thing clearly are seeing some tough times, too. So I would say that one's a little bit delayed by a couple of months, but that's as of right now, today as I report to the board. So that's how I feel.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Dave. And then also the combination of Process and Industrial, in other words, the future structure of the business, the future Emerson here. Are you taking actions already to combine overhead or other elements of these 2 businesses yet? Or is it ju
componenttext: Okay, Dave. And then also the combination of Process and Industrial, in other words, the future structure of the business, the future Emerson here. Are you taking actions already to combine overhead or other elements of these 2 businesses yet? Or is it just stand-alone, frankly, until you get that other process done and then you'll go down this one?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are -- I'm being very careful here. Relative to this business, we are taking some actions early on the combination and not totally across-the-board, but in certain select areas in preparation of it. So that will be, by the time we get into the middle o
componenttext: We are -- I'm being very careful here. Relative to this business, we are taking some actions early on the combination and not totally across-the-board, but in certain select areas in preparation of it. So that will be, by the time we get into the middle of this year, those actions will be well on its way. On the Commercial & Residential Solutions business, we are embarking upon that as we speak. And so the -- I think that you're -- both are well underway. I made a commitment to the board, I made a commitment to the individuals and I mean I think I probably told you guys that by the end of the second -- halfway to the third quarter, we're going to have these things structured properly. Now it doesn't mean everything's done, but that's how -- that's what the game plan is at this point in time.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Eli Lustgarten of Longbow Securities.
componenttext: We'll go to Eli Lustgarten of Longbow Securities.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I've got one quick question on the Process side and you talked about the upstream projects, some on completion, new projects. What push in the business at this point still relates to the upstream projects that have been completed? And I mean how much does
componenttext: I've got one quick question on the Process side and you talked about the upstream projects, some on completion, new projects. What push in the business at this point still relates to the upstream projects that have been completed? And I mean how much does that disappear? I mean, where does that go to as you go through the year. Does that go to a very minor part? Or how do we handle that?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have those exact numbers. I can't give you that. I mean, I can't break it out that way. I know what our oil and gas percentage will be this year in upstream. I mean, I know it's still going to be a significant percentage of our total business. It
componenttext: I don't have those exact numbers. I can't give you that. I mean, I can't break it out that way. I know what our oil and gas percentage will be this year in upstream. I mean, I know it's still going to be a significant percentage of our total business. It will be next year, too, but it's not going to 0. People just don't stop it. We will give you our best feel for it next week. I have some ideas where we think the segment's going to go. But they don't move that fast. And it's really hard to say because it's -- what we talked about, what you think about are not necessarily how everyone looks at this business in a day-to-day business standpoint. So I can't give you that information, to be honest.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just trying to sense that, that's the part that's disappearing and trying to see are we close to bottom of that impacting or -- and you're sort of indicating that by the middle of the year [indiscernible] tackled it. You talked about having to do some res
componenttext: Just trying to sense that, that's the part that's disappearing and trying to see are we close to bottom of that impacting or -- and you're sort of indicating that by the middle of the year [indiscernible] tackled it. You talked about having to do some restructuring in Process because of market that's quite easily understood. But can you talk about whether you're starting to look at Industrial Automation in the same way? I mean, it's a very weak market, weak condition and so that there's more or a second level of restructuring there to try to hold profitability better because that profitably can be under a lot of pressure if the demand stays in the current way.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've laid at the restructuring that we have intended to do this year relative to Industrial Automation business and that's well underway. I'm also in the process of selling that business. So from my perspective, I mean, I will lead, there's more of
componenttext: Well, we've laid at the restructuring that we have intended to do this year relative to Industrial Automation business and that's well underway. I'm also in the process of selling that business. So from my perspective, I mean, I will lead, there's more of this restructuring, looks like, for the potential buyer of the company. I have a business plan laid out, which is being worked on right now. I don't see anything at this point in time. Now if we make the decision we're not going to sell this Industrial Automation asset, then that's all in assortment [ph]. But right now, we're down a path that we're going to sell that asset.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to John Inch of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll go next to John Inch of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So last quarter, you called out, in general, incremental concerns possibly about Middle East. Has your thought process changed because there's obviously been some conjecture around possible efforts to curtail production, and you called out volatile. I'm j
componenttext: So last quarter, you called out, in general, incremental concerns possibly about Middle East. Has your thought process changed because there's obviously been some conjecture around possible efforts to curtail production, and you called out volatile. I'm just curious, has anything changed in the last few months with respect to your perspective on Middle East?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I meant -- my perspective on Middle East hasn't changed. I think that the risk I see today in the world for spending in -- and you're talking about, say, the oil and gas, the type of spending that goes on and just the process pending, North America, C
componenttext: No, I meant -- my perspective on Middle East hasn't changed. I think that the risk I see today in the world for spending in -- and you're talking about, say, the oil and gas, the type of spending that goes on and just the process pending, North America, China and Latin America. Those are 3 concerned areas I have relative to the spending around that industry. I just came back from the Middle East. I mean, the national economy has to spend a certain level of money and they've been cutting back and I think we probably have that built in. So I feel okay there right now as of right now. Obviously, some major crisis is going to erupt in the Middle East and things blowing up and stuff like that. But right now, I feel reasonably good about that. But my concerns are North America investments and the concerns we're going to have on companies that may not make it or as they consolidated. And then China, clearly, I think, as you -- I've got my forecast for China, it's worse than probably most people say out there, so I'm a little concerned about that one.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. David, a year ago at the analyst meeting, you made comments that you thought Canada's petroleum industry was probably going to be better than people expected because there were a lot of obviously reasons for it, efforts to support domest
componenttext: That makes sense. David, a year ago at the analyst meeting, you made comments that you thought Canada's petroleum industry was probably going to be better than people expected because there were a lot of obviously reasons for it, efforts to support domestic businesses, that sort of thing. You think that's changed? I mean the dollar's collapsed a lot. I guess, debatably it makes that country a little more export-competitive or whatnot. But I'm just wondering if you think, because it's such an important trading partner with the United States, if you think outlook for Canada is kind of sort of where you thought it was before? It's sort of a similar question on the Middle East only for Canada.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say it's worse. One, they have a new type of government there that doesn't necessarily care for this industry. And secondly, the price, where it is right now, is not good. So I would say, from our perspective, what we've been doing is we've been restr
componenttext: I'd say it's worse. One, they have a new type of government there that doesn't necessarily care for this industry. And secondly, the price, where it is right now, is not good. So I would say, from our perspective, what we've been doing is we've been restructuring and downsizing in Canada. So I mean, it's an important market, but strategically it's going to be a tough market for the next 2 years.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just lastly, Dave. You obviously touched an awful lot of verticals, right, lots of different things. So kind of ex petroleum, do you think that -- I mean, are you guys tracking maybe some end markets or verticals or other things within Emerson that actual
componenttext: Just lastly, Dave. You obviously touched an awful lot of verticals, right, lots of different things. So kind of ex petroleum, do you think that -- I mean, are you guys tracking maybe some end markets or verticals or other things within Emerson that actually could be contributively positive or surprise kind of to the upside, let's call it, in the next, I don't know, 12 months -- 6, 12 months?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're going to talk about -- I'm going to give you -- we're going to give you a different view of the verticals and the growth rate next week. And I think the answer is yes. I think there are some verticals that are going to do better than people thi
componenttext: Yes. We're going to talk about -- I'm going to give you -- we're going to give you a different view of the verticals and the growth rate next week. And I think the answer is yes. I think there are some verticals that are going to do better than people think and so -- and that's where -- we started talking about this last summer. We've been reallocating our resources, really pushing hard reallocating our resources. We've had a very, very good run in the oil and gas upstream and we gained a lot of growth, we've gained a lot of market share. And now what we're going to do is refocusing on those resources and so we'll talk a little bit about that next week because what you just said is exactly right. And there are markets out there and we're -- the whole organization within Process Management is focused on how they can go out after those markets, reenergize their workforce and go after that.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: We'll go next to Robert McCarthy of Stifel.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Yes, maybe we could just go back to, I think, a kind of a question I asked in the last call. I'm not trying to put words in your mouth, but I think it was to that effect. And then...

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. I guess the only other question I have is -- I mean, you did mention, and this dovetails with the question I just asked, but I think you did mention like we've come through 4 quarters of what looks like an industrial recession. You thin
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. I guess the only other question I have is -- I mean, you did mention, and this dovetails with the question I just asked, but I think you did mention like we've come through 4 quarters of what looks like an industrial recession. You think there's about 2 -- 1 to 2 left. And are you seeing anything in the GFI or just the order patterns or the trajectory absent kind of process management vertical where it's obviously dynamic and tied to the commodity price where you can kind of point to an upward trajectory or reason for recovery there in terms of the macro?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the answer is yes. And on April -- the call is April 1, April 1, and I mean I'm talking about the April orders, you know that. And then -- I'm -- we, right now, Frank and I'll sit here, we tell you we believe that our underlying sales will go positiv
componenttext: Yes, the answer is yes. And on April -- the call is April 1, April 1, and I mean I'm talking about the April orders, you know that. And then -- I'm -- we, right now, Frank and I'll sit here, we tell you we believe that our underlying sales will go positive in the third quarter based on the trajectories we see. We make -- I felt that all year long and Frank's crossing his fingers over there. He's a great CFO really -- stay right behind me, man. He's right behind me with a gun to my back. But no, I still believe that. And the key issue -- now keep in mind, if you're paying attention, I'll give it to you. We said that first quarter underlying sales will be down probably 9% to 10%. We finished a little bit under 9%. The last time I talked on the phone, I said underlying sales will be down 5% to 7% in the second quarter. I'm now -- Frank and I believe that our underlying sales will be down 4% to 6% in the second quarter. So the key issue for us as we map out and we get together, we'll give you an insight on orders when we're together next week. We're trying to get orders. Somebody asked me a question about January, we'll try to get those to get those so we can at least have a sense when we're together next week. [indiscernible] would stop going to play basketball so much and watching LeBron James, maybe we could get him. But -- so I think right now, I'm standing behind that. And I mean, the chart's going to say April's orders go above positive and second -- third quarter sales will be -- have a plus [indiscernible] underlying sales. And [indiscernible] will not be standing there talking to me.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm trying to reconcile, I think like everybody else, I mean, you're bearish but you're still calling things getting better in April. But I think the angle I want to take is that and there's a good and bad here. And the good is that you mentioned a commen
componenttext: I'm trying to reconcile, I think like everybody else, I mean, you're bearish but you're still calling things getting better in April. But I think the angle I want to take is that and there's a good and bad here. And the good is that you mentioned a comment, fixed assets off-line, and we've been writing that we think the entire industry needs to do this. But you guys are the only ones that are really doing it. So how do you -- how do we get out of this mess? If you're one of the only companies that's willing to admit that it's a, for a lack of a better word, a bit of a sh** show out there, how do we get out of this mess to where even if your orders turn, call it, slightly positive, I mean, it's probably more flattish than positive to be more realistic, but how do we get out of this...

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: They'll be above the line, though. They'll be above the line. I actually got my nose above the water [indiscernible], Scott.
componenttext: They'll be above the line, though. They'll be above the line. I actually got my nose above the water [indiscernible], Scott.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, what's it going to take to get us out of this mess is my question, really, Dave. Because, again, unless everybody capitulates, which we saw in 2002, we saw it in 2009, doesn't it just start to bleed into different components of the economy and dif
componenttext: I mean, what's it going to take to get us out of this mess is my question, really, Dave. Because, again, unless everybody capitulates, which we saw in 2002, we saw it in 2009, doesn't it just start to bleed into different components of the economy and different businesses that you sell into that aren't being impacted right now start to see impact as we get later on in the, call it, cycle?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can't speak to those people. I mean, they've got to be looking at the same issues from the standpoint of too much costs, too much capital, fixed investments invested. They've got to be looking at that in the -- and so eventually they're going to have to
componenttext: I can't speak to those people. I mean, they've got to be looking at the same issues from the standpoint of too much costs, too much capital, fixed investments invested. They've got to be looking at that in the -- and so eventually they're going to have to say, look, we've got to take action. A good leader -- if they don't take action, I think some -- there will be some other people come in and work on that issue. But from our standpoint, I feel quite strongly, as you know, we're trying to deal with this issue. I'm trying to call -- we made calls. I made calls. You've known me for a long time. I make a call. Sometime I call right, sometimes I call it wrong. But you have to make calls and say, we've got too much capacity. Things are going to be down longer. You've got to deal with it. And we start seeing this happen last year. And I think other people are now maybe just starting to see it and they're starting to deal with it. But if you don't have the capability of dealing with it, sometimes it's -- you just sit there and tread water and watch your profitability get hit. I think there are several companies out there. In my opinion, the industry right now, they're doing a good job in dealing with this issue. There are several companies that are not, and you know that. You can see it. And I don't have that magic call, I just know -- I can tell you what we can do. And so I'd know right now that certain things are going the right way. I have a feel for what things are. But I do know, that given right now, given where the price of oil and gas is and potentially where to go, we fundamentally will have a capacity issue in that industry, which we didn't have, say, 12 months ago. And so we've got to think about how we get to deal with that issue and that, as you know, also takes time. And so -- but that's on the table right now and no one wants to deal with that because that's a really hard thing to deal with. But you've got to deal with it. Period.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, understood. And I'm encouraged by your comment on price being relatively rational, it was in the last cycle as well. But there's always little tidbits out there. Caterpillar's been talking about the alternator contract they have with you guys an
componenttext: Yes, yes, understood. And I'm encouraged by your comment on price being relatively rational, it was in the last cycle as well. But there's always little tidbits out there. Caterpillar's been talking about the alternator contract they have with you guys and trying to drive price down. I mean, is that -- you view that as more of a one-off? Or you have multiple situations going on like that, but you've been able to hold on price because the competing bids haven't been any better?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: From the standpoint, I think most people are being rational on this thing. Our contract with Caterpillar is a contract and the contract's set and they can -- they have the right to go do what they want to, but the contract's set. So from the standpoint of
componenttext: From the standpoint, I think most people are being rational on this thing. Our contract with Caterpillar is a contract and the contract's set and they can -- they have the right to go do what they want to, but the contract's set. So from the standpoint of the overall industry, I would say the biggest issue right now is because volumes are dropping for people and they have excess capacity, trying to fill up a plant up for lower price is not a very smart thing to do because it doesn't work for you. That's why I think it's been more rational here. And so I -- so far, I mean, I think we've mapped it out and Frank and Ed Purvis and all the business leaders laid out a plan what they thought last summer, early fall and going -- we'll look at it again right now on the pricing. And it's pretty well in line and I feel good about it. But like I said, 10 years ago I think it was or 12 years ago, I got really sideswiped and so that's why we spend more time on it than probably the average company.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Shannon O'Callaghan of UBS.
componenttext: We'll go next to Shannon O'Callaghan of UBS.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, just within the Process spending that you are seeing, I mean we went through this period, which seems like, in a lot of cases we're still in where seemingly everything was getting cut upstream, midstream, downstream, maintenance spending. The spendi
componenttext: Dave, just within the Process spending that you are seeing, I mean we went through this period, which seems like, in a lot of cases we're still in where seemingly everything was getting cut upstream, midstream, downstream, maintenance spending. The spending that you are seeing happening, whether it's some of the downstream stuff or the chemical, what are the projects exactly? What are people willing to spend on right now?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the big projects that are -- say, upstream is that the projects, to a certain point in time, they see that spending -- I'll just -- I'll make a number up, $1 billion more to get cash flow, the customer is going move forward with that. Because if you're
componenttext: On the big projects that are -- say, upstream is that the projects, to a certain point in time, they see that spending -- I'll just -- I'll make a number up, $1 billion more to get cash flow, the customer is going move forward with that. Because if you're stuck 75% into a project and you stop, then you've got a problem because the project won't be that good by the time you come back to it in 5 years or wherever. So most people you're seeing, those monies will get spent. Now every time they go through a process of having to cut capital within that industry, that will fine-tune that. But most people are taking advantage of the environment right now to go out and improve their, I say, the efficiency. The facilities are spending on small capital projects, upgrades that will help them get more out of the facility, higher quality, higher yield. So that's where they're spending right now to get more of each facility. I mean, I see them still spending money. It's just an interesting process. They're going through the process of being very selective where when they have -- things are going their away, they threw a lot of money and everything. So the money is still being spent. But it's definitely be a lot more selective and it's going to be much more on how can I improve the investments we made over the last 10 years to get me more money out of that given the fact that my oil prices are down or my inputs are down, what can I do, so that's -- they're being a lot more selective along those lines and so -- which is a good business for us, but clearly you don't have the big projects, which give you a lot of top line growth with a big bang. But there's money being spent out there.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on Network Power, I mean, nice margin result there in the quarter. It's been a while since Network Power margins beat my expectations. Was there -- is that a function of having kind of cleared any major part of the restructuring or just a l
componenttext: Okay. And then on Network Power, I mean, nice margin result there in the quarter. It's been a while since Network Power margins beat my expectations. Was there -- is that a function of having kind of cleared any major part of the restructuring or just a lag of getting this stuff to kind of show up in what you're shipping in terms of the numbers? Or is there a reason why it sort of finally came through now?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that there's -- across Network Power, from the standpoint of the actions they started undertaking last summer and start flowing through and they've systematically been working and it's really starting to come through in the final P&L. So it starte
componenttext: I think that there's -- across Network Power, from the standpoint of the actions they started undertaking last summer and start flowing through and they've systematically been working and it's really starting to come through in the final P&L. So it started actually around the last month, the last year of the fiscal year September and it's proceeding each month. So I mean our expectation is that this will continue to take hold based on what we see happening in that market. So we should see sequential type of margin improvement in that business, which will be good because Scott and his team have really attacked this. They've become -- they're getting out of certain businesses, they're investing in other businesses. I think they've done a great job of evaluating where they want to be and the cost structure they have and now they're executing around that stability. And my hats off to the team in a very dynamic marketplace. So I think they're heading the right way and I feel good about that and they did a great job executing in the first quarter.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Rich Kwas of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: We'll go next to Rich Kwas of Wells Fargo.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Dave, just probably speaking -- I mean, given what's going on in oil and gas here in North America, are you seeing any signs in your other businesses of meaningful contagion in CR&S or Climate? Anything that you would point out here? You talked about t
componenttext: So Dave, just probably speaking -- I mean, given what's going on in oil and gas here in North America, are you seeing any signs in your other businesses of meaningful contagion in CR&S or Climate? Anything that you would point out here? You talked about the last 30 days being volatile. Just any thoughts there because obviously there's a lot more concern in the market in the last 60 days or so.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say the -- I mean, we have not seen it yet, Rich, from the order pattern that we saw in December. I don't know -- even the forecast for January, I didn't see anything. It could take a little while, but we don't see it yet. I think the marketp
componenttext: Yes, I would say the -- I mean, we have not seen it yet, Rich, from the order pattern that we saw in December. I don't know -- even the forecast for January, I didn't see anything. It could take a little while, but we don't see it yet. I think the marketplace has definitely been very volatile. I think the marketplace is starting to see numbers that we've been seeing. Now we've been -- if you look at the fourth calendar quarter, the third calendar quarter, they were pretty tough quarters for companies like Emerson. And so the market is now digesting that news as they saw it come out in the earnings report and the comments people are making right now, and let's say, a little bit more negative about 2016. So I would say that we sort of -- we've been trying to get ahead of that. And at this point in time, I feel that we've got that sized. I don't see the knock-on effect or what we saw the volatility, both in the marketplace and then also the commodity place in January. We have to watch it very carefully unfold and -- but if I look at the construction -- residential construction and the residential spending, the consumer spending in the areas that we are, they're still holding up pretty well right now. So we'll see. I mean, 30 days is pretty short. You've got to give us a little -- a few more days here.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood.
componenttext: Understood.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know you're very quick compared to me, but, man.
componenttext: I know you're very quick compared to me, but, man.

componenttext: On Process, in terms of M&A, you talked about deploying some capital there for this year. I mean, with what's happened there, incrementally more interested or less interested? How should we gauge that over the course of '16 in terms of the opportunities you're seeing right now.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm interested, higher interest. I mean, you can never call what time to buy, and from my perspective right now, I think that there are unique assets out there that I would like to buy. And our cash is going to -- Frank's over here working on how we're go
componenttext: I'm interested, higher interest. I mean, you can never call what time to buy, and from my perspective right now, I think that there are unique assets out there that I would like to buy. And our cash is going to -- Frank's over here working on how we're going to get cash back to United States with the spin and the divestitures, and we're going to talk a little bit about that next week. So from my personal standpoint, I look at this as a buying opportunity. And talking to my board today, the board's right there. They're on me on is to make sure we execute and we execute as hard as possible around this repositioning, this restructuring and then spend that money to make Emerson a better company long term. And we've got an opportunity here to figure out how to play with it. And so that's what we're all about.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Deane Dray of RBC.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Deane Dray of RBC.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just thought it was interesting how in a period of significant volatility and we've all been questioning you what you're seeing here, but you're also giving quarterly guidance. That's not really what -- Emerson didn't use to be in the quarterly guidance b
componenttext: Just thought it was interesting how in a period of significant volatility and we've all been questioning you what you're seeing here, but you're also giving quarterly guidance. That's not really what -- Emerson didn't use to be in the quarterly guidance business. But where's the additional confidence? Where is the additional visibility? I mean, it's certainly welcome, but that -- it's a change.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a change. I may go back. You know me, I've been around a few years. It's all about right now that we are on a detailed plan that we started executing last June and I want to make sure you guys understand where we are relative to that transition. And
componenttext: It's a change. I may go back. You know me, I've been around a few years. It's all about right now that we are on a detailed plan that we started executing last June and I want to make sure you guys understand where we are relative to that transition. And I want to make sure you get clarity around what I see sequentially happening each quarter. And the management team has been working this very aggressively right now. We've been discussing with the board. And I think it's very important for you to all understand what I see happening each quarter -- we see happening each quarter. And that clarity. Now once we come back to normality in the marketplace, we may go right back to, I don't necessarily -- I don't believe in quarterly guidance, but we might just go right back to the old way. But right now, I think we're through this transition period. I think it's very, very important you understand what's on our mind and where we see standing throughout this whole repositioning each quarter and so we're going to actually give you clarity on things next week on a second quarter, which you'd probably never get from us.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I certainly...
componenttext: Yes, I certainly...

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just think it's important that we stay joined at the hip here. Some of you are right there with me, some of you don't necessarily agree with us. It's all about execution, can we execute and I'm telling you what the road map looks like and what the band
componenttext: I just think it's important that we stay joined at the hip here. Some of you are right there with me, some of you don't necessarily agree with us. It's all about execution, can we execute and I'm telling you what the road map looks like and what the band looks like each quarter. And I will get through this quarter and I'll tell you the third quarter.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a great perspective and it is a change, and in a period of this uncertainty, to have your line of sight on this is appreciated. And then just have a nit follow-up on Commercial & Resi. It was interesting for professional tools. You wanted to bla
componenttext: Yes, it's a great perspective and it is a change, and in a period of this uncertainty, to have your line of sight on this is appreciated. And then just have a nit follow-up on Commercial & Resi. It was interesting for professional tools. You wanted to blame that also on upstream spending. And I just never thought professional tools was as tied to that, but maybe I'm wrong.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, now you're talking to one of the former presidents of Ridge Tool. And the former president of Ridge Tool that went through a last recession, a really tough recession we had, we have a significant part of that business that sells specialty tools and
componenttext:
Well, now you're talking to one of the former presidents of Ridge Tool. And the former president of Ridge Tool that went through a last recession, a really tough recession we had, we have a significant part of that business that sells specialty tools and equipment to the oil and gas producers and users, upstream and downstream. And it's this whole industry stopped spending and the first thing they do is -- that just dries right up around the world and that is a big chunk of our business there. And it's significant enough from that standpoint, it's big and it's also profitable. And all I can tell you was I thought I was going to be fired as Division President with my first 12 months when I came in here and the oil and gas hit me back in the early 1990, 1991. I thought -- that's what I thought. It's tough. That's what it is. It's not made up, but trust me, it's there.
I have to get going. I apologize. I know we have a lot of questions. I've got to cut some people off. I don't have any idea who I cut off. I didn't look at the list, was no selective here. I want to appreciate everyone for calling and I appreciate the questions and I'm going to try to be open and as honest possible in the situation, give you an idea where we're trying to go. But clearly, I've given you the clarity that I see with my management team right now and it's our call and that's what we're going to do up here for this year to make sure we're all on the same journey together as we come out of 2016. Thank you very much. Bye.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
