componenttext: On Process, in terms of M&A, you talked about deploying some capital there for this year. I mean, with what's happened there, incrementally more interested or less interested? How should we gauge that over the course of '16 in terms of the opportunities you're seeing right now?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm interested, higher interest. I mean, you can never call what time to buy, and from my perspective right now, I think that there are unique assets out there that I would like to buy. And our cash is going to -- Frank's over here working on how we're go
componenttext: I'm interested, higher interest. I mean, you can never call what time to buy, and from my perspective right now, I think that there are unique assets out there that I would like to buy. And our cash is going to -- Frank's over here working on how we're going to get cash back to United States with the spin in the divestitures, and we're going to talk a little bit about that next week. So from my fundamental standpoint, I look at this as a buying opportunity. And talking to my board today, the board's right there. They're on me on is to make sure we execute and we execute as hard as possible around this repositioning, this restructuring and then spend that money to make Emerson a better company long term. And we've got an opportunity here to figure out how to play with it. And so that's what we're all about.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Deane Dray of RBC.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Deane Dray of RBC.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just thought it was interesting how in a period of significant volatility and we've all been questioning you about what you're seeing here, but you're also giving quarterly guidance. That's not really what -- Emerson didn't use to be in the quarterly guid
componenttext: Just thought it was interesting how in a period of significant volatility and we've all been questioning you about what you're seeing here, but you're also giving quarterly guidance. That's not really what -- Emerson didn't use to be in the quarterly guidance business. But where's the additional confidence? Where is the additional visibility? I mean, it's certainly welcome, but that -- it's a change.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a change. I may go back. You know me, I've been around a few years. It's all about right now that we are on a detailed plan that we started executing last June and I want to make sure you guys understand where we are relative to that transition. And
componenttext: It's a change. I may go back. You know me, I've been around a few years. It's all about right now that we are on a detailed plan that we started executing last June and I want to make sure you guys understand where we are relative to that transition. And I want to make sure you get clarity around what I see sequentially happening each quarter. And the management team has been working this very aggressively right now. We've been discussing with the board. And I think it's very important for you to all understand what I see happening each quarter -- we see happening each quarter. And that clarity. Now once we come back to normality in the marketplace, we may go right back to, I don't necessarily -- I don't believe in quarterly guidance, but we might just go right back to the old way. But right now, I think we're through this transition period. I think it's very, very important you understand what's on our mind and where we see standing relative to this whole repositioning each quarter and so we're going to actually give you clarity on things next week on a second quarter, which you'd probably normally never get from us.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I certainly...

componenttextpreview: I just think it's important that we stay joined at the hip here. Some of you are right there with me, some of you don't necessarily agree with us. It's all about execution, can we execute and I'm telling you what the road map looks like and what the band
componenttext: I just think it's important that we stay joined at the hip here. Some of you are right there with me, some of you don't necessarily agree with us. It's all about execution, can we execute and I'm telling you what the road map looks like and what the band looks like each quarter. And I will get through this quarter and I'll tell you the third quarter.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a great perspective and it is a change, and in a period of this uncertainty, to have your line of sight on this is appreciated. And then just have a nit follow-up on Commercial & Resi. It was interesting for professional tools. You wanted to bla
componenttext: Yes, it's a great perspective and it is a change, and in a period of this uncertainty, to have your line of sight on this is appreciated. And then just have a nit follow-up on Commercial & Resi. It was interesting for professional tools. You wanted to blame that also on upstream spending. And I just never thought professional tools was as tied to that, but maybe I'm wrong.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, now you're talking to one of the former presidents of Ridge Tool. And the former president of Ridge Tool that went through a last recession, a really tough recession we had down there, we have a significant part of that business that sells specialty
componenttext:
Well, now you're talking to one of the former presidents of Ridge Tool. And the former president of Ridge Tool that went through a last recession, a really tough recession we had down there, we have a significant part of that business that sells specialty tools and equipment to the oil and gas producers and users, upstream and downstream. And it's this whole industry stopped spending and the first thing they do is -- that just dries right up around the world and that is a big chunk of our business there. And it's significant enough from that standpoint, it's big and it's also profitable. And all I can tell you was I thought I was going to be fired as Division President with my first 12 months when I came in here and the oil and gas hit me back in the early 1990, 1991. I thought -- that's what I thought. It's tough. That's what it is. It's not made up, but trust me, it's there.
I have to get going. I apologize. I know we have a lot of questions. I've got to cut some people off. I don't have any idea who I cut off. I didn't look at the list, was no selective here. I want to appreciate everyone for calling and I appreciate the questions and I'm going to try to be open and as honest possible in the situation, give you an idea where we're trying to go. But clearly, I've given you the clarity that I see with my management team right now and it's our call and that's what we're going to do up here for this year to make sure we're all on the same journey together as we come out of 2016. Thank you very much. Bye.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, May 3, 2016. Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain forw
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, May 3, 2016. 
Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain forward-looking statements, including the company's outlook for the remainder of the year. Information on factors that could cause actual results to vary materially from those discussed today is available at Emerson's most recent annual report on Form 10-K as filed with the SEC. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Craig Rossman, Director of Investor Relations at Emerson. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Matt. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; and Frank Dellaquila, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Today's call will summarize Emerson's second quarter 2016 results. The conferen
componenttext:
Thank you, Matt. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; and Frank Dellaquila, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Today's call will summarize Emerson's second quarter 2016 results. The conference call slide presentation will accompany my comments and is available on the Emerson's website at emerson.com. 
A replay of this conference call and slide presentation will be available in the website for the next 90 days. 
I will start the presentation with the second quarter summary as shown on Slide 2. Net sales in the quarter decreased 9% to $4.9 billion with underlying sales down 5%. As we anticipated, served markets were mixed as oil and gas and industrial markets remained under pressure, particularly in North America where conditions were tougher. On the positive side, market conditions were more favorable in HVAC and U.S. construction. Data center and telecommunication spending improved during the quarter as well. Reported earnings per share decreased 60% to $0.57. Adjusted earnings per share of $0.66, which excludes $56 million of total separation costs, were slightly above our expectations. Profitability in the quarter benefited from the significant restructuring actions we completed in 2015 and solid operating performance across our businesses. Improved working capital performance generated strong operating cash flow of $719 million in the quarter. Overall, the second quarter exceeded many of the company's expectations, and we remain on track for fiscal 2016. 
Turning to Slide 3. Gross profit margin was up 40 basis points due to cost reductions and containment actions, and lower SG&A expense benefited from restructuring actions. The year-over-year change in EBIT reflects the impact of separation cost of $31 million and a $932 million divestiture gain from the Power Transmission Solutions business in the prior year. Excluding the gain and the separation costs, EBIT margin increased 70 basis points. 
Turning to Slide 4. Underlying sales decreased in all regions except Europe. The results were similar to the first quarter, which are noted on the slides for your reference, as the global economies are still not showing much strength. 
Turning to Slide 5. Business segment margin improved 140 basis points to 14.6%, led by year-over-year margin improvement in the Network Power, Climate Technology and Commercial & Residential Solutions segments. Restructuring was a positive, and savings from the 2015 restructuring actions and lower expense in the current year were a benefit across the segments. Comparisons in corporate and other were driven by an increase of $46 million in stock compensation, resulting from share price appreciation, pretax separation cost of $31 million and a 2015 divestiture gain of $932 million. Working capital performance drove an operating cash flow improvement of 101% in the quarter. 
Turning to Slide 6. Process Management underlying sales decreased 9% in the quarter. Oil and gas customer spending remained a headwind across the regions but was more pronounced in certain markets like the Canadian oil sands and the U.S. Efficiency and productivity projects continued to gain traction with customers in the energy sector as interest and engagement continue to increase. Project opportunities in power in the U.S., Asia, Europe and Middle East/Africa continued to support growth, while chemical markets across various regions continue to be favorable as well. Segment margin decreased 20 basis points primarily from volume deleverage and mix but were partially offset by savings from restructuring actions, which will continue to benefit profitability in the remainder of the fiscal year. 
Turning to Slide 7. Industrial Automation second quarter sales declined 10%, reflecting continued weakness in industrial and upstream oil and gas spending. Power-generating alternator sales are at a 10-year low. Alternative energy wind projects were a bright spot for the drives business. Segment margin decreased 50 basis points primarily due to volume deleverage, unfavorable mix and price, partially offset by savings from restructuring actions and materials cost containment. Slightly better market conditions and easing comparisons are expected to improve both underlying growth and profitability in the second half of fiscal 2016. 
Turning to Slide 8. Network Power underlying sales were down 1% in the quarter, but global demand for data center telecommunications infrastructure improved during the quarter.
Telecommunications power systems had particularly strong growth in North America. Segment margin improved 490 basis points to 8.1%, mainly benefiting from restructuring actions. New product programs and the segment's global repositioning strategy are starting to flow through to both sales and profitability. Improving order trends for both data center and telecommunications investment will drive positive third quarter sales growth and improved margins. 
Turning to Slide 9. Climate Technologies underlying sales increased 2%, driven by the U.S. residential and commercial air conditioning business, which was up 10%. Europe reflected strong growth across the region. The refrigeration business was up high single digits. Segment margin increased 170 basis points primarily due to significant savings from restructuring actions and material cost containment. Favorable air conditioning and refrigeration end markets should continue to support improvement in underlying growth through the remainder of the fiscal year. 
Turning to Slide 10. Underlying sales in the Commercial & Residential Solutions segment increased 2%. Favorable conditions in U.S. construction markets, particularly residential, were supportive for growth. The divestiture of the commercial storage business reduced year-over-year sales by 16% but had a positive impact on segment margin, which improved 380 basis points to 23.2%. Favorable trends in U.S. residential construction are expected to continue, supporting the outlook for modest levels of underlying growth and margin improvement in the remainder of the fiscal year. 
Turning to Slide 11. While the global economic environment for Emerson businesses will continue to be challenging, demand has begun to stabilize or improve in certain markets. Comparisons in the second half of the year also become easier due to the significant decline in underlying sales during fiscal 2015. As we've indicated, order trends remain in line with expectations and therefore continue to support our assumptions that 2016 underlying sales will be down 2% to 5%, excluding negative currency translation of 1% and a 2% deduction from completed divestitures. Underlying sales in the third quarter are expected to be approximately flat to the prior year. We also reaffirm our guidance that adjusted earnings per share will be $3.05 to $3.25 excluding $250 million to $300 million of separation cost related to the company's portfolio repositioning. Adjusted earnings per share for the third quarter are anticipated to be flat to the prior year or approximately $0.85, excluding $145 million of separation costs. 
And now I'll turn it over to Mr. David Farr.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Craig. Thank you very much for joining us today. I appreciate your time. And as you could see, I've -- this was a very solid quarter, and I want to thank the entire global organization relative to execution around the significant rest
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Craig. Thank you very much for joining us today. I appreciate your time. And as you could see, I've -- this was a very solid quarter, and I want to thank the entire global organization relative to execution around the significant restructuring starting last year and continue to run through this year. And the results are starting to flow through, as they did for the last 3 quarters. 
Core profitability has now begun to improve, and we're exhibiting strong cash flow and very good performance. And again, I want to thank the global Emerson organization out there for doing some very difficult heavy-lifting in a very challenging marketplace. 
As we talked about it since November, I've been talking about fixed-rate orders. We're going to reach our goal by April. I'm not quite sure yet, but it's -- as we've looked at the order pace for the last several months, step by step by step, with October being the bottom, we've seen continued improvement. Last month's 3-month roll, we basically saw at around negative 4%. We do not know what the April ending numbers will be, which report -- we're talking about reporting around the May [indiscernible] products meeting. But right now, my gut tells me we've seen some weaker in North America oil and gas spending in the short cycle, included, we're seeing very weak spending round the backup power-generating marketplace, which, as we see, it's running at an 11-year low. But we might close. And we'll know when we get it all in. But it might be May. But we haven't get it up in April yet. I know -- I can tell you this one, we're going to be close enough that my 14-month old Zorro might be able to jump that rope and get there, but I do know there's been some weakening in the North America oil and gas spending route in the alternate route, for sure. 
The overall performance this quarter relative to the operations was very good in a very challenging marketplace. You think about the balance sheet, the cash flow, the earnings, setting up for us, what we believe is a very important milestone, again, in the third quarter, with hopefully underlying sales getting close to 0 and our earnings per share being flat with improved margins. Again, very important milestones as we quickly work through the process. And operations have done a lot of heavy-lifting here, and the restructuring is really starting to pay off. 
From my perspective right now, as I look at the global marketplace, I just came back from Europe. Europe -- our Western European business had continued to improve. I finally see good -- some good momentum there. No, the economy is not going to be robust there, but they clearly are making investments. They're making strategic investments. They have some experts. And so underlying, we see our European business being a benefit, a positive versus what it was a couple of months ago. I see the U.S., the U.S. economy, in particular the industrial segment, has continued to be challenging in certain segments. I would say even weaker within the U.S. marketplace. The rest of the world basically is trending along the lines we've been talking about for the last 2 or 3, 4 quarters, including what we talked about at our analyst meeting in February. So not a whole lot of change as I see it. The plus is coming from Europe. The minus is coming from the U.S. 
Network Power business orders continue to be improving and positive, and we expect Network Power to have positive growth in the third quarter, the top line, and positive growth in earnings. We expect the Commercial & Residential Solutions efforts is continuing to be positive, and we also expect our Climate Technology business to do reasonably well. But one market we're struggling right now is China residential. The rest of the world, they're progressing, do extremely well. And obviously, you could see some of the profitability coming through from these businesses as they've got the restructuring done in the second half of last year and the early part of this year. 
From a restructuring standpoint, we're going to be around this -- Frank, I think we're talking about $68 million [ph] -- $70 million, $80 million. We are looking at areas right now where we've seen weaknesses -- where we'll wrap up a little bit more restructuring, but we have this pretty well in focus as we look at this year. We're also starting to look at opportunities as we've now formed the 2 strategic businesses underneath 2 leaders of Mike Train and Bob Sharp. And we're looking at programs that will institute coming forward into '17 and '18, I would say, create a more best-cost, structural-global organization and manufacturing process and opportunities that we can then look at taking more cost out both for profitability but also to increase investments and for growth in some of the technologies and innovations area. So overall, I'm pleased with the opportunities there and look forward to continuing to figure out how we can generate higher levels of profitability in the 2 core businesses that will remain as we finish the repositioning. 
Relative to the repositioning, as we review with the board last night and again this morning, we're making progress. The Network Power program both is on the table at this point in time. We're looking at either a sale or spin, both our viable at this point in time. And the board, along with inputs from the management team, we're getting closer and closer to making that final position, and we will be making that decision. We have filed initial spin documents, which you have to do, and will continue to refine those documents based on inputs from the SEC. But from our standpoint right now, both options of what we're going to do to the business will create value for our shareholders and for value for us as a company going forward, still on the table and is still actively being worked. And it is not a problem. I know people like to speculate and people like to aggravate, but this is a process that's well underway and well and focused and well in line with what we expected. 
Relative to Leroy-Somer CT, Control Techniques, again we had a lot of viable global potential buyers of these assets, and that process is well underway. And even despite the tougher marketplace we see in that market we're selling, we still have a good, good opportunity there to sell these businesses for, what I would say, a [indiscernible] price and accept that and take that money and reinvest it back into Emerson and to the 2 core businesses that we're going to maintain. 
We'll also review today significant acquisition opportunities. the board. One thing good about the world today and the struggle relative to a lot of companies, there are unique acquisition opportunities out there both from a technology standpoint and the commercial and residential standpoint and also from the automation solution standpoint. So we are looking for opportunities to reinvest the proceeds, and the objective is to take that money and reinvest it back into the core businesses and eventually get back into $20-plus billion corporation, but a much more focused and selective and profitable business. As we talked about in February, when we come out of this transition, we'll be a more profitable business, we'll be more focused business and will be a more -- very much focused on doing significant acquisitions around these 2 businesses and once again regaining the size, as big as a corporate relative to what we need to do in a global basis. i like where we sit today. We're pivoting from significant restructuring to getting closer to growth in new orders, significant growth in improved profitability and pivoting towards this completion of the repositioning of the 2 core businesses we're trying to get out and positioning ourselves towards making additional acquisitions. And a great progress along those lines. No more specific details than I just gave you. So you can ask, and I would say, "No -- don't comment." But that's the flavor we are right now and good discussion with the board for lengthy term last night and again today relative to that. But again, as we wrap up here and open up for questions, again very, very good execution by the operating folks from Frank and his team and Ed Purvis and Ed Monser and then all the business leaders out there. I truly appreciate the -- really working as hard in trying to create a high level of profitability and high level of cash flow for us to have the opportunity to reinvest and grow this company again. 
So with that, I open the mic for questions.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You must be watching too much TV, Scott. That's what I'm thinking about. It's a fair aspect. A couple of things going on. As you know, when we went through the period [indiscernible] restructuring and trying to change organization, we went through a perio
componenttext: You must be watching too much TV, Scott. That's what I'm thinking about. It's a fair aspect. A couple of things going on. As you know, when we went through the period [indiscernible] restructuring and trying to change organization, we went through a period of having to develop a, I would say, a more selective type of product portfolio for the market changes and opportunities. It did give us a chance to really have a better package to go out and sell in a more focused approach with the organization and also, clearly, the comps got a little bit easier. But the most important thing here is the work that Scott Barbour and his team did over the last couple of years in getting their team focused around the different channels, the different products, the different solutions. And now I think that focus and that cost structure we put in place really are allowing these guys to compete and win. And it's a global thing. And so that is very good to see. So we have a long way to go with that business, but it's nice to have it helping and carrying a load right now. So that's where it is -- that's what's really going on.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. Dave, is there a sense -- I mean, can you give us a little bit of sense and timing. And I know you said you weren't going to give any deals, but are we talking about having Network Power wrapped up in 3 months? Or is it more like 6 months?
componenttext: Good. Dave, is there a sense -- I mean, can you give us a little bit of sense and timing. And I know you said you weren't going to give any deals, but are we talking about having Network Power wrapped up in 3 months? Or is it more like 6 months?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: From our perspective, if you go the route of a sale, most likely will be a little longer from a standpoint of review and approval process. There's a lot of regulation. As you know is a global, global business. So a lot of people will be reviewing that. A
componenttext: From our perspective, if you go the route of a sale, most likely will be a little longer from a standpoint of review and approval process. There's a lot of regulation. As you know is a global, global business. So a lot of people will be reviewing that. A spin is one -- assuming we don't know what the FTC will do from an input standpoint. But our focus right now, if we go the route in spin, to be towards the end of the fiscal year, if not, just right after the fiscal year. If we had to sell have to go through review process, it could be a couple of months longer. But right now, we still look at some time in the September-October -- end of September, October, November time frame for that -- and now the way we go, but that's time frame looking at that there, Scott. Leroy-Somer Control Techniques, get it really depends. There's a sale process. If we have to go in international person, relative a potential strategic buyer there it will take, I think, from a revenue standpoint, both of them as governments around the world longer. Both the U.S., the European government, the substantial position for Leroy-Somer CT and friends. But I think that's going to definitely be more likely -- by the time is completed in the fourth calendar quarter, but most -- what you'll from us sometime most likely this quarter or -- end in this quarter early next fourth quarter, you'll hear which way we're going. You'll hear from us. Sale or spin.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Am I to assume that that's not a gating factor in doing deals? That you'd be comfortable doing a deal even before those things are announced? Or do you feel like...
componenttext: Am I to assume that that's not a gating factor in doing deals? That you'd be comfortable doing a deal even before those things are announced? Or do you feel like...

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct. Our financial position right now is we can go and do deals right now, and we are doing deals, but we could do several billions of dollars of deals right now if we need to. We have the financial capability to spin, sale, doesn't make much differen
componenttext: Correct. Our financial position right now is we can go and do deals right now, and we are doing deals, but we could do several billions of dollars of deals right now if we need to. We have the financial capability to spin, sale, doesn't make much difference. We have the capability doing that right now. And Scott, follow to that. One of the reasons why we did stop the share repurchase in the second quarter and most likely tail back again in the third quarter is to make sure that we do have the financial flexibility to do the type of transaction, the market started to open up. Just want to make sure we have the capability. We can always come back and do the share repurchase, which we're now looking at probably around $1 billion this year versus what we've said earlier. So that's the only thing we've done.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This time we'll move to Gautam Khanna from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: This time we'll move to Gautam Khanna from Cowen and Company.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I was wondering if you could expand on your comments on some of the oil and gas orders weakening or what have you, the pace of activity weakening. And if you just could expand on what you saw related to any specific data projects? And if you could com
componenttext: And I was wondering if you could expand on your comments on some of the oil and gas orders weakening or what have you, the pace of activity weakening. And if you just could expand on what you saw related to any specific data projects? And if you could comment more broadly on any repricing of the backlog or customers pushing back on existing orders and trying to reprice them lower.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Relative to the second question, the answer is nothing. We don't -- we're not seeing that type of pressure from us from that standpoint, on a repricing of a commitment from our customers. And that's not an issue relative to this space at this point. Relat
componenttext: Relative to the second question, the answer is nothing. We don't -- we're not seeing that type of pressure from us from that standpoint, on a repricing of a commitment from our customers. And that's not an issue relative to this space at this point. Relative to North America and particularly U.S., it's primarily just the day-to-day type of spending that you see on the oil projects, not really big projects specific. It's all around the day-to-day type of what we call the MRO type. This normal type of spend. Our capital budget have definitely been curtailed by most oil and gas guys or companies within North America both in Canada and the United States. And so they're continuing to tighten those belts up, and we're seeing that business, not day-to-day business, given our strength in this marketplace, which been hurting us more on the, what I'd call the shorter-cycle type of products and the big -- the project business is not -- we haven't seen anything there. Just been more of a more day-to-day type of situation, and that's been going -- weakening here for the last couple of months. And we anticipate that's going to continue for the rest of this year now. As most of the oil and gas companies reported here the last couple weeks talked about, again, slowing down some capital. And we're feeling that on a day-to-day type of spend. That's what we're seeing them.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just on the flip side, given oil has moved a bit back up, I mean, do you think that -- do you think it actually will be down for the full year? Do you think the potential to actually see lift before the fiscal year end?
componenttext: Okay. And just on the flip side, given oil has moved a bit back up, I mean, do you think that -- do you think it actually will be down for the full year? Do you think the potential to actually see lift before the fiscal year end?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't see a lift before the fiscal year. I think that price of oil is -- I've talked about and my [indiscernible] price over the months of here. Think there's a chance that we could flip back in the 30s and trailing back up towards $50. Got to see stabi
componenttext: I don't see a lift before the fiscal year. I think that price of oil is -- I've talked about and my [indiscernible] price over the months of here. Think there's a chance that we could flip back in the 30s and trailing back up towards $50. Got to see stability in the $50-plus range towards $60 and then a continued growth of demand, which would see the day around the demand for oil and gas. But clearly, the current pricing and the stress that comes with going through right now to make sure they rightsize, not that the turnaround in a month or 2. And say "A, okay, go ahead and spend." That's not going to happen. If they get to see -- the way we look in this marketplace right now is the first part of '17 will continue to be challenging for our customer base and they continue to be tight in places like North America. And going to be very, very tight relative to spending, and I just don't see that bounce back until probably later in '17, early '18.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: We move now to Steven Winoker with Bernstein.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just Dave, you've talked a lot about the challenges in making the call for growth investments versus cuts and how to draw that line across the businesses, particularly when revisiting you guys. So what -- where you are now that thinking given how markets
componenttext: Just Dave, you've talked a lot about the challenges in making the call for growth investments versus cuts and how to draw that line across the businesses, particularly when revisiting you guys. So what -- where you are now that thinking given how markets have been evolving and the more aggressive, [indiscernible] guys have been getting, when should we be not be surprised about the pivot to growth investment?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that we're starting to pivot the growth on the Commercial & Residential Solutions side already. We're looking at some unique technology investments there both in [indiscernible] and through acquisitions. On the automation side, the -- so the comme
componenttext: I think that we're starting to pivot the growth on the Commercial & Residential Solutions side already. We're looking at some unique technology investments there both in [indiscernible] and through acquisitions. On the automation side, the -- so the commercial and residential side, I think you'll to start see as we start talk about as we get into quarters, that business continues to grow. I think that we are looking at the unique investments to help grow that business more in '17 and '18. On the automation side of the business right now, we're still going to go through, I would say, continue to downsize and rationalize for some time here. One of the things -- as we form the 2 businesses, we're looking at ways that we can take out cost and increase -- create the investment dollars, some to go to margins, some to go internally, but that's going to be more in '17, '18 time period. So I think you're looking at us already pivoting on part of the portfolio and the automation part of the portfolio we are still rationalizing, restructuring, and profitability and making sure that we do the right thing to protect the core value of the businesses. And so we're not walking away from the strategic investments there, but we're more in the -- let's make sure we have this opportunity to get the cost in line and we have any weak pieces of the tree and the wood or whatever it is, let's get a trend. And that's what we are at right now.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then -- it looks like you've got obviously flat growth guidance for 3Q and therefore implied flattish growth for 4Q underlying. So what does that mean for you assumptions around small -- the MRO side, small-to-midsize projects, because you calle
componenttext: Okay. And then -- it looks like you've got obviously flat growth guidance for 3Q and therefore implied flattish growth for 4Q underlying. So what does that mean for you assumptions around small -- the MRO side, small-to-midsize projects, because you called it out again. I'm just a little unclear on therefore what do we have to see happen for that to be achieved in the fourth quarter -- sorry, for the rest of the year.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what any -- [indiscernible] it depends on what you're signing to look at, Steve. I think businesses are -- I mean just look at this the business reporting in economic reports. They're continuing to really curtail spending. And I think can tell you
componenttext: I think what any -- [indiscernible] it depends on what you're signing to look at, Steve. I think businesses are -- I mean just look at this the business reporting in economic reports. They're continuing to really curtail spending. And I think can tell you see businesses start saying feel comfortable that they can start stabilizing their capital spend versus cutting their capital spend, I think it's going to be a quarter-by-quarter fight. And in North -- in the U.S. North America region here. But were already seeing some increase in Europe. We're already seeing Southeast Asia, but the key markets there are North America. They're still being pretty tight. So I think until we start hearing CEOs talk about expanding core capital investments for productivity, for [indiscernible] as reported of products, I think it's going to be a slide. [indiscernible]

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You said that China -- so your guidance for the year for China was down mid-single digits. Obviously, there's been some signs of stability, but 2Q was still down 12. So maybe you can talk about what you're seeing there and what you think for the rest of t
componenttext: You said that China -- so your guidance for the year for China was down mid-single digits. Obviously, there's been some signs of stability, but 2Q was still down 12. So maybe you can talk about what you're seeing there and what you think for the rest of the year.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our forecast is still to be in that mid-single-digit, 5%, 6%, 7%, 8% down. From a comparison standpoint, this sucker really turned down hard in the second -- shouldn't call it sucker, but I did. This market really turned down hard in the second half
componenttext: Yes. Our forecast is still to be in that mid-single-digit, 5%, 6%, 7%, 8% down. From a comparison standpoint, this sucker really turned down hard in the second -- shouldn't call it sucker, but I did. This market really turned down hard in the second half last year. I mean we had done -- if you think about the second half of 2015, [ph] our China sales were down probably around 16%. Not probably, they were. In the first half of this year, they're down around 12%, 13%. So what we're seeing is we're starting to see some pick back up in certain sectors, and comparisons will be a little bit easier. So if we go flat, it's still not really exciting, given the fact how hard it was down last year. So that's what we're seeing at this point in time. We see the second half being about the same pace, or a little bit better, but coming off a lot easier comps because the second half of '15 was down 16%, 17%. And that's where we are right now. And we see that across some of the businesses where -- some of the day-to-day spending and processes starting to happen. We're starting to see the refrigeration and some of the transportation market spending and the climate technology. seeing data centers and telecom spending. So we're starting to see some level of improvement there. So I still think that we'll see, on average, the year being down 6%, 7%, 8% at this point in time, unless there's been another shock, which we haven't seen yet. That's where we are right now.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful, Dave. And then profit margin down a little bit in the quarter [indiscernible] expecting pretty weak first half of the year. [indiscernible] steep increase to get to your high teens guidance for the year. How realistic is that? And c
componenttext: Great. That's helpful, Dave. And then profit margin down a little bit in the quarter [indiscernible] expecting pretty weak first half of the year. [indiscernible] steep increase to get to your high teens guidance for the year. How realistic is that? And could you get there with your kind of plan to mix having more unfavorable impact in your expected?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that Steve and Mike and team have done a phenomenal job of going after the cost. And they're working very hard and -- so getting that -- so that cost is coming out there quickly. It started last year. They've been aggressively after it. So we
componenttext: Yes. I think that Steve and Mike and team have done a phenomenal job of going after the cost. And they're working very hard and -- so getting that -- so that cost is coming out there quickly. It started last year. They've been aggressively after it. So we get a start seeing more and more savings. Very good second quarter profitability as I thought. I think we're starting to see that flow through. Now -- we do -- we're concerned about the North America, I would say, weakness because that is a very profitable business for us, but they still have other actions they can take to protect that profitability. And we're set pretty comfortable relative to whole year that we -- range we gave you, I think, back in February. And so I still feel pretty good about that. I think we're reasonably on track.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's now go to Julian Mitchell of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Let's now go to Julian Mitchell of Credit Suisse.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to start with Industrial Automation. You talked about pricing pressure in the slides. I think that may be news. So maybe any color around that? And also you seem particularly heavy destocking. Does the order trends not really improving if it l
componenttext: Just wanted to start with Industrial Automation. You talked about pricing pressure in the slides. I think that may be news. So maybe any color around that? And also you seem particularly heavy destocking. Does the order trends not really improving if it looked like February to March. So just maybe give some color on different verticals within that.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The big issue there is we have a mix going on from the standpoint of pricing pressure, profitability pressures. The other big issue is our alternator business in North America and parts of Europe has been extremely weakened and take another dive down. And
componenttext: The big issue there is we have a mix going on from the standpoint of pricing pressure, profitability pressures. The other big issue is our alternator business in North America and parts of Europe has been extremely weakened and take another dive down. And so that's big issue for us is that continue to weakened. And they're basically, at this point of time, seeing very weak end-market demand, our customers, and continue to ratchet back down. We're getting to a point right now come after -- to the pace is getting low enough, but it's kind of ugly from the standpoint. There's not much volume going on. But that's where we are at this point in time and a very -- I'm in the absolute cycle and it's just -- we took another notch down the last couple of months, and I think we're getting really close. And we should start seeing some improvement momentum back up through that. And that's where we are at this time. Again, they continue to take costs out. It's a tough cycle right now if not for this guys.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: These are the deltas. So in the first quarter, we're -- delta year around $80 million improved from restructuring. Second quarter, we're looking at around $100 million. The third quarter, it looks to us like it's going to probably back around $70 million
componenttext: These are the deltas. So in the first quarter, we're -- delta year around $80 million improved from restructuring. Second quarter, we're looking at around $100 million. The third quarter, it looks to us like it's going to probably back around $70 million because now we're starting to get -- get comparisons from last year. And then yes, in the fourth quarter what happens here we see a bounce back up again, priced over $100 million because the expense is going to be down. So delta there is going to help us a little bit. So that's how the numbers look right now, and we just had a very good quarter here. I expect [indiscernible] decent quarter in the third quarter, and that will get a big pot because will be less spending from versus last year, which we had a big pickup. So the savings are starting to flow through along those lines. Next year, now I would say based on just the businesses left, let's say that we -- we're executing the sale or the spin or whatever of the business, you look at process business and you look at the commercial residential business left, which is the day-to-day restructuring. Those numbers are going to drop significantly because of what's going on. And then what -- and so when I say significantly we're going to be under $50 million. [indiscernible] number yet, but going to be under $50 million. [ph] And then what can happen though is Bob Sharp and Jim are looking at opportunities across the Commercial & Residential Solutions business that we are going to start executing on as we get into '17. So they are all of a sudden, that we don't have a number yet, but to start taking that number up, where that 50 maybe -- might go up $25 million, $30 million, $40 million as we look at a 2-year program to rightsize and restructuring and reposition the commercial residential on a global basis to make it really best-cost location, best cost structure and allow us to take some of that profitability to the P&L and also to help us invest for growth. So there's some unique opportunities to put this business together, and that will happen as we get into '17. But next year, restructuring, Mike, that tells me that the core business will be down significantly. A long-winded answer for probably you didn't want to hear. But that's [indiscernible]

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think of Emerson particularly dominant larger projects in process Industrial Automation. Calling on some out for the smaller medium-size projects in MRO and in process, for example. Just curious if you can give us some color in terms of how that may shi
componenttext: I think of Emerson particularly dominant larger projects in process Industrial Automation. Calling on some out for the smaller medium-size projects in MRO and in process, for example. Just curious if you can give us some color in terms of how that may shift market shares or what you're doing to work on the share in the smaller-size, medium-size projects?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We -- I mean, from our perspective, we've been re-pushing resources because there's not as many large, large, large projects out there right now. So we direct our resources back into the small- and medium-size projects to pick up that business. Because yo
componenttext: We -- I mean, from our perspective, we've been re-pushing resources because there's not as many large, large, large projects out there right now. So we direct our resources back into the small- and medium-size projects to pick up that business. Because you're right. If you look at our share, we go very high for large, very strong the day-to-day, the middle, probably the weakest, as you've said. So we've been shifting some of the resources down from the large down to medium to go after those smaller projects. From a growth in market share, yes, I still feel that we're good at a -- we'll come out of the cycle ahead. As we did last cycle, I think Emerson will come out ahead and will be a stronger player in the Process Management industrial marketplace around the space here when the cycle comes out from an overall participation. On the day-to-day stuff, that, say, more driven by the corporate world of CEOs being very cautious, worried about cash flow, the same thing. Doing if you look at them as if you look at the capital spend in the first half of the year. We're down significantly from last year. Nothing any different from any of the CEOs out there. I think that CEOs right now are being very, very cautious relative to spending. And particularly, given weakness imaging in the industrial space. So I think that market -- that is going to be pretty, pretty challenging for the next 6 months and CEOs feel, "Okay, I can let go a little bit of money, more money and reinvest back into the company." That's how I see it at this point in time.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And also recall that efficiency productivity investments in process. Where are we in that investment cycle? Is it just beginning? And I'm curious why we don't see that in Industrial Automation and some of those efficiency investments.
componenttext: Got it. And also recall that efficiency productivity investments in process. Where are we in that investment cycle? Is it just beginning? And I'm curious why we don't see that in Industrial Automation and some of those efficiency investments.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Boy, that's -- if I could read everyone's mind, we'll be okay there. I think that we're seeing that both on the automation side and the process side in Europe. We're starting to see -- we're Western European do not invest for sometime and other doing it.
componenttext: Boy, that's -- if I could read everyone's mind, we'll be okay there. I think that we're seeing that both on the automation side and the process side in Europe. We're starting to see -- we're Western European do not invest for sometime and other doing it. We're going after it. We're seeing -- starting to see a little bit of that in Asia Pacific. In North America, people are just being very, very tight with capital right now. Even though money is cheap, free almost, people are very, very cautious at this point in time relative to spending a lot of capital. We are very focused on our capital spend right now on productivity, quality improvement and trying to get the cost down. But a lot of people are still trying to evaluate where they want to take their businesses. So I think there's been an underinvestment. And hopefully, we'll see it come back up. In the alternative improving the efficiency and operations in North America. I'm a little bit disappointed to watch corporate America cutting too far in that area. But that's with you are right now. And I can push and shove anymore to make them do it. So I'd know what we're doing and we redirected heavily the capital we're spending. I mean we're spending less capital, but it's all tied basically to efficiency and productivity and how do we get lower cost for the future.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So David, I just wanted to square your comments on orders bottoming in process and the fact that things are getting weaker in oil and gas. One of the things that you mentioned in your slides was that the power markets have been getting better. And we've h
componenttext: So David, I just wanted to square your comments on orders bottoming in process and the fact that things are getting weaker in oil and gas. One of the things that you mentioned in your slides was that the power markets have been getting better. And we've heard that from a few different people as well. So maybe is that the reason why you feel better about kind of the orders bottoming on the process business? And what specifically are you guys seeing in the power markets?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The process business -- I mean, I look around the world, and one place we've seen improved -- the increased weakness is this U.S. day-to-day spending. That's the one area I see the weakness. The rest of the world has continued to start increasing their in
componenttext: The process business -- I mean, I look around the world, and one place we've seen improved -- the increased weakness is this U.S. day-to-day spending. That's the one area I see the weakness. The rest of the world has continued to start increasing their investments in what I call the day-to-day productivity-type investments. We're seeing that spending going on. When you look at the order pace in Europe, look at the order pace in Asia, that trend is turning the right way. So that's why we felt pretty good. The one surprise we had is this -- the last couple of months. We've seen the U.S. spending rate come back down again, which by the sense and that's what's created probably this delay by 1 month relative to April -- the April time -- I don't know yet, for sure. But just intuition tells me where we were at negative 4%, that should be close to negative 2%. So it's this -- what's going on right now on this thing -- this is climbing up a little bit slower and we're having people be a little more cautious in spending. But on the power side, people are happy to spend money for the new regulations coming to play. They've underinvested for a while. We have some plants they've got to take off line. And so that we're seeing people spend money on trying to move towards gap. So the spending is there for power, and seen that. We're doing extremely well in Europe. We're doing well in North America and doing well in Asia. We are a company that actually continue to invest and grow and put the technology and a lot of our competitors are walking away from what I call primary power. And so be it, I love it. But we'll gladly make those investments for people. So we've been investing from a technology, innovation and acquisition of companies in our space that we can compete against are actually deemphasizing it. And walking away from it.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And maybe the follow-up there on the other gas piece. Have you started to see any weakness in midstream? That's one area that you guys have called out as being pretty strong for you. Is that attributing some of the weaker oil and gas pending? Or...

But clearly, some things happened to create people to back off, maybe redefine the warehouse and stuff that they had purchased for some investments. But clearly, they're backed off, and so they're using some older equipment or some equipment they found. And that's all that's going on at this point in time.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I feel -- Frank, I think we feel good about profitability right now because the operations, and I know the operations are really -- we got on this last year, starting real early. And they worked it and kept the pace. As you know, we haven't really flipped
componenttext: I feel -- Frank, I think we feel good about profitability right now because the operations, and I know the operations are really -- we got on this last year, starting real early. And they worked it and kept the pace. As you know, we haven't really flipped off the spending or the savings. And it's really starting to flow through. So I feel -- we feel good about that. I feel a little bit more worried about sales because of the U.S. marketplace, in Particular. I feel better about Europe you can tell. A Little bit nervous about -- feel a little nervous about Latin America business still think these guys is the starting -- the still struggling. But the U.S., this -- I would say slow to start turn that nose up really bothers me. But I would say that within the forecast we've given out there for sales, but still comfortable, but it's probably lower than it was below, but I feel good about the profitability from [indiscernible] because that's happening. And so it's just -- we got some markets going on and some markets are not going that way. They're not all turning at the same time. And so that's where we are at this point in time.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, very strong quarter in margins and free cash flow generation. Nobody can debate that. The final question I have is just following up I think on Scott's earlier question around the timing of M&A and probably a limit to what you can talk about this. B
componenttext: Well, very strong quarter in margins and free cash flow generation. Nobody can debate that. The final question I have is just following up I think on Scott's earlier question around the timing of M&A and probably a limit to what you can talk about this. But obviously, certain decile of deals that you have to use equity for? Will that kind of delay the timing? Do you have to get this exit out of the way before you would consider using equity as you're gating factor there?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't -- we don't see any issue there. The deals are working out right probably going to be cash deal. We could do billions of dollars in cash right now. That's on an issue. We've got ample balance sheet. Operations of the -- they've got liquidity b
componenttext: No, I don't -- we don't see any issue there. The deals are working out right probably going to be cash deal. We could do billions of dollars in cash right now. That's on an issue. We've got ample balance sheet. Operations of the -- they've got liquidity back in got a working capital back in a line of profitability is coming up. So I think from the type of deals we're seeing at this point in time we're looking at and not some big, strategic -- I don't see us moving that way until we exit these 2 businesses. But we see opportunities of multiple billion dollars type of opportunity that we could do internally right now just cash. So we've got the position.

So hopefully, were getting to bottom this from the cycle standpoint. But it's been a tough front for these guys for the last couple of years.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We expect the profitability -- that -- the business used to run 10-plus percent type of profitability, and so our goal is to get that back above that. And so as this business continues the restructuring is getting closer and closer. I think got majority o
componenttext: We expect the profitability -- that -- the business used to run 10-plus percent type of profitability, and so our goal is to get that back above that. And so as this business continues the restructuring is getting closer and closer. I think got majority of the restructuring -- a little bit left in the second half this year. But from an underlying profit, the growth profit, may begin to leverage quite nicely. So we expect them to see a pretty good growth in the second half of the year and improvement profitability in the second half of the year. All from growth and also from improvement in the cost structure.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, just on the restructuring. It sounds like it's tracking according to plan and everything, but the first half was only $28 million of expense. Just conceptually, I'm trying to figure out why that would be kind of a back-half-loaded restructuring plan
componenttext: Dave, just on the restructuring. It sounds like it's tracking according to plan and everything, but the first half was only $28 million of expense. Just conceptually, I'm trying to figure out why that would be kind of a back-half-loaded restructuring plan. It seems like you kind of know what you need to do and you get after it earlier in the year. Can you just maybe explain what's going on there.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're doing some significant restructuring, some challenging restructuring in Europe. And you have to do it in a very measured pace. That's one of the answers right there. And so it's a plan that you try to get it done within 12 months. Sometimes it
componenttext: Well, we're doing some significant restructuring, some challenging restructuring in Europe. And you have to do it in a very measured pace. That's one of the answers right there. And so it's a plan that you try to get it done within 12 months. Sometimes it takes 14 months. Our European process for restructuring is one you want to do very carefully to get done without major disruption and major problems when your work force. So a lot of it is around that European situation. North America's a little bit easier. And that's pretty straightforward. But we have some restructuring underway in Europe that well planned out. And we might miss a month or 2 here as we push around. So that's been going on at this point in time. The other thing we're doing at this point in time is also is we are getting restructuring done  actually getting it done at a lower cost. There profits are getting it done -- which is nice to see, if you do it with a measured pace, you actually get it done with a better and better cost structure and get their work done our cost is less. But still think we're going to be doing around this $60 million, $70 million this year. And again as I said, looking at some of the process industry as [indiscernible] we need to do to be probably steady position as we go into, I would say, challenging first half of '17 at this point in time.

Organizationally, there's been obviously you're undergoing some big changes and also some management's moving around in that the business becoming organizationally, you're in a position you we want to do something sizable?

componenttext: Yes. We're ready to grow. I mean ready to go. I'm a further section -- by the time you start the process, I mean the restructuring, a lot of it will be well behind you as you get beyond -- acquisitions don't happen 1 day or 2 days. So If you do the process, I think that we're well positioned as we go into the second half of this calendar year to take on some additional. And if we can pick up a couple of billion dollars worth of things, then we've be very excited about that.
