headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, May 3, 2016. Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain forw
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, May 3, 2016. 
Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain forward-looking statements, including the company's outlook for the remainder of the year. Information on factors that could cause actual results to vary materially from those discussed today is available at Emerson's most recent annual report on Form 10-K as filed with the SEC. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Craig Rossman, Director of Investor Relations at Emerson. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Matt. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; and Frank Dellaquila, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Today's call will summarize Emerson's second quarter 2016 results. The conferen
componenttext:
Thank you, Matt. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; and Frank Dellaquila, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Today's call will summarize Emerson's second quarter 2016 results. The conference call slide presentation will accompany my comments and is available on the Emerson's website at emerson.com. A replay of this conference call and slide presentation will be available on the website for the next 90 days. 
I will start the presentation with the second quarter summary as shown on Slide 2. Net sales in the quarter decreased 9% to $4.9 billion, with underlying sales down 5%. As we anticipated, served markets were mixed as oil and gas and industrial markets remained under pressure, particularly in North America where conditions were tougher. 
On the positive side, market conditions were more favorable in HVAC and U.S. construction. Data center and telecommunication spending improved during the quarter as well. 
Reported earnings per share decreased 60% to $0.57. Adjusted earnings per share of $0.66, which excludes $56 million of total separation costs, were slightly above our expectations. 
Profitability in the quarter benefited from the significant restructuring actions we completed in 2015 and solid operating performance across our businesses. Improved working capital performance generated strong operating cash flow of $719 million in the quarter. 
Overall, the second quarter exceeded many of the company's expectations, and we remain on track for fiscal 2016. 
Turning to Slide 3. Gross profit margin was up 40 basis points due to cost reductions and containment actions, and lower SG&A expense benefited from restructuring actions. The year-over-year change in EBIT reflects the impact of separation costs of $31 million and a $932 million divestiture gain from the Power Transmission Solutions business in the prior year. Excluding the gain and the separation costs, EBIT margin increased 70 basis points. 
Turning to Slide 4. Underlying sales decreased in all regions except Europe. The results were similar to the first quarter, which are noted on the slide for your reference, as the global economies are still not showing much strength. 
Turning to Slide 5. Business segment margin improved 140 basis points to 14.6%, led by year-over-year margin improvement in the Network Power, Climate Technology and Commercial & Residential Solutions segments. Restructuring was a positive, as savings from the 2015 restructuring actions and lower expense in the current year were a benefit across the segments. Comparisons in corporate and other were driven by an increase of $46 million in stock compensation, resulting from share price appreciation, pretax separation costs of $31 million and a 2015 divestiture gain of $932 million. Working capital performance drove an operating cash flow improvement of 101% in the quarter. 
Turning to Slide 6. Process Management underlying sales decreased 9% in the quarter. Oil and gas customer spending remained a headwind across the regions, but was more pronounced in certain markets like the Canadian oil sands and the U.S. Efficiency and productivity projects continued to gain traction with customers in the energy sector as interest and engagement continue to increase. Project opportunities in power in the U.S., Asia, Europe and Middle East/Africa continued to support growth, while chemical markets across various regions continue to be favorable as well. Segment margin decreased 20 basis points primarily from volume deleverage and mix, but were partially offset by savings from restructuring actions, which will continue to benefit profitability in the remainder of the fiscal year. 
Turning to Slide 7. Industrial Automation second quarter sales declined 10%, reflecting continued weakness in industrial and upstream oil and gas spending. Power generating alternator sales are at a 10-year low. Alternative energy wind projects were a bright spot for the drives business. Segment margin decreased 50 basis points primarily due to volume deleverage, unfavorable mix and price, partially offset by savings from restructuring actions and materials cost containment. Slightly better market conditions and easing comparisons are expected to improve both underlying growth and profitability in the second half of fiscal 2016. 
Turning to Slide 8. Network Power underlying sales were down 1% in the quarter. The global demand for data center and telecommunications infrastructure improved during the quarter. Telecommunications power systems had particularly strong growth in North America. Segment margin improved 490 basis points to 8.1%, mainly benefiting from restructuring actions. New product programs and the segment's global repositioning strategy are starting to flow through to both sales and profitability. Improving order trends for both data center and telecommunications investment will drive positive third quarter sales growth and improved margins. 
Turning to Slide 9. Climate Technologies underlying sales increased 2%, driven by the U.S. residential and commercial air-conditioning business, which was up 10%. Europe reflected strong growth across the region. The refrigeration business was up high single digits. Segment margin increased 170 basis points primarily due to significant savings from restructuring actions and material cost containment. Favorable air-conditioning and refrigeration end markets should continue to support improvement in underlying growth through the remainder of the fiscal year. 
Turning to Slide 10. Underlying sales in the Commercial & Residential Solutions segment increased 2%. Favorable conditions in U.S. construction markets, particularly residential, were supportive for growth. The divestiture of the commercial storage business reduced year-over-year sales by 16%, but had a positive impact on segment margin, which improved 380 basis points to 23.2%. Favorable trends in U.S. residential construction are expected to continue, supporting the outlook for modest levels of underlying growth and margin improvement in the remainder of the fiscal year. 
Turning to Slide 11. While the global economic environment for Emerson businesses will continue to be challenging, demand has begun to stabilize or improve in certain markets. Comparisons in the second half of the year also become easier due to the significant decline in underlying sales during fiscal 2015. As we've indicated, order trends remain in line with expectations and therefore continue to support our assumptions that 2016 underlying sales will be down 2% to 5%, excluding negative currency translation of 1% and a 2% deduction from completed divestitures. 
Underlying sales in the third quarter are expected to be approximately flat to the prior year. We also reaffirm our guidance that adjusted earnings per share will be $3.05 to $3.25, excluding $250 million to $300 million of separation costs related to the company's portfolio repositioning. Adjusted earnings per share for the third quarter are anticipated to be flat to the prior year or approximately $0.85, excluding $145 million of separation costs. 
And now I'll turn it over to Mr. David Farr.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Craig. Thank you very much for joining us today. I appreciate your time. And as you could see, fundamentally, this was a very solid quarter, and I want to thank the entire global organization relative to execution around the significa
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Craig. Thank you very much for joining us today. I appreciate your time. And as you could see, fundamentally, this was a very solid quarter, and I want to thank the entire global organization relative to execution around the significant restructuring starting last year and continue to run through this year. And the results are starting to flow through, as they did for the last 3 quarters. 
Core profitability has now begun to improve, and we're exhibiting strong cash flow and very good performance. And again, I want to thank the global Emerson organization out there for doing some very difficult heavy lifting in a very challenging marketplace. 
As we talked about it, since November, I've been talking about fixed-rate orders. We're going to reach our goal by April. I'm not quite sure yet, but it's -- as we've looked at the order pace for the last several months, step by step by step, with October being the bottom, we've seen continued improvement. Last month's 3-month roll, we basically saw at around negative 4%. We do not know what the April ending numbers will be, which we report -- we're talking about reporting around the May Electrical Products Group meeting. But right now, my gut tells me we'd seen some weaker North America oil and gas spending in the short cycle, and clearly, we're seeing very weak spending around the backup power-generator marketplace, which, as we see, it's running at an 11-year low. But we might be close, and we'll know when we get it all in. But it might be May, but we haven't given up on April yet. And I know I can tell you this one, we're going to be close enough that my 14-month old Zorro might be able to jump that rope and get there. But I do know there's been some weakening in the North America oil and gas spending route in the alternate route, for sure. 
The overall performance this quarter relative to the operations was very good in a very challenging marketplace. And you think about the balance sheet, the cash flow, the earnings, setting up for us what we believe is a very important milestone, again, in the third quarter, with hopefully, underlying sales getting close to 0 and our earnings per share being flat with improved margins. Again, very important milestones as we quickly work through the process. And operations have done a lot of heavy lifting here, and the restructuring is really starting to pay off. 
From my perspective right now, as I look at the global marketplace, I just came back from Europe. Europe -- our Western European business had continued to improve. I finally see good -- some good momentum there. No, the economy is not going to be robust there, but they clearly are making investments. They're making strategic investments. They have some exports. And so underlying, we see our European business being a benefit and a positive versus what it was a couple of months ago. I see the U.S., the U.S. economy, in particular on the industrial segment, has continued to be challenging in certain segments. I would say even weaker within the U.S. marketplace. The rest of the world basically is trending along the lines that we've been talking about for the last 2 or 3, 4 quarters, including what we talked about at our analyst meeting in February. So not a whole lot of change as I see it. The plus is coming from Europe. The minus is coming from the U.S. 
Network Power business orders continue to be improving and positive, and we expect Network Power to have positive growth in the third quarter, the top line, and positive growth in earnings. We expect the Commercial & Residential Solutions efforts is continuing to be positive, and we also expect our Climate Technology business to do reasonably well. But one market they're struggling with right now is China residential. The rest of the world, they're progressing, doing extremely well. And obviously, you could see some of the profitability coming through in some of these businesses as they've got the restructuring done in the second half of last year and the early part of this year. 
From a restructuring standpoint, we're going to be around this -- Frank, I think we're talking about $60 million to $80 million -- $70 million, $80 million. We are looking at areas right now where we've seen weaknesses where we'll ramp up a little bit more restructuring, but we have this pretty well in focus as we look at this year. We're also starting to look at opportunities as we've now formed the 2 strategic businesses underneath 2 leaders of Mike Train and Bob Sharp. And we're looking at programs that will institute coming forward into '17 and '18 to, I would say, create a more best-cost, structural, global organization and manufacturing process and opportunities that we can then look at taking more cost out both for profitability, but also to increase investments and for growth in some of the technologies and innovations area. So overall, I'm pleased with the opportunities there and look forward to continuing to figure out how we can generate higher levels of profitability in the 2 core businesses that will remain as we finish the repositioning. 
Relative to the repositioning, as we reviewed with the board last night and again this morning, we're making progress. The Network Power program both is on the table at this point in time. We're looking at either a sale or a spin; both are viable at this point in time. And the board, along with inputs from the management team, are getting closer and closer to making that final decision, and we will be making that final decision. We have filed initial spin documents, which you have to do, and we'll continue to refine those documents based on inputs from the SEC. And -- but from our standpoint right now, both options of what we're going to do to the business to create value for our shareholders and for value for us as a company going forward, are still on the table and are still actively being worked. And it is not a problem. I know people like to speculate and people like to aggravate, but this is a process that's well underway and well and focused and well in line with what we expected. 
Relative to Leroy-Somer CT, Control Techniques, again we have a lot of viable global potential buyers of these assets, and that process is well underway. And even despite the tougher marketplace we see in that market we're selling, we still have a good, good opportunity there to sell these businesses for, what I would say, a respectable price and exit that and take that money and reinvest it back into Emerson, in the 2 core businesses that we're going to maintain. 
We also reviewed today significant acquisition opportunities with the board. One thing good about the world today and the struggle relative to a lot of companies, there are unique acquisition opportunities out there both from a technology standpoint, from the commercial and residential standpoint and also from the automation solution standpoint. So we are looking for opportunities to reinvest the proceeds, and the objective is to take that money and reinvest it back into the core businesses and eventually get back into the $20-plus billion corporation, but a much more focused and selective and profitable business. As we talked about in February, when we come out of this transition, we will be a more profitable business, we'll be more focused business and we'll be a more -- very much focused on doing significant acquisitions around these 2 businesses and once again regaining the size, right, as big as a corporate relative to what we need to do on a global basis. 
So i like where we sit today. We're pivoting from significant restructuring to getting closer to growth in new orders, significant growth in improved profitability and pivoting towards this completion of the repositioning of the 2 core businesses we're trying to get out and positioning ourself towards making additional acquisitions. And a great progress along those lines. 
No more specific details than I just gave you. So you can ask, and I will say, "No comment." But that's the flavor we are right now, and good discussion with the board for a lengthy term last night and again today relative to that. 
But again, as we wrap up here and open up for questions, again very, very good execution by the operating folks from Frank and his team and Ed Purvis and Ed Monser and then all the business leaders out there. I truly appreciate the -- they're really working us hard in trying to create a higher level of profitability and high level of cash flow for us to have the opportunity to reinvest and grow this company again. 
So with that, I open the mic for questions.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You must be watching TV too much, Scott. That's all I can think about. No, it's a fair ask. There's a couple of things going on. As you know, we went -- when we went through the period of [indiscernible] restructuring and trying to change the organization
componenttext: You must be watching TV too much, Scott. That's all I can think about. No, it's a fair ask. There's a couple of things going on. As you know, we went -- when we went through the period of [indiscernible] restructuring and trying to change the organization, we went through a period of having to develop, I would say, a more selective type of product portfolio for the market changes and opportunities. It did give us a chance to really have a better package to go out and sell in a more focused approach with the organization and also, clearly, the comps got a little bit easier. But the most important thing here is the work that Scott Barbour and his team did over the last couple of years in getting their team focused around the different channels, the different products, the different solutions. And now I think that that focus and that cost structure we've put in place really are allowing these guys to compete and win. And it's a global thing. And so that is very good to see. So we have a long way to go with that business, but it's nice to have it helping and carrying a load right now. So that's where it -- that's what's really going on.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Good. Dave, is there a sense -- I mean, can you give us a little bit of sense and timing. And I know you said you weren't going to give any deals, but are we talking about having Network Power wrapped up in 3 months? Or is it more like 6 months?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: From our perspective, if you go the route of a sale, most likely it will be a little longer from the standpoint of a review and approval process. There's a lot of regulation. It's a very -- as you know, a global, global business. So a lot of people will b
componenttext: From our perspective, if you go the route of a sale, most likely it will be a little longer from the standpoint of a review and approval process. There's a lot of regulation. It's a very -- as you know, a global, global business. So a lot of people will be reviewing that. A spin is one that you can have -- assuming what -- we don't know what the FTC will do from an input standpoint. But our focus right now, if we go to this side, we go to route of spin, it will be towards the end of the fiscal year, if not, just right after the fiscal year. If we have to sell it and have to go through a review process, it could be a couple of months longer. But right now, we still look at some time in the September-October -- end of September, October, November time frame for that based on the way we go, but that's the time frame we're looking at that there, Scott. On Leroy-Somer and Control Techniques, again, it really depends. There's a sale process. If we have to go with an international person, relative -- a potential strategic buyer there, it will take, I think, from a review standpoint, both from the various governments around the world, longer. Both the U.S. government and the European government, there's a substantial position for Leroy-Somer CT in France. So I think that's going to definitely be most likely by the time it's completed in the fourth calendar quarter. But most -- what -- you'll hear from us sometime most likely this quarter or end of this quarter, early next fourth quarter, you'll hear which way we're going. You'll hear from us, sale or spin.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Am I to assume that that's not a gating factor in doing deals? That you'd be comfortable doing a deal even before those things are announced? Or do you feel like you are already?
componenttext: Okay. Am I to assume that that's not a gating factor in doing deals? That you'd be comfortable doing a deal even before those things are announced? Or do you feel like you are already?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct. Our financial position right now is we can go and do deals right now, and we are doing deals, but we could do several billions of dollars of deals right now if we need to. We have the financial capability, spin, sale, it doesn't make much differe
componenttext: Correct. Our financial position right now is we can go and do deals right now, and we are doing deals, but we could do several billions of dollars of deals right now if we need to. We have the financial capability, spin, sale, it doesn't make much difference. We have the capability doing that right now. And, Scott, to follow-up on that; one of the reasons why we did stop the share repurchase in the second quarter and most likely we tailed back again in the third quarter is to make sure that we do have the financial flexibility to do the type of transaction. The market started to open up, and we just want to make sure we have the capability. And we can always come back and do the share repurchase, which we're now looking at probably around $1 billion this year versus what we'd said earlier. So that's the only thing we've done.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This time we'll move to Gautam Khanna with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: This time we'll move to Gautam Khanna with Cowen and Company.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could expand on your comments about some of the oil and gas orders weakening or what have you, the pace of activity weakening. And if you just could expand on what you saw as it related to any specific type of projects? And if you c
componenttext: I was wondering if you could expand on your comments about some of the oil and gas orders weakening or what have you, the pace of activity weakening. And if you just could expand on what you saw as it related to any specific type of projects? And if you could comment more broadly on any repricing of the backlog or customers pushing back on existing orders and trying to reprice them lower.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Relative to the second question, the answer is nothing. We don't -- we're not seeing that type of pressure from us from that standpoint, on a repricing of a commitment from one of our customers. And that's not an issue relative to this space at this point
componenttext: Relative to the second question, the answer is nothing. We don't -- we're not seeing that type of pressure from us from that standpoint, on a repricing of a commitment from one of our customers. And that's not an issue relative to this space at this point in time. Relative to North America and particularly U.S., it's primarily just the day-to-day type of spending that you see on the oil projects, not really big project-specific. It's all around the day-to-day type of what we call the MRO type of -- this normal type of spend, where capital budgets definitely have been curtailed by most oil and gas guys or companies within the North America, both in Canada and the United States. And so they're continuing to tighten those belts up, and we're seeing that business, in that day-to-day business, given our strength in this marketplace, which has been hurting us more on the -- what I'd call the shorter-cycle type of products and the big -- the project business is not -- we haven't seen anything there, it's just been more the more day-to-day type of situation. And that's been going -- been weakening here for the last couple of months. And we anticipate that's going to continue for the rest of this year now. As most of the oil and gas companies who reported here in the last couple of weeks have talked about, again, slowing down some capital. And we're feeling that on the day-to-day type of spend. That's where we're seeing it.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just on the flipside, given oil has moved a bit back up, I mean, do you think that -- do you think it actually will be down for the full year? Or do you think there's the potential to actually see a lift before the fiscal year-end?
componenttext: Okay. And just on the flipside, given oil has moved a bit back up, I mean, do you think that -- do you think it actually will be down for the full year? Or do you think there's the potential to actually see a lift before the fiscal year-end?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't see a lift before the fiscal year. I think that the price of oil is -- I've talked about my opinion on the price of oil over the months here. I still think there's a chance that we could slip back in the 30s and then start trailing back up towards
componenttext: I don't see a lift before the fiscal year. I think that the price of oil is -- I've talked about my opinion on the price of oil over the months here. I still think there's a chance that we could slip back in the 30s and then start trailing back up towards $50. You've got to see stability in the $50-plus range towards $60 and then a continued growth of demand, which we see today around the world, demand for oil and gas. But clearly, at the current pricing and the stress that companies are going through right now. If they make sure they rightsize, they're not going to turn around in a month or 2, and say "Hey, okay, go ahead and spend." That's not going to happen. I think you're going to see -- the way we're looking at this marketplace right now is the first part of '17 will continue to be challenging for our customer base and they're -- continue to be tight in places like North America. And they're going to be very, very tight relative to spending, and I just don't see that bounce back until probably later in '17 or early '18.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We move now to Steven Winoker with Bernstein.
componenttext: We move now to Steven Winoker with Bernstein.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just, Dave, you've talked a lot about the challenges in making the call for growth investments versus cuts and how to draw that line across the businesses, particularly when we were visiting you guys. So what -- where are you now in that thinking given ho
componenttext: Just, Dave, you've talked a lot about the challenges in making the call for growth investments versus cuts and how to draw that line across the businesses, particularly when we were visiting you guys. So what -- where are you now in that thinking given how the market's been evolving and the more aggressive, it sounds like, achievement on the cost side that you guys have been getting? So when should we be -- not be surprised about the pivot to growth investment?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that we're starting to pivot the growth on the Commercial & Residential Solutions side already. We're looking at some unique technology investments there both internally and through acquisitions. On the automation side -- so on the Commercial & Re
componenttext: I think that we're starting to pivot the growth on the Commercial & Residential Solutions side already. We're looking at some unique technology investments there both internally and through acquisitions. On the automation side -- so on the Commercial & Residential side. So I think you're going to start seeing as we start talking about, as we get in the quarters, that business continues to grow. I think that we are looking at unique investments to help grow that business more in '17 and '18. On the automation side of the business right now, we're still going to go through -- I would say, continue to downsize and rationalize for some time here. One of the things -- as we form the 2 businesses, we're looking at ways that we can take out costs and then accrete -- create new investment dollars, some to go to margins, some to go internally. But that's going to be more in the '17-'18 time period. So I think you're looking at us already pivoting on part of the portfolio and the automation part of the portfolio we are still rationalizing, restructuring, protecting profitability and making sure that we do the right thing to protect the core value of the businesses. And so we're not walking away from the strategic investments there, but we're more in the -- let's make sure we have this opportunity to get the costs in line. And if we have any weak pieces of the tree and the wood or whatever it is, let's get a trend. And that's where we are at right now.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, it looks like -- so you've got obviously flat growth guided for 3Q and therefore implied flattish growth for 4Q underlying. So what does that mean for your assumptions around the MRO side, small-to-midsize projects, because you did call it
componenttext: Okay. And then, it looks like -- so you've got obviously flat growth guided for 3Q and therefore implied flattish growth for 4Q underlying. So what does that mean for your assumptions around the MRO side, small-to-midsize projects, because you did call it out again? I'm just a little unclear on therefore what do we have to see happen for that to be achieved in the fourth quarter -- sorry, for the rest of the year.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what you need -- well, we're seeing -- so it depends on what segment you look at, Steve. I think that businesses are -- I mean, just look at their business reporting in the economic reports. They're continuing to really curtail spending. And
componenttext: Well, I think what you need -- well, we're seeing -- so it depends on what segment you look at, Steve. I think that businesses are -- I mean, just look at their business reporting in the economic reports. They're continuing to really curtail spending. And I think until you see businesses start saying they feel comfortable that they can start stabilizing their capital spend versus cutting their capital spend, I think it's going to be a quarter-by-quarter fight and in North -- in the U.S. North America region here. But we're already seeing some increase in Europe. We're already seeing Southeast Asia, but the key markets here are North America. They're still being pretty tight. So I think until we start hearing CEOs talk about expanding core capital investments for productivity, for not capacity, but just report activity for some new products, I think it's going to be a slog. No doubt about it.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew Kaplowitz from Citi has the next question.
componenttext: Andrew Kaplowitz from Citi has the next question.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, you said that China was -- so your guidance for the year for China was down mid-single digits. Obviously, there's been some signs of stability, but 2Q was still down 12%. So maybe you can talk about what you're seeing there and what you think for th
componenttext: Dave, you said that China was -- so your guidance for the year for China was down mid-single digits. Obviously, there's been some signs of stability, but 2Q was still down 12%. So maybe you can talk about what you're seeing there and what you think for the rest of the year.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our forecast is still to be in that mid-single digits, 5%, 6%, 7%, 8% down. From a comparison standpoint, this sucker really turned down hard in the second -- I shouldn't call it sucker, but I did. This market really turned down hard in the second ha
componenttext: Yes. Our forecast is still to be in that mid-single digits, 5%, 6%, 7%, 8% down. From a comparison standpoint, this sucker really turned down hard in the second -- I shouldn't call it sucker, but I did. This market really turned down hard in the second half last year. I mean we had down -- if you think about the second half of 2015, our China destination sales were down probably around 16%. Not probably, they were. In the first half of this year, they're down around 12%, 13%. So what we're seeing is we're starting to see some pick back up in certain sectors, and comparisons will be a little bit easier. So if we go flat, it's still not really exciting, given the fact how hard it was down last year. So that's what we see at this point in time. We see the second half being about the same pace, a little bit better, but coming off a lot easier comps because the second half of '15 was down 16%, 17%. So that's where we are right now. And we see that across some of the businesses where some of the day-to-day spending and process are starting to happen. We're starting to see the refrigeration and some of the transportation market spending and the climate technology. We're seeing the data centers and telecom spending. So we're starting to see some level of improvement there. So I still think that we'll see, on average, the year being down 6%, 7%, 8% at this point in time, unless there's been another shock, which we haven't seen yet. That's where we are right now.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. That's helpful, Dave. And then Process Management margin, down a little bit in the quarter. You're obviously expecting a pretty weak first half of the year. But you do need necessarily see a big increase to get to your high teens guidance for
componenttext: Okay, great. That's helpful, Dave. And then Process Management margin, down a little bit in the quarter. You're obviously expecting a pretty weak first half of the year. But you do need necessarily see a big increase to get to your high teens guidance for the year. So how realistic is that? And could you get there with your current plans? Is the mix having a more unfavorable impact than you expected?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that Steve and Mike and his whole team have done a phenomenal job of going after the costs. And they're working very hard and so they're getting -- that cost is coming out very quickly. It started last year. They've been aggressively after it
componenttext: Yes, I think that Steve and Mike and his whole team have done a phenomenal job of going after the costs. And they're working very hard and so they're getting -- that cost is coming out very quickly. It started last year. They've been aggressively after it. So we're going to start seeing more and more savings. They had a very good second quarter profitability as I saw it. And I think that we're starting to see that flow through. Now I -- we do -- we are concerned about the North America's, I would say, weakness because that is a very profitable business for us. But they still have other actions they can take to protect that profitability. And we are set pretty comfortable relative to the whole year that we -- range we gave you, I think, back in February. And so I still pretty good about that. I think we're reasonably on track.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's now go to Julian Mitchell of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Let's now go to Julian Mitchell of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to start with Industrial Automation. You talked about pricing pressure in the slides. And I think that may be new, so maybe any color around that? And also, are you seeing particularly heavy destocking or something because the order trend's no
componenttext: Just wanted to start with Industrial Automation. You talked about pricing pressure in the slides. And I think that may be new, so maybe any color around that? And also, are you seeing particularly heavy destocking or something because the order trend's not really improving if it looked like February to March. So just maybe give some color on different verticals within that.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The big issue there is we have a mix going on from the standpoint of pricing pressure, profitability pressures. The other big issue is our alternator business in North America and parts of Europe has been extremely weakened and taken another dive down. An
componenttext: The big issue there is we have a mix going on from the standpoint of pricing pressure, profitability pressures. The other big issue is our alternator business in North America and parts of Europe has been extremely weakened and taken another dive down. And so that's been a big issue for us is that continued to weaken. And they're basically, at this point of time, seeing very weak end-market demand in our customers, and so our guys are continue to ratchet back down. We're getting to a point right now after -- to the pace it's getting low enough, but it's kind of ugly from the standpoint there's not much volume going on. But that's where we are at this point in time in a very -- I mean, depths of the cycle and it's just it took another notch down the last couple of months, and I think we're getting really close. And we should start seeing some improvement momentum back up through that. And that's where we are at this time. Again, they continue to take costs out. It's a tough cycle right here now for these guys.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then just overall company-wide, I think in February, you talked about a $335 million savings number for this year. If there's any detail you could give on how much of that was recognized in the first half. And maybe any sense -- when we lo
componenttext: Understood. And then just overall company-wide, I think in February, you talked about a $335 million savings number for this year. If there's any detail you could give on how much of that was recognized in the first half. And maybe any sense -- when we look at the restructuring plans for the next 6 months, any color you could give on how much you might be carrying into sort of next year?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Now -- and the number we gave you, is what, $350 million for the year you said? Is that what you said?
componenttext: Okay. Now -- and the number we gave you, is what, $350 million for the year you said? Is that what you said?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: $335 million.
componenttext: $335 million.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: $335 million. And right now, it's at -- we're probably just a tad further than that right now, given on the second half of the year for the restructuring and the benefits that we're seeing from that. So as we look at the pieces, these are the actual numbe
componenttext: $335 million. And right now, it's at -- we're probably just a tad further than that right now, given on the second half of the year for the restructuring and the benefits that we're seeing from that. So as we look at the pieces, these are the actual numbers, these aren't the deltas, correct? I'm now looking at a sheet here.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: These are the deltas.
componenttext: These are the deltas.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: These are deltas. So in the first quarter, we're -- delta year around $80 million of improved from restructuring. Second quarter, we're looking at around $100 million. The third quarter, it looks to us like it's going to probably back around $70 million b
componenttext: These are deltas. So in the first quarter, we're -- delta year around $80 million of improved from restructuring. Second quarter, we're looking at around $100 million. The third quarter, it looks to us like it's going to probably back around $70 million because now we're starting to get -- we start to get some comparisons from last year. And then -- yes, and then in the fourth quarter what happens here is we're seeing a bounce back up again, probably to over $100 million because the expense is going to be down. So the delta there is going to help us a little bit. So that's how the numbers look right now, and we just had a very good quarter here. I would expect us to have another decent quarter in the third quarter, and then we'll get a big pot because there'll be less spending from versus last year, which we had a big pickup. So the savings are starting to flow through along those lines. Next year, now I would say based on just the core businesses left, let's say that we were executing the sale or the spin or whatever of the businesses, you look at the Process business and you look at the Commercial & Residential business left, and just the day-to-day restructuring, those numbers are going to drop significantly because of what's going on. And then what -- and so when I say significantly, we're going to be under $50 million. I mean, I haven't seen the number yet, but I got to believe it's going to be under $50 million. And then what's going to happen though is Bob Sharp and Jim Lindemann are looking at opportunities across the Commercial & Residential Solutions business that we are going to start executing on as we get into '17. So they are all of a sudden, that we don't have a number yet, but we're going to start taking that number up, where that $50 million may become -- might go up $25 million, $30 million, $40 million as we look at a 2-year program to rightsize and restructure and reposition the Commercial & Residential on a global basis to make it really best cost location, best cost structure and allow us to take some of that profitability to the P&L and also to help us invest for growth. So there're some unique opportunities now that we've put these businesses together. And that will happen as we get into '17. But next year, restructuring, Mike tells me in the core bases, we'll be down significantly. A long-winded answer for probably what you didn't want to hear. But that's it.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And now we'll hear from Mike Wood with Macquarie Capital.
componenttext: And now we'll hear from Mike Wood with Macquarie Capital.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think of Emerson as particularly dominant in the larger projects in Process, Industrial Automation. And you're calling out in some of your remarks hope for the smaller, medium-sized projects in MRO and in Process, for example. Just curious if you can gi
componenttext: I think of Emerson as particularly dominant in the larger projects in Process, Industrial Automation. And you're calling out in some of your remarks hope for the smaller, medium-sized projects in MRO and in Process, for example. Just curious if you can give us some color in terms of how that may shift market shares or what you're doing to work on the share in the smaller-sized, medium-sized projects?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, from our perspective is we've been re-pushing resources because there's not as many large, large, large projects out there right now. So we direct our resources back into the small- and medium-sized projects to pick up that business. Because you'r
componenttext: I mean, from our perspective is we've been re-pushing resources because there's not as many large, large, large projects out there right now. So we direct our resources back into the small- and medium-sized projects to pick up that business. Because you're right, if you look at our share, we go very high for large, we're very strong the day-to-day. In the middle, we're probably the weakest, as you've said. So we've been shifting some of the resources down from the large down to the medium, go after those smaller projects. From a growth to market share, yes, I still feel that we're going to end up -- we'll come out of this cycle ahead. As we did the last cycle, I think Emerson will come out ahead and we'll be a stronger player in the Process Management, industrial marketplace around this space here when the cycle comes out from overall participation. On the day-to-day stuff, that's staying more driven by the corporate world of CEOs being very cautious, worried about cash flow, being the same thing I'm doing. If you look at Emerson, if you look at our capital spend in the first half of the year, we're down significantly from last year. I don't think I'm any different from any other CEO out there. And I think that CEOs right now are being very, very cautious relative to spending. And particularly, given they keep seeing weakness emerging in the industrial space. So I think that market -- that part's going to be pretty, pretty challenging here for the next 6 months until CEOs feel, "Okay, I can let go a little bit of money, more money and reinvest back into the company." That's how I see it at this point in time.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And also you called out the efficiency productivity investments in Process. Where are we in that investment cycle? Is it just beginning? And I'm curious why we don't see that in Industrial Automation in some of those efficiency investments.
componenttext: Got it. And also you called out the efficiency productivity investments in Process. Where are we in that investment cycle? Is it just beginning? And I'm curious why we don't see that in Industrial Automation in some of those efficiency investments.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Boy, that's -- if I could read everyone's mind, being okay there. I think that we are seeing that both on the automation side and the process side in Europe. We're starting to see -- where Western European did not invest for some time and now they're doin
componenttext: Boy, that's -- if I could read everyone's mind, being okay there. I think that we are seeing that both on the automation side and the process side in Europe. We're starting to see -- where Western European did not invest for some time and now they're doing it. They're going after it. We're seeing -- we're starting to see a little bit of that in Asia Pacific. In North America, people are just being very, very tight with capital right now. Even though money is cheap, free almost, people are very, very cautious at this point in time relative to spending a lot of capital. We are very focused on our capital spend right now on productivity, quality improvement and trying to get the cost down. But a lot of people are still trying to evaluate where they want to take their businesses. So I think there's been an underinvestment. And hopefully, we'll see it come back up in the old productivity and improving your efficiency and operations in North America. I'm a little bit disappointed to watch corporate America cutting too far in that area. But that's where they are right now. And I can't push and shove any more to make them do it. So I'd know what we're doing and we redirected heavily the capital we're spending. It's -- I mean, we're spending less capital, but it's all tied basically to efficiency and productivity and how do we get lower costs for the future.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We move now to Joe Ritchie with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We move now to Joe Ritchie with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So David, I just wanted to square your comments on orders bottoming in Process and the fact that things are getting weaker in oil and gas. One of the things that you mentioned in your slides was that the power markets have been getting better. And we've h
componenttext: So David, I just wanted to square your comments on orders bottoming in Process and the fact that things are getting weaker in oil and gas. One of the things that you mentioned in your slides was that the power markets have been getting better. And we've heard that from a few different people as well. So maybe is that the reason why you feel better about kind of the orders bottoming on the Process business? And what specifically are you guys seeing in the power markets?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Process business, I mean, I look around the world, the one place that we've seen improved -- increased weakness is this U.S. day-to-day type of spending. That's the one area I see the weakness. The rest of the world has continued to start increasing t
componenttext: The Process business, I mean, I look around the world, the one place that we've seen improved -- increased weakness is this U.S. day-to-day type of spending. That's the one area I see the weakness. The rest of the world has continued to start increasing their investments in what I would call the day-to-day productivity-type investments. We're seeing that spending going on. If I look at the order pace in Europe, I look at the order pace in Asia, that trend is turning the right way. So that's why we felt pretty good. The one surprise we had is this -- is the last couple of months. We've seen the U.S. spending rate come back down again, which bothers us and that's what's created probably this delay by 1 month relative to April -- the April target, which may have -- I don't know yet for sure, but just intuition tells me where we were at negative 4%, that should have been closer to negative 2%. So it's this -- what's going on right now, this thing, this is climbing up a little bit slower and we're having people be a little more cautious in spending and -- but on the power side, people are having to spend money for the new regulations come into play. They've underinvested for a while. They have some plants they've got to take offline. And so we're seeing people spend money on trying to move towards gas. And so the spending is there for power and aggressively seen that. We're doing extremely well in Europe. We're seeing -- we're doing well in North America and we're doing well in Asia. We are a company that actually continue to invest and grow and put new technology in. A lot of our competitors are walking away from what I call primary power. And so be it, I love it. But we'll gladly make those investments for people. And so we've been investing from a technology, innovation and acquisitions and a lot of companies in our space that we can compete against are actually deemphasizing it and walking away from it.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And maybe the follow-up there on the oil and gas piece is have you started to see any weakness in midstream? I know that's one area that you guys have called out as being pretty strong for you. Is that attributing some of the weaker oil and gas sp
componenttext: Got it. And maybe the follow-up there on the oil and gas piece is have you started to see any weakness in midstream? I know that's one area that you guys have called out as being pretty strong for you. Is that attributing some of the weaker oil and gas spending? Or...

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Now, midstream's fine. It's just the -- I think there might be an element going on we could be seeing some cannibalization going on of -- as you know, there was a lot of investments that were done and siting out there, used equipment, maybe equipment
componenttext: No. Now, midstream's fine. It's just the -- I think there might be an element going on we could be seeing some cannibalization going on of -- as you know, there was a lot of investments that were done and siting out there, used equipment, maybe equipment that wasn't ever put in place. There could be an element of that; people going back and digesting, cannibalizing that right now. But clearly, something's happened to create people to back off. Maybe they found a warehouse of stuff that they had purchased for some investments. But clearly, they're backed off, and so they're using some older equipment or some equipment they found. And that's all that's going on at this point in time.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I feel -- Frank, I think we feel good about the profitability right now because I think the operations -- not I think, I know the operations have really -- we got on this last year starting real early, and they've worked it and we kept the pace. And
componenttext: Yes, I feel -- Frank, I think we feel good about the profitability right now because I think the operations -- not I think, I know the operations have really -- we got on this last year starting real early, and they've worked it and we kept the pace. And as you know, we haven't really slipped off the spending or the savings, and it's really starting to flow through. So I feel -- we feel good about that. I feel a little bit more worried about sales because of the U.S. marketplace, in particular. I feel better about Europe as you can tell. I feel a little bit nervous about -- I feel a little bit nervous about Latin America because I still think these guys are still starting to -- they're still struggling. But the U.S., just I would say slow to start turning that nose up really bothers me. But I would say that within the forecast we'd given out there for sales, we're still comfortable, but it's probably a little lower than it was below. But I feel good about the profitability from the power because that's happening. And so it's just -- we got some markets going on our way, some markets are not going that way. And they're not all turning at the same time. And so that's where we are at this point in time.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, admittedly, a very strong quarter on margins and free cash flow generation. I don't know -- I don't think anybody can debate that. The final question I have is just following up, I think, on Scott's earlier question around the timing of M&A and ther
componenttext: Well, admittedly, a very strong quarter on margins and free cash flow generation. I don't know -- I don't think anybody can debate that. The final question I have is just following up, I think, on Scott's earlier question around the timing of M&A and there's probably limits to what you can talk about this, but obviously, there's a certain decile of deals that you have to use equity for? Do -- will that kind of delay the timing? Do you have to get this exit out of the way before you would consider using equity? Is there a gating factor there?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't -- we don't see any issue there. The deals we're working out right now are probably going to be cash deals. We could do billions of dollars in cash right now. That's not an issue. We've got ample balance sheet. Operations have got -- they've g
componenttext: No, I don't -- we don't see any issue there. The deals we're working out right now are probably going to be cash deals. We could do billions of dollars in cash right now. That's not an issue. We've got ample balance sheet. Operations have got -- they've got the liquidity back in. They've got the working capital back in line. Our profitability is coming up. So I think from the type of deals we're seeing at this point in time we're looking at and not some big, strategic -- I don't see us moving that way until we exit these other 2 businesses. But we see opportunities of multiple billion dollars type of opportunities that we could do internally right now just with pure cash. So we've got the position to do that.

componenttext: Around $1.5 billion. Profit margin's down a little bit. ClosetMaid, I would say it's probably somewhat flat. The margins are somewhat flat this year. So there's not -- and we're not really taking an action on ClosetMaid at this point in time. But I would say Leroy-Somer's Control Techniques have not seen the recovery that we thought originally. That business, the backup power area and industrial spending has been much weaker; though we're starting to see the improvements in Europe in that area and some improvement in Asia. So hopefully, we're getting to the bottom of this from a cycle standpoint. But it's been a tough run for these guys for the last couple of years.

Already seeing big improvements this year, but you also commented on a long way to go, so I'm wondering if you've now kind of established the guide path for another big step-ups in profitability here for the segment.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We expect the profitability -- that -- the business used to run 10-plus percent type of profitability, and so our -- the goal is to get that back above that. And so as this business continues, the restructuring is getting closer and closer. I think they'v
componenttext: We expect the profitability -- that -- the business used to run 10-plus percent type of profitability, and so our -- the goal is to get that back above that. And so as this business continues, the restructuring is getting closer and closer. I think they've got the majority of their restructuring. I know they probably have a little bit left in the second half of this year. But from an underlying profit, when the growth comes, these guys are going to leverage quite nicely. So I expect them to see a pretty good growth in the second half of the year and improvement in profitability in the second half of the year, all from growth and then also from improvement in the cost structure.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, just on the restructuring. It sounds like it's tracking according to plan and everything, but the first half was only $28 million of expense. Just conceptually, I'm trying to figure out why that would be kind of a back-half-loaded restructuring plan
componenttext: Dave, just on the restructuring. It sounds like it's tracking according to plan and everything, but the first half was only $28 million of expense. Just conceptually, I'm trying to figure out why that would be kind of a back-half-loaded restructuring plan. It seems like you kind of know what you need to do and you'd be getting after it earlier in the year. Can you just maybe explain what's going on there?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well we're doing some significant restructuring, some challenging restructuring in Europe. And we -- you have to do it at a very measured pace. That's one of the issues right there. And so it's a plan that you try to get it done within 12 months; sometime
componenttext: Well we're doing some significant restructuring, some challenging restructuring in Europe. And we -- you have to do it at a very measured pace. That's one of the issues right there. And so it's a plan that you try to get it done within 12 months; sometimes it takes 14 months. A European process for restructuring is one that you want to do very carefully to get it done without major disruption and major problems with your workforce. So a lot of it is around that European situation. North America's a little bit easier. And that's pretty straightforward. But we have some restructuring underway in Europe that we are well planned out. And we might miss a month or 2 here as we push around. So that's what's going on at this point in time. The other thing we're doing at this point in time is also is they are getting the restructuring done. And they're actually getting it done at a little lower cost. They're getting the profits. They're getting it done, which is nice to see. If you do it with a measured pace, you actually get it done at a better cost structure and get the work done and the cost is less. But still think we're going to be doing around this $60 million, $70 million this year. And again, as I said, we're looking at somewhat in the process industrial area right now. There's some more incremental things we need to do to be properly staged -- positioned as we go into, I would say, a challenging first half of '17 at this point in time.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just one more follow-up on kind of the M&A angle. Clearly, as you mentioned, you have the financial strength to do what you want to do. I mean, organizationally, there's been obviously you're going some -- undergoing some big changes and a
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just one more follow-up on kind of the M&A angle. Clearly, as you mentioned, you have the financial strength to do what you want to do. I mean, organizationally, there's been obviously you're going some -- undergoing some big changes and also, some management's moving around within the businesses. I mean organizationally, are you in a position where you'd want to do something sizable?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're ready to go. I mean, we're ready to go. I mean, for the restructuring -- by the time you start the process, I mean, the restructuring, a lot of it will be well behind you as you get -- our acquisitions don't happen in 1 day or 2 days. So If you
componenttext: Yes. We're ready to go. I mean, we're ready to go. I mean, for the restructuring -- by the time you start the process, I mean, the restructuring, a lot of it will be well behind you as you get -- our acquisitions don't happen in 1 day or 2 days. So If you do the process, I think that yes, we're well positioned as we go into the second half of this calendar year to take on some additional. And if we can pick up a couple of billion dollars' worth of things, then we'd be very excited about that.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I mean, I -- what we saw is I was talking earlier on the phone call as kind of my initial comment would be the U.S., North America oil and gas day-to-day business was weaker than we would had anticipated. On the positive side, Network Power is a little bit stronger. I would say also -- I would say that our order pace in China and some of the other businesses, I thought would -- may be a little bit better, but it didn't quite trend that way yet. But I would say the primary reasons I look at the order pace is the North America capital type of spend market, day-to-day marketplace was weaker the last 3 or 4 months. And that's probably what's created the slowdown. If you look at the line, it still continued to drift up. It should have drifted a little bit faster the last 2 months, but it's sort of on a curve now. It's 1 month behind where I thought it would be.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: No, I don't think so from a residential standpoint. We're not as much of a resi -- I mean, we -- it depends what we're talking. I mean the high-end residential, we'd be a player there. But I would say our core markets, our core customer right now just went into a situation with too much inventory, and they're having to deal with that. and the rest, if you look at the rest of China, it's been pretty good for our residential business -- for our commercial -- our residential business and the climate business, but it's -- not much going on there. I mean, it's just that market goes in pockets. These guys are going 2 or 3 quarters, they buy heavily and then they overstock and then they cut back. So nothing unusual there at this point in time.

componenttext: Well I said one piece of it's at -- was at an 11-year bottom, and I don't think I used the word nosediving, but it's a -- I would say that, at this point in time, we -- if we feel we can get the right type of cash out of this asset, then we will monetize and move on. I mean, how long it takes for some of these assets to come back in certain cycles? We have things we want to do relative to repositioning, so we want to get on with it and do it rather than sit there and manage it.

componenttext: Yes, as I said earlier -- what I said earlier, our cost reduction, our profitability is running at very good levels. And then you look at the slower climb out on order pace will create -- clearly putting some pressure on us where we think the top line will be. If the top line was a little bit stronger, then clearly, our profitability would go higher and our EPS is a little higher. Right now, we're more concerned about the top line sales than we are the profitability because we've got our cost structure in line right now. I feel good about that. We feel good about that.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think right now -- I think the day-to-day sales is pretty much set based on the -- it's not price or oil-driven. I'm just -- I mean, I just happen to be one of these guys, you know me, Rich, I make -- I put stakes in the ground. I mean, I put
componenttext: No, I don't think right now -- I think the day-to-day sales is pretty much set based on the -- it's not price or oil-driven. I'm just -- I mean, I just happen to be one of these guys, you know me, Rich, I make -- I put stakes in the ground. I mean, I put a stake in the ground back in November about April. I mean, how many people do things like that? It's just my nature. And so my feel right now, I've always told you that I always felt that price of oil would run up and run down a couple of times. I firmly believe there's a chance it could run back down again to the 30s. I personally believe, by the time we get in the fourth calendar quarter this year, we'll be around that $50 mark. That's why I think -- that's where I think things are going. People are cutting back. The demand is still growing, but it takes a long time. When you make an investment and you have oil and gas pumping and you got that capital spent, you just don't turn it off. Typically, you let it run and try to make some cash out of it. And even though you're not making as much as you thought, you're still trying to get that payback. So I think that's what we're going through right now. We're still squeezing it out. And I think that there could be a bump in the road here down, and -- but fundamentally, I think the trend line is back up a little bit towards the $50 mark.

componenttext: Nothing right now. The channels move up and down. I think that could have had a couple of months where they -- construction wasn't as strong as people did and the inventories being built. Right now, it looks like things are pretty well balanced. And the order pace is pretty good in North America. So I would expect us to have a decent third quarter in North America. And depending on how to get to this how much liquidation goes out and how much you have to build later in the year, which will be a good thing for us. So we'll see what happens right now. Right now, it's setting up to be a decent year for us in North America and a decent year for us in Europe and other -- in some other parts of the marketplace. But it's good to see. It's good to see.

componenttext:
Yes. And Frank doesn't jump up and down, shake his head, we're okay. 
Well, I want to thank everybody for their time today. Again, operations, outstanding job in the execution. We thank Frank and Ed and Ed and everybody out there working with the operation guys to get this done. We clearly continue to pivot towards the repositioning, and our goal is to come out, as we talked about in the February investor meeting, come out a little bit smaller company, more profitable company, but quickly add on acquisitions to use the money we're going to generate here to invest in the growth again and get this company back above $20 million, with a 19% to 20% EBIT margin, so a very good business. 
So thank you very much and you all have a great summer. Bye.
