headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, August 2, 2016. Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain f
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, August 2, 2016. 
Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain forward-looking statements, including the company's outlook for the remainder of the year. Information on factors that could cause actual results to vary materially from those discussed today is available at Emerson's most recent annual report on Form 10-K as filed with the SEC. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Craig Rossman, Director of Investor Relations at Emerson. Please go ahead.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Renée. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; Frank Dellaquila, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Catherine [indiscernible] Vice President, Chief Marketing Officer. Today's ca
componenttext:
Thank you, Renée. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; Frank Dellaquila, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Catherine [indiscernible] Vice President, Chief Marketing Officer. 
Today's call will summarize Emerson's third quarter 2016 results and also provide an update on Emerson's business transformation. A conference call slide presentation will accompany my comments and is available on Emerson's website at emerson.com. 
A replay of this conference call and slide presentation will be available on the website for the next 90 days. 
I will start with the third quarter summary, as shown on Page 2 of the slide presentation. Net sales in the quarter decreased 7% versus the prior year to $5.1 billion with underlying sales down 5%. The third quarter results reflected the continuation of challenging demand conditions in our key served markets. Oil and gas spending, both capital investment and operational expenditures, remains at significantly depressed levels. Automation markets in North America have been extremely challenging as anticipated improvements in spending did not materialize as we had forecast. Data center and telecommunications infrastructure demand continue to be favorable while global air conditioning and refrigeration in U.S. construction markets were mixed. The trailing 3-month orders for June were down 6.7% on a GAAP basis with underlying trends down 4.4%, excluding approximately 2% per currency translation. Adjusted earnings per share, which excludes $37 million of separation cost, decreased 5% to $0.80. 
Reported earnings per share were $0.74. Operating cash flow in the quarter was $718 million. 
Turning to Slide 3. Despite lower-than-expected sales, EBIT margin increased 20 basis points versus the prior year, driven by benefits from restructuring actions and solid operational execution with our businesses. No additional, shares were repurchased during the quarter and separation costs were significantly lower than expected. 
Turning to Slide 4. Underlying sales decreased in all regions except Europe. The results by region were similar to the second quarter as the global environment for business investment remains challenging. 
Turning to Slide 5. Total segment margin was up 50 basis points to 16% as 3 segments reported improved margins. Both the Climate Technology and Commercial & Residential Solutions segments reported up margins despite lower volumes. And improved cost structure resulted in operating cash flows of $718 million in the quarter. Capital spending continues to be reduced, in line with overall business conditions. 
Turning to Slide 6. Process Management underlying sales decreased 13% in the quarter. Energy spending, particularly in North America, continues to be reduced -- continue to be reduced as customers evaluate the stability of current oil and gas prices, while power and life sciences markets continue to provide growth. 
Restructuring programs will be further increased in response to weak demand conditions from global oil and gas customers and the expectation that weaker conditions will continue into 2017. 
Segment margin decreased 290 basis points primarily due to a sharp volume reduction and the resulting deleverage, partially offset by savings from restructuring actions.
Turning to Slide 7. Industrial Automation third quarter underlying sales declined 11%, reflecting continued [indiscernible] in industrial spending in upstream oil and gas capital investments while wind projects remained favorable for the drives business. Segment margin decreased 110 basis points primarily due to volume deleverage and price, partially offset by savings from restructuring actions and material cost containment. Mix demand forecasts among the businesses are expected to result in improved levels of sales and profitability in the fourth quarter.
Turning to Slide 8. Network Power underling sales increased 10% in the quarter as strong order trends in both data center and telecommunications infrastructure markets translated into positive growth. Sales increased in all regions except Europe, which reflected a difficult comparison to the prior year from large project revenues. 
Segment margin improved 550 basis points to 9.1%, driven by volume leverage in savings from restructuring actions. Benefits from restructuring actions and new product program support the expectation for continued margin improvement in the fourth quarter. 
Turning to Slide 9. Climate Technologies underlying sales decreased 1% in the quarter as decreases in Asia and the Middle East more than offset increases in other regions. Underlying sales growth in North America and Europe reflected low single-digit growth in both the air conditioning and commercial refrigeration businesses. Segment margin increased 270 basis points to 22.4%, primarily due to savings from restructuring actions and material cost containment, partially offset by lower pricing. The near-term outlook for global demand in our served markets supports the expectation for modest sales growth in the fourth quarter. 
Turning to Slide 10. Underlying sales in the Commercial & Residential Solutions segment decreased 1% as growth in food waste disposers was offset by declines in all other businesses, which were impacted by customer-driven inventory reduction. Segment margin improved 380 basis points to 24.4%, reflecting the impact of the divestiture, savings from restructuring actions and material cost containment. Modest levels of underlying growth are expected in the fourth quarter as we anticipate favorable conditions in U.S. construction to continue and channel inventory reduction should be complete.
Turning to Slide 11. Earlier today, we announced agreement to sell our Network Power, Leroy-Somer and Control Techniques businesses for a combined value $5.2 billion, which is in line with the guidance we provided at our February investor conference. These agreements represent a significant step forward in the overall portfolio repositioning strategy we announced last year in June. And with these agreements now in place, the strategic repositioning squarely focuses on acquisitions within our core platforms of automation solutions and Commercial & Residential Solutions as Emerson management and the board determine how to best to redeploy the cash proceeds from these divestitures.
Turning to Slide 12. The third quarter results continue to reflect the low growth global environment facing our businesses today. And the outlook remains challenging as markets will continue to be impacted by reduced levels of investment spending, weaker global economics and political uncertainty. Considering these conditions, coupled with the fact that anticipated improvement in order trends did not materialize, the company now expects fiscal year underlying sales to be down 5% to 6%, excluding currency translation and an impact from completed divestitures of approximately 2% each. Adjusted earnings per share for the fiscal year are now expected to be $2.90 to $3, excluding $200 million to $250 million of separation costs and a fourth quarter loss of approximately $100 million related to the agreements to sell Leroy-Somer and Control Techniques. 
I will now turn the presentation over to Cathy to talk about our business transformation.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Before we do that -- this is David Farr. I want to first thank Craig for the update in the quarter. Secondly, Cathy -- I've introduced Cathy. Cathy has been engaged for a little bit over a year now relative to what we refer to internally as the new Emerso
componenttext: Before we do that -- this is David Farr. I want to first thank Craig for the update in the quarter. Secondly, Cathy -- I've introduced Cathy. Cathy has been engaged for a little bit over a year now relative to what we refer to internally as the new Emerson. There's a lot of work that has to be done relative to the communication to our investors, our communication to our customers, our communication to our employees. And Cathy's taken on this assignment well with her team and several people from the various businesses that will still be part of Emerson going forward. And she's creating a new presentation of what Emerson means going forward. And so what we want to do today, given the announcement of the transaction to sell Network Power and the transaction to sell Leroy-Somer CT, I wanted Cathy to go through and share with investors and the outside people what we see as we go forward and will be formally announcing in early October. So I've asked Cathy to talk to the investors today and give you an insight set. And Cathy, the floor is yours. Thank you.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dave. Good afternoon, everyone. I'm positive you're all anxious to hear from Dave, so we'll try to use you're incredibly valuable time with great care and sensitivity. It is clear to me that I'm merely the warm-up band, and you're eager to get
componenttext:
Thank you, Dave. Good afternoon, everyone. I'm positive you're all anxious to hear from Dave, so we'll try to use you're incredibly valuable time with great care and sensitivity. It is clear to me that I'm merely the warm-up band, and you're eager to get to the main act. 
Today, we're going to briefly discuss how we plan our market expertise to better redefine our great company, to accelerate change, drive growth and imagine a different future. I believe you've already witness some tangible efforts of this this morning. 
Go to Page 2. Although today is about moving your view beyond our financial pie charts, this particular one holds all the excitement about our new possibilities. This demonstrates how we are adapting to a new reality, utilizing our already industry leadership position in adjacent markets and driving our single source end-to-end solutions. 
Go to Page 3. This is not revolutionary for an already well-managed and financially strong company. We're on our 126th-year-old journey of complexity reduction and perpetual integration of our businesses. We're driving efficiencies through a tighter brand, which should deliver more collaboration and more customer focus, resulting in more integrated solutions innovations between our businesses. We are therefore more capable of cross-leveraging our remaining portfolio and making it easier for all to navigate our business. 
Slide 4. So we need to accelerate past our previous transformations, evolving our business and our messaging from doing many things to concentrating our efforts on the critical challenges facing our customers specifically process, industrial, commercial and residential markets. For automation solutions, this means being the most trusted partner and problem solver for our customers during the current business crisis for them. This also becomes a showcase for our Internet of Things initiatives as we built on our legacy of long-term success of network intelligence in the field, our groundbreaking point in technology and our unmatched wireless heritage. For our commercial and residential business, we can focus on the [indiscernible] criticality of human comfort, connected homes, food quality, advancing energy efficiency at home and work as well as sustainability. 
Slide 5. As conglomerates have fallen out of favor, we quickly transitioned to a more highly focused enterprise. The best example of this has been through emerson.com debuting on October 1. But all of our communications, both internal and outside, will reflect and promote our new positioning. Talent acquisition migrates from fragmented business units to an Emerson career-centric approach. Our social media has historically been product brand-focused. And now we're trying to expose our deep industry expertise and to humanize our brand. Finally, advertising, which previously portrayed as a wide and deep, now can support 2 major businesses and their own deep special expertise. 
Slide 6. So a great example of this was our truly unexpected foundational sponsorship which is you probably know as the Davos meeting of the oil and gas industry. As we were developing our new Emerson automation solutions positioning, this seemed like a great opportunity to dramatically demonstrate our leadership position in the industry and launch our unique and desperately needed approach for the oil and gas businesses facing a crucial moment in their troubled marketplace. Top quartile solutions were a breakthrough approach for a vulnerable industry, and we try to optimize our moment in the sun. 
Slide 7. We poured exceptional effort and assets into the Houston-based event with full immersion media and social media training for all the Emerson executives. As we drove a full frontal media approach to Citi venue and with all the participants. The extraordinary results are the positive outcome of tightly choreographed messaging strategy as well as very well prepared executives. This is Emerson at its best applying full energy in singular focus. 
Slide 8. For Emerson's newly combined Commercial & Residential Solutions business, the opening of our new Helix Innovation Center in Dayton offered a similarly tightly-focused media and promotional event. It was designed to showcase the advantages mostly aligned with these businesses. Innovation Center clearly demonstrates our unique research capabilities around energy efficiency, connected homes and businesses in a real-time simulated environment. This miraculously includes a fully built-in IKEA-furnished house, a commercial kitchen which serves the entire Dayton campus of catering and convenience store. This all exists under a single roof and allows for monitoring and research under an exceptional array of climate environments and variable conditions. 
Slide 9. From a marketing viewpoint, the opening of the Helix allowed for wildly focused media event. We continued our highly publicized STEM support initiative with a survey on the issues of STEM education. For you financial guys, STEM is the acronym for science, technology, engineering and math. We again tapped Internet science superstar, Hank Green, and the backdrop of our innovation center on the University of Dayton campus. It was media magic. We showcased our engineering initiatives and allowed Hank to do a storytelling sorcery to millions of network viewers, social media networkers and even thousands of potential investors. This was astonishingly successful for a B2B initiative where media interest was stoked by the authentic connected story of STEM careers, sustainable research, a science geek in a real university setting. This is not just another product launch event. 
Slide 10. As we all know, digital access and transparency has changed all of our business lives forever. We also know that an extraordinary amount of research and private exploration goes on long before salesman is invited to the party. Your website is the window to your company's soul and undoubtedly has the ability to expose one's capability to better explain as well as execute one's business. Most multibillion-dollar companies cannot unify and face the challenge of reconstituting their digital presence. The unique inflection point of today's divestitures had swung open an opportunity to begin again. We've been working for 12 months on Phase 1 of our new web presence to launch single taxonomy, single product catalog, single technology approach, resulting in mobile always, all-glass responsive design. This will result in a cleaner, portable, searchable new emerson.com. It will take us 2 more years to complete the technology transition. Keep, kill, edit invent. We had over 700,000 pages in our previous environment, but we will be, at the very least, a more nimble, unified player. This is the one thing I believe our competitors did not expect from us and would fear the most, a better [indiscernible] integrated Emerson. 
Slide 11. So Dave has generously allowed me to give you a 3.5-minute quick tour of the emerson.com prototype. This is giving you all a sneak preview into our Phase 1 of the new site. I think you will find it as a new vision of a streamlined, tightly focused sales, exemplifying enduring strength and adaptability change as we rise to the new challenge. 
Here with me, as we thought it was technically safer to videotape the prototypes as it is a little jumpy, and we didn't want to take you out of the webcast, here is emerson.com. Please roll the video.
[Presentation]
Here we go. Okay. The front page is dedicated to introducing our clean design inviting customers
[Audio Gap]
breadth of our industries and humanize our brands. 
As we move to About Us, we see we introduce our visitors to our transformation story. This describes how we plan to increase value to both our customers and shareholders with our tight focus on 2 major business segments. Our realignment is about accelerated cultural change inside, customer joy outside and value creation for all. As we wind our visitors down the page, they will encounter a new Social Responsibility Report, access to our educational I Love STEM page and an extensive -- a much more extensive Join our Team Careers section. I'm also very proud of our more extensive social channel at YouTube. We are ready to connect. 
Finally, we head to our investors' happy home. Our Investors page is meant to be a familiar but improved user experience for all of you. Rollover resources, back year annual reports, profiles and SEC filings are at your mouse tap. Finally, an up-to-the-minute mergers and acquisition updates section will be available, but not currently available in our 30-day-old prototype. 
[Audio Gap]
Our world-famous signature brands are still prominent and easily searchable so every customer can still reach each SKU by bookmark, new easy search and relatable discovery. 
The Emerson Commercial & Residential Solutions business introduces us to the unified concept of optimized performance for connected buildings with energy control. All our products and services form the basis of many cohesive growth opportunities based on connected equipment, home and business monitoring, energy-efficient improvements and infrastructure support. World-class signature brands like Rigid, Sensi and InSinkErator form the basis for scalable solutions and are the bedrock of this B2B business in our only B2C Empire. 
As I introduced earlier, the Helix is a metaphor for commercial and residential businesses. Our 5 simulated environments are almost impossible to appreciate from a distance as the building offers us the ability to control the external environment, think winter in Alaska, summer in Dubai, in order to measure the energy efficiency of the home or business inside. Our innovation center is the realized laboratory, so Emerson's most impressive sustainable innovations like InSinkErator sprang to energy, food waste initiatives to Sensi, Wi-Fi thermostats and groundbreaking compressor health controls. 
So thanks -- thank you very much for your time and attention. And I will hand it back to Dave Farr.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Cathy. I appreciate your time. I wanted to -- the shareholders to understand, the investors to understand where we're trying to take the company going forward. A lot of work will be undertaken here the next 60 days as we get ready to
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Cathy. I appreciate your time. I wanted to -- the shareholders to understand, the investors to understand where we're trying to take the company going forward. A lot of work will be undertaken here the next 60 days as we get ready to launch. It's very important for our employees and our customers to understand what we're trying to do with Emerson and reposition the company into these 2 core business units. 
Clearly, a little over a year ago, we announced our repositioning efforts. We announced that we were going to sell or spin Network Power and sell the Leroy-Somer CT business. Today, we're very excited to announce that we found 2 strong partners to buy these respected businesses. Platinum buying the Network Power business, and a great solution for this business and one that we are excited about for platinum, the management team. And long term, meaning potentially us, given that we will have some potential upside if they're successful with our 15% equity ownership down the road. Also, a strong Japanese company that we've known for a long time, I know the Chairman for years buying our Leroy-Somer CT business and managing that business going forward. Again, a great solution for these 2 businesses with a good outcome for Emerson with over $5 billion of investment value for Emerson and our shareholders and for allowing us to reposition the company. We will have one more transaction in 2017. If you remember, we talked about selling ClosetMaid. We said we'd do that in '17. In total, we do somewhere between $5 billion and $6 billion in proceeds. And so we're well within what we expected back in February. 
So we look forward to closing these 2 transactions before the end of the calendar year and moving forward as the new Emerson and trying to drive a stronger valuable proposition for customers and for our shareholders. 
Now the third quarter. Yes, it was a tough quarter, a very tough quarter. June was a very challenging industrial marketplace for us, especially around process. Given the recent announcements of the GDP numbers, it shouldn't surprise any of us. The numbers announced last week from business investment for the last 9 months were negative and declining. Restatements for the last couple of years made it worse. So we're facing a very tough environment. And we saw that very quickly in the month of June as our process transactional business really slowed down as our customers continued to protect cash flow and their investments to make sure they have the cash needed to run the businesses or pay dividends or whatever they're doing. But clearly, a very challenging environment, but an environment where our team across Emerson knows what to do. And we're acting on it very aggressively and making sure we keep our costs in line, making sure we do the right things internally to protect the key investments but also keep our costs in line to allow us to generate the profits, the cash and the returns we expect at this company. 
In total, profitability for the third quarter was pretty good. We generate operating margins flat with last year at 17.4%. In case you didn't figure that out, 17.4%. We're down underlying sales of over 4%. Cash flow was very strong in the quarter. We're strong in cash flow for the first 9 months. We will continue to generate the cash flow to run the company, to invest and pay money back to our shareholders and do what we need to do. But we have to face the reality of what we see today. It's a tough market. We did see a bounce back in July in our process orders, which is a good sign. But in reality, we are looking at the marketplace right now where people are being very cautious, they're being very careful where they're spending money on and they're very uncertain relative to what's going on around the world from a political standpoint relative to this a business environment standpoint and where things are heading. So we're staying very focused on trying to drive the necessary actions to protect the short-term profitability, at the same time, staying very focused on making the right relevant long-term investments to drive the necessary change that we'll see in this business, this industry, when we come out. We will come out. This industry will come out. But clearly, a challenging marketplace right now and one that we fully understand that we have to deal with. And we will deal with it. 
Now let's think on the positive side of this. We had many people out there doubted that Emerson could take the transaction and the repositioning and get the job done. But the team within corporate, the team within Network Power, the team within LSCT and external partners did a lot of work the last 12 months and came up with very strong proposition both for our shareholders and for the buyers of these actions and also remaining assets that are being bought. Very pleased with the work there. Not easy to do in a marketplace, by the way, which is quite challenging. So my hats off to the entire team around the world for making this happen. I also want to thank the team for landing a tough quarter, a quarter that was a lot tougher than we started out thinking about it. And in reality, it ended up being very challenging, but we got the job done and delivered pretty good levels of profitability and levels of cash flow. No, it was not what we expected, but still very good in the environment we're seeing. 
From the perspective of the board and the senior management team, we're very focused on the future of the company. We have been repositioning the company, and we continue to reposition the company. It is a very solid company when we get down to the 2 businesses that will remain at the end of the calendar year. And we're very much focused on making the necessary investments internally and through strategic acquisitions to build upon these 2 businesses to once again return to over $20 billion in sales, profitable sales and profitable returns. The opportunities are there, and we're working on those. Yes, it's a tough environment, but there's no problem within Emerson. We deal with a tough environment. That's what we do. It's our DNA. Clearly, would I like to have a better time? Yes. But that's not what we're faced today. We're facing reality. We're very much focused on driving a stronger company, a more profitable company, a faster-growing company and remain an industry leader in the 2 key business units, business segments that will have when we finish. A tough quarter. Fourth quarter is going to be tough, too. Wasn't that long ago I thought that maybe we'd actually have flat or up sales in the fourth quarter. That's not going to happen. So we're going to have to deal with that. And from our perspective, as we continue the restructuring and get ready for a challenging 2017, it will be more favorable coming through a very difficult last 18 months, but still a challenging environment for us, but we are well positioned and will continue to be well positioned to drive levels of profitability that will generate great cash flow and returns. And over time, we'll continue to return to a growth mode that we know we have inside Emerson. 
So yes, I look back at the third quarter, a tough one, but we've got a lot done. Within 12 months from the announcement of the concept of our repositioning and selling our Network Power business, LSCT, we did it. We got it announced. We're looking at how we reorganize on the company to drive longer-term value, very good. The game is still on. The hard work is still happening. And I want to thank the entire management team globally working so hard here the last 12 months in this quarter to deliver what we need to deliver to continue to move Emerson forward to remain relevant and an industry leader in the space as we serve today and will continue to serve going forward in 2017 and beyond. 
With that, I open the floor for questions or comments. Thank you.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, thank you. I will not talk about '17. I will not talk about '17. Wait, Andy, let's be realistic here. We're in the first process of selling 2 businesses will happen in our first quarter of '17. We're in the process of going through what I'd call conti
componenttext: No, thank you. I will not talk about '17. I will not talk about '17. Wait, Andy, let's be realistic here. We're in the first process of selling 2 businesses will happen in our first quarter of '17. We're in the process of going through what I'd call continued restructuring process. We're going to an environment where people are still cutting back spending. So I'm give you a forecast. I've had a tough time this year. So I mean been better view of 6 months than what I do now. So from my perspective, I'm not going to give you forecast for '17. People are trying to guess '17 right now. I think it's a pure guess.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I understand. So just shifting gears then. You're guiding to $90 million to $100 million of expense this year. Yes, I think you've done $43 million so far. We know you've mentioned in the past restructuring takes time. But when we look at restructuring go
componenttext: I understand. So just shifting gears then. You're guiding to $90 million to $100 million of expense this year. Yes, I think you've done $43 million so far. We know you've mentioned in the past restructuring takes time. But when we look at restructuring going forward, you're seeing Process Management business have lower decrementals in the quarter than last quarter. How do we look at margin going forward in Process Management? To the decrementals get a little worse before they get better?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, from our perspective, yes. I think we're going to see from a Process Management standpoint, we'll have a good fourth quarter in process because it's always our best quarter. And from our -- we have a lot of restructuring underway in process. A lot
componenttext: I mean, from our perspective, yes. I think we're going to see from a Process Management standpoint, we'll have a good fourth quarter in process because it's always our best quarter. And from our -- we have a lot of restructuring underway in process. A lot of things have been announced and will be starting to book already. So we expect -- we'll be closer to $90 million global restructuring at fourth quarter. Clearly, you have timings and when things get pushed and shoved. But we're going to a continue the restructuring there in the fourth quarter, Then also in the first half for process automation. It looks to us that looks to me right now the process automation from the profitability standpoint are going down into the operating level -- probably around the high 17, low 18 EBIT margins obviously lower of restructuring. And they'll bounce back in that 20 level, but will not bounce back in '17 based on what we see right now. I just don't see the growth coming in the process will drive that leverage back up. A mode right now of trying to protect and minimize the downfall and profitability. And so what we're looking at right now probably from profitability is somewhere between 200, 250 basis points, I would say, deterioration and profitability at the operating level line of the process business for 2016. And that will stabilize that as we get into that -- into '17.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, Dave. And then if you look back, gave the order growth was in May and talk about potentially going positive in July? I know you talked about it sort of being delayed. How do you think about that order growth curve? Now I know you said it's
componenttext: That's helpful, Dave. And then if you look back, gave the order growth was in May and talk about potentially going positive in July? I know you talked about it sort of being delayed. How do you think about that order growth curve? Now I know you said it's very hard to forecast, but is it fair to say it's just sort of pushed out maybe 6 to 9 months? Any commentary on orders as we go forward here?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The order curves that we see today have trended pretty much in line with where I thought -- except for process. On the process segment, we have been bouncing between this minus 12% to minus 14% underlying order rate now for over a year. And until -- we an
componenttext: The order curves that we see today have trended pretty much in line with where I thought -- except for process. On the process segment, we have been bouncing between this minus 12% to minus 14% underlying order rate now for over a year. And until -- we anticipate, including myself, I made the call, no one else did, I made this call, that I've thought that would start lifting up towards a minus single digit. It has not happened. So based on what I see right now, the rest of the businesses have continued to trend upwards and would be pulling is up to positive, it would pull us up earlier in the positive, but until Process Management starts to seeing, I would say, a lift in the order pace, which, right now, is running at minus 12%, minus 13% range. Until we start seeing that move off that range and will communicate that. So once it goes into this minus 5% to minus 10%, start seeing the total Emerson lift comp. But right now, process is such a big piece. It's down at a level that we have not seen the lift pull us up. that's where we see right now. I see no indication that we'll see that going into single-digit underlying order pattern in the rest of this fiscal year, which is the fourth quarter. So most likely we'll start seeing as we move out of this quarter going into the first quarter and second quarter of fiscal '17.

componenttext: Right. If you got to agree to still get it done. The midpoint for the fourth quarter implied, I think, sequentially it's about a 5 -- just over 5% sequential step-up. It is a little bit more than we've seen historically. And given all the order rates you keep giving us certainly makes me question -- just wanted to understand a little bit, are there bright spots and you that making you think that this will be a little bit better than usual from Q3 to 4Q?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Based on the -- if you look at our underlying order pattern, we've been, total Emerson, been running underlying around the 4%, 4.5%, 5%, if you look at the pure underlying order rate. Right now, what we're saying is that pattern continues where we've been
componenttext: Based on the -- if you look at our underlying order pattern, we've been, total Emerson, been running underlying around the 4%, 4.5%, 5%, if you look at the pure underlying order rate. Right now, what we're saying is that pattern continues where we've been seeing them, then we should be able to reach this from the standpoint sequentially from the sale. We are also seeing, on a positive standpoint, we are seeing -- we had a lot -- inventory liquidation in some of our channel in the month of June and May and June and some of the commercial residential, we expect that that -- some of that will return in the fourth quarter. We also expect some of our compressor-type of business, which is the heat and the refrigeration markets, we expect a little bit of lift in that which will help us as we go into the fourth quarter. We're not expecting much from the process automation. If you look at the underlying business, we're down last year fourth quarter around 10% of sales for process. We'll be expect to be down again around 10%, again for the fourth quarter. So we're seeing the other businesses are saying of a lift. And that's what's going to pull us up. And we are banking the fact that process does not have a leg down. So while I was very pleased to see process came in preparation for today's board meeting and shared -- a showed is the July orders the way they work they do at 4, 4.5, so we know the July orders and the bounce back to a run rate that they got back into the average they've been seeing for the last 5 or 6 months and way above what we saw in June. So we did see a bounce back there. So that's how we look at it right now, Steve.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then if you look at just MRO versus CapEx type of demand within process and industrial, what -- or just raw automation, any -- at least a little more commentary on the MRO side? A little more stabilization there?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then if you look at just MRO versus CapEx type of demand within process and industrial, what -- or just raw automation, any -- at least a little more commentary on the MRO side? A little more stabilization there?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really. We've seen very weak -- in North America has been the real challenge for us to be Canada, U.S. and Mexico. The MRO business, the trend, what we call the transactional business, had a very, very weak June. As people really -- some of our custom
componenttext: Not really. We've seen very weak -- in North America has been the real challenge for us to be Canada, U.S. and Mexico. The MRO business, the trend, what we call the transactional business, had a very, very weak June. As people really -- some of our customers curtailed spending. They're doing the turnaround of the facilities and changes and the facilities and maintenance, but they're doing it very, very carefully and really cutting back on the expense at how much money is being spent. So that was -- that has not seen an improvement. We expected that to stabilize, but it's not yet. That will be a key sign for us. And I think that is also reflection that you see in the GDP -- when you disconstruct [ph] the GDP in the United States the last 3 quarters, you'll see that business investment continues to deteriorate. And that's one of the areas we're seeing right now is that day-to-day MRO type of business. And that's hurt us in the space.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can I sneak one more in? Given your prior comments -- commentary about where to deploy the capital going forward, and especially now that you're through this big milestone, are you thinking still -- you talked about a couple -- 1 or 2 transformational
componenttext: And can I sneak one more in? Given your prior comments -- commentary about where to deploy the capital going forward, and especially now that you're through this big milestone, are you thinking still -- you talked about a couple -- 1 or 2 transformational deals versus bolt-ons, what should investors -- are you leaning -- do you think we should expect 1 bolt-on us versus transformational? Is it really up in the air? What are you thinking?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We continue to do a little bolt-on, done a couple of smaller transactions of [indiscernible] software transactions in the commercial residential business the last 30 -- 30 days, 40 days. We're continuing to look for strategic investment in either the auto
componenttext: We continue to do a little bolt-on, done a couple of smaller transactions of [indiscernible] software transactions in the commercial residential business the last 30 -- 30 days, 40 days. We're continuing to look for strategic investment in either the automation business or the commercial residential business. So in discussions with the board today, we're very much focused on driving a trend -- what we call a -- a more strategic type of deal, a bigger deal included with the balance sheet strength, we can do that. But we're still very much focused on that. And our focus is to get that done some time in the next 3, 4, 5, 6 months. I mean, we're not going to do anything stupid, but we're looking at whatever we can invest to make a stronger core industrial Industrial Automation business or a core automation solutions business in this tough marketplace. So we're going to work it hard. We're not going to step back and wait.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Just following up on the issue of the step-up of restructuring. So if we think about this sort of remain co automation solutions segment, is the idea that the restructuring you have announced today, that should be sufficient to keep margins sort of flat in that business over the next 12 months, even as sales just line sort of a single-digit rate?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, our goal is, within the automation business and automation business -- Commercial & Residential Solutions business restructuring is really starting to tail off. Bob Sharp and Jim Lindemann have really done a very good job. They got ahead of this, and
componenttext: Yes, our goal is, within the automation business and automation business -- Commercial & Residential Solutions business restructuring is really starting to tail off. Bob Sharp and Jim Lindemann have really done a very good job. They got ahead of this, and that business is doing better. So our goal here is, between this year and the first 6 months of automation solutions business, is again spend restructuring [indiscernible] order and price spend between $50 million and $60 million next year. And the goal is to maintain the profitability level of this business, plus or minus 10 [ph] per 2. [ph] That is the goal. We're trying to find where we can find the bottom without, Julian, without as I my board, will not jeopardize the future of that franchise. Because it is a franchise. But we clearly are working that equation right now relative -- is a business has continued to weaken, as we look at probably next year, as I've said, probably a low single digit negative growth in the automation solutions business. How do we protect that profitability at the level we finished this year? And that's what the game is and that's what you're trying to structure. That's how the -- working the equation right now.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Understood. And then just a follow-up around this sort of gross margins impact from price versus material cost. I guess, for you, for everyone, that's been a tailwind for 12, 18 months in particular. When you're looking the next 12 months where input costs are now and what pricing is doing particularly for large projects, how do you see the price cost delta shifting, if at all?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: I think we have one more quarter of it, Julian, to be honest. And then my feeling is -- talked about I think that shift is going to come and the wind is going to come against a little bit. I firmly believe that with you start seeing that squeeze and we will not have the positive and that we'll have to fight pretty hard to maintain a neutral balance. But I wouldn't be surprised if you don't have a quarter or 2 the wind goes against us. But right now, we're in a mode where was the positive, but I think there's a period coming maybe early '17 where it goes against me for a couple of quarters. But were working that hard -- yes, were off -- Frank Dellaquila says were up 2/10 [ph] of GDP for the quarter. Assessment is right. As a give us another quarter, and we'll probably get 2 or 3 quarters coming out to be more challenging. And we'll probably be neutral or slightly negative.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pricing is not changing. What's happening right now, the pricing -- I think we talked about pricing around the point -- negative on average negative 0.5 -- negative 6, negative 0.7 for the year, we're well within that boundary right now. And the net mater
componenttext: Pricing is not changing. What's happening right now, the pricing -- I think we talked about pricing around the point -- negative on average negative 0.5 -- negative 6, negative 0.7 for the year, we're well within that boundary right now. And the net material inflation has been good for us. And it's been good for all the people. So the pricing is staying well within that boundary. I think, next year, we're probably -- I mean if I took a snapshot right now, Julian, [indiscernible] next year, I think it will be slightly negative. It won't be quite as negative as this year. But our net material inflation won't be as positive, and we do have that switch coming on where you all squeeze a little bit. So that's what is the right now. But people are behaving. We got other issues out there from that manufacturing standpoint like too much capacity and stuff like that.

componenttext: And just one other one. We've heard a lot about the M&A pipeline on the business. Can you talk about what you're looking for in the CNRS business? What types of technologies or geographies that you're looking at in? Any sense for what the size and opportunity might impacts be?

componenttextpreview: Yes. Most of the opportunities within the Commercial & Residential Solutions, I'll use the [indiscernible] that every be shy got Cathy better marketing, talking about is [indiscernible] hit me on the head with a baseball bat. Looking forward, and for sens
componenttext: Yes. Most of the opportunities within the Commercial & Residential Solutions, I'll use the [indiscernible] that every be shy got Cathy better marketing, talking about is [indiscernible] hit me on the head with a baseball bat. Looking forward, and for sensing, sensing [indiscernible] a bigger solution within our core product that we have there today, our software, looking for monitoring. We're looking for the transformation that we did the process world back. 20 years ago, when we created a very strong component business and created sensing solutions, the software, and that's where we're taking the position for the commercial residential. The business acquisitions, most of them right now, will be probably in the $20 million to $100 million range. There might be another $100 million, $200 million. No big significant acquisitions is from I would say the next 12, 18, 24 months. Bob Sharp and his team is driving the solution strategy around us right now. But -- so the early days with understanding how to create that. One of things Bob is coming from the process world and understanding that. So I'm expecting him to create a more of a solutions type of environment around this and to deleverage the core assets, leading assets we have in that space. So -- but it's going to be smaller sensing solution software type of acquisition and companies you [indiscernible] probably never even heard of or thought of, to be honest.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, I got congratulations on getting the sales done and for the amount that you got them done. I guess, as I think about your capital allocation [indiscernible] clearly, we've been talking about the M&A. But can you maybe touch on the dividend once agai
componenttext: Dave, I got congratulations on getting the sales done and for the amount that you got them done. I guess, as I think about your capital allocation [indiscernible] clearly, we've been talking about the M&A. But can you maybe touch on the dividend once again? And it's kind of like a holy grail for you. But I'm kind of get a sense for whether you're planning to set aside any of the capital from the net proceeds to fund the dividend going forward and how to think about buyback in that context as well?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks. First of all, thank you very much for recognizing the sale. Appreciate that. As I've been communicating for over a year on our -- the sort of our utilization of cash flow going forward, yes, the dividends is important -- important to us, to
componenttext: Okay. Thanks. First of all, thank you very much for recognizing the sale. Appreciate that. As I've been communicating for over a year on our -- the sort of our utilization of cash flow going forward, yes, the dividends is important -- important to us, to us, but to our shareholders we have our perspective we are right right now, with the shrinking of the company down to say around $15 billion [ph] and the cash flow is coming down along those lines, we will be [indiscernible] our dividend as to discuss the board that's for the next couple of years. The goal is obviously to grow the company both organically and through acquisitions to rebuild the cash flow based that we're losing from the divestitures. But right now, as you think about our company, you think about our free cash -- about our free cash flow next year and let's say we take the dividend up marginally a little bit like we did this year. Our dividend coverage, our cash flow -- free cash flow to dividend coverage is going to around the mid 60% level. And -- so our goal is to figure out how to keep that -- peak in that mid-60s, maybe higher 60s, and then move it back down in the range of 40% to 50%. As I've told the shareholders, however, let's say that we're not able to find significant strategic acquisition. We're in -- we're not able to get the growth necessary to get back up to the side of the earnings and cash flow base that we had just a couple of years ago. And then we will, as a board, we'll have to consider to cut the dividend. That is not where we sit right now. Right now, we have the capability and funding internally and doing the dividend and will dial back the share repurchase. And this year, we end up to around $600 million share repurchase. Next year, we'll probably be somewhere in the $100 million to $200 million range, just basically covering what -- and any stock that we're putting out there for employees and -- but will dial that back. The intention of the board, as we've discussed a lot over the last 12 months, the use of proceeds that we -- in our balance sheet, to go out and to continue to aggressively and make investments within the 2 core spaces maintaining or keeping the company. And that's where our focus is going to be.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- to be very honest here, I think -- given the current trends, the underlying growth rate of our automation business next year will be slightly negative. We'll be low single-digit negative sales. From that perspective, with the restructuring doin
componenttext:
I think -- to be very honest here, I think -- given the current trends, the underlying growth rate of our automation business next year will be slightly negative. We'll be low single-digit negative sales. From that perspective, with the restructuring doing we're doing everything possible to protect our profitability as we finish this year in that environment. And that's in -- and so that's what I see right now. Until I see our customer base willing to invest more for productivity, invest for next-generation capacity or whatever it takes, it's going to be a tough environment. So I don't see that. On the commercial residential. We do see underlying growth, and we do see a little bit of improvement in profitability. Next year, the focus of that business will be the integration of some of the various businesses. As we've talked about streamlining and creating a very strong global integrated business. And so that's what that focus is going to be. So next year, I would say that business will be -- we'll have a positive underlying growth. And most likely, we'll see little bit of continued margin improvement.
[Audio Gap]
So this business is done. How much of the free cash -- or how much free cash would you be generating in the United States?

componenttext: I mean I don't think -- I mean I -- from my perspective in North America, Amy there's some hesitation read of the spending but really, anything about -- it really boils down to the overall economy not growing. 1% growth for the last 2 or 3 quarters and 4 quarters is not very exciting. And I think that created an environment where businesses are being very, very cautious spending money. The political environment around the world is where a function of what's going on in Europe, our election years, what's going on in Japan, it's just -- this a lot of uncertainty relative to what from a government standpoint is what the direction is the government. Are we going to try to create negative interest rates for the world? Are ready to try to invest and grow the world? And right now, I've see more of an environment where a lot of create negative interest rates to give people free money and there's no incentive to invest. That's the whole environment, I'd say.

componenttext: From a -- from the control platform, from diagnostics and things and stuff like that, we continue to invest. We continue to buy technologies.
