headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, August 2, 2016. Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain f
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded today, August 2, 2016. 
Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain forward-looking statements, including the company's outlook for the remainder of the year. Information on factors that could cause actual results to vary materially from those discussed today is available at Emerson's most recent annual report on Form 10-K as filed with the SEC. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Craig Rossman, Director of Investor Relations at Emerson. Please go ahead.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Renée. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; Frank Dellaquila, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Katherine Button Bell, Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer. Today's ca
componenttext:
Thank you, Renée. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; Frank Dellaquila, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Katherine Button Bell, Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer. 
Today's call will summarize Emerson's third quarter 2016 results and also provide an update on Emerson's business transformation. A conference call slide presentation will accompany my comments and is available on Emerson's website at emerson.com. 
A replay of this conference call and slide presentation will be available on the website for the next 90 days. 
I will start with the third quarter summary as shown on Page 2 of the slide presentation. Net sales in the quarter decreased 7% versus the prior year to $5.1 billion, with underlying sales down 5%. The third quarter results reflected the continuation and challenging demand conditions in our key served markets. Oil and gas spending, both capital investment and operational expenditures, remains at significantly depressed levels. Automation markets in North America have been extremely challenging, as anticipated improvements in spending did not materialize as we had it forecast. Data center and telecommunications infrastructure demand continued to be favorable while global air conditioning and refrigeration and U.S. construction markets were mixed. The trailing 3-month orders for June were down 6.7% on a GAAP basis with underlying trends down 4.4%, excluding approximately 2% per currency translation. Adjusted earnings per share, which excludes $37 million of separation cost, decreased 5% to $0.80. 
Reported earnings per share were $0.74. Operating cash flow in the quarter was $718 million. 
Turning to Slide 3. Despite lower-than-expected sales, EBIT margin increased 20 basis points versus the prior year, driven by benefits from restructuring actions and solid operational execution with our businesses. No additional shares were repurchased during the quarter, and separation costs were significantly lower than expected. 
Turning to Slide 4. Underlying sales decreased in all regions except Europe. The results by region were similar to the second quarter as the global environment for business investment remains challenging. 
Turning to Slide 5. Total segment margin was up 50 basis points to 16% as 3 segments reported improved margins. Both the Climate Technology and Commercial & Residential Solutions segments reported up margins despite lower volumes. And improved cost structure resulted in operating cash flow of $718 million in the quarter. Capital spending continues to be reduced, in line with overall business conditions. 
Turning to Slide 6. Process Management underlying sales decreased 13% in the quarter. Energy spending, particularly in North America, continues to be reduced -- continued to be reduced as customers evaluate the stability of current oil and gas prices, while power and life sciences markets continue to provide growth. 
Restructuring programs will be further increased in response to weak demand conditions from global oil and gas customers and the expectation that weaker conditions will continue into 2017. 
Segment margin decreased 290 basis points primarily due to a sharp volume reduction and the resulting deleverage, partially offset by savings from restructuring actions.
Turning to Slide 7. Industrial Automation third quarter underlying sales declined 11%, reflecting continued weakness in industrial spending and upstream oil and gas capital investments, while wind projects remained favorable for the drives business. Segment margin decreased 110 basis points primarily due to volume deleverage and price, partially offset by savings from restructuring actions and material cost containment. Mix demand forecasts among the businesses are expected to result in improved levels of sales and profitability in the fourth quarter.
Turning to Slide 8. Network Power underling sales increased 10% in the quarter as strong order trends in both data center and telecommunications infrastructure markets translated into positive growth. Sales increased in all regions except Europe, which reflected a difficult comparison to the prior year from large project revenues. 
Segment margin improved 550 basis points to 9.1%, driven by volume leverage in savings from restructuring actions. Benefits from restructuring actions and new product program support the expectation for continued margin improvement in the fourth quarter. 
Turning to Slide 9. Climate Technologies underlying sales decreased 1% in the quarter as decreases in Asia and the Middle East more than offset increases in other regions. Underlying sales growth in North America and Europe reflected low single-digit growth in both the air conditioning and commercial refrigeration businesses. Segment margin increased 270 basis points to 22.4% primarily due to savings from restructuring actions and material cost containment, partially offset by lower pricing. The near-term outlook for global demand in our served markets supports the expectation for modest sales growth in the fourth quarter. 
Turning to Slide 10. Underlying sales in the Commercial & Residential Solutions segment decreased 1% as growth in food waste disposers was offset by declines in all other businesses, which were impacted by customer-driven inventory reduction. Segment margin improved 380 basis points to 24.4%, reflecting the impact of the divestiture, savings from restructuring actions and material cost containment. Modest levels of underlying growth are expected in the fourth quarter as we anticipate favorable conditions in U.S. construction to continue and channel inventory reduction should be complete.
Turning to Slide 11. Earlier today, we announced agreements to sell our Network Power, Leroy-Somer and Control Techniques businesses for a combined value of $5.2 billion, which is in line with the guidance we provided at our February investor conference. These agreements represent a significant step forward in the overall portfolio repositioning strategy we announced last year in June. And with these agreements now in place, the strategic repositioning squarely focuses on acquisitions within our core platforms of Automation Solutions and Commercial & Residential Solutions as Emerson management and the board determine how best to redeploy the cash proceeds from these divestitures.
Turning to Slide 12. The third quarter results continue to reflect the low growth global environment facing our businesses today. And the outlook remains challenging as markets will continue to be impacted by reduced levels of investment spending, weaker global economics and political uncertainty. Considering these conditions, coupled with the fact that anticipated improvement in order trends did not materialize, the company now expects fiscal year underlying sales to be down 5% to 6%, excluding currency translation and an impact from completed divestitures of approximately 2% each. Adjusted earnings per share for the fiscal year are now expected to be $2.90 to $3, excluding $200 million to $250 million of separation costs and a fourth quarter loss of approximately $100 million related to the agreements to sell Leroy-Somer and Control Techniques. 
I will now turn the presentation over to Kathy to talk about our business transformation.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Before we do that -- this is David Farr. I want to, first, thank Craig for the update in the quarter. Secondly, Kathy -- I'll introduce Kathy. Kathy has been engaged for a little bit over a year now relative to, what we refer to internally as, the new Eme
componenttext: Before we do that -- this is David Farr. I want to, first, thank Craig for the update in the quarter. Secondly, Kathy -- I'll introduce Kathy. Kathy has been engaged for a little bit over a year now relative to, what we refer to internally as, the new Emerson. There's a lot of work that has to be done relative to the communication to our investors, our communication to our customers, our communication to our employees. And Kathy has taken on this assignment well with her team and several people from the various businesses that will still be part of Emerson going forward. And she's creating a new presentation of what Emerson means going forward. And so what we want to do today, given the announcement of the transaction to sell Network Power and the transaction to sell Leroy-Somer and CT, I want Kathy to go through and share with investors and the outside people what we are seeing as we go forward and will be formally announcing in early October. So I've asked Kathy to talk to the investors today and give you an insight to that. And Kathy, the floor is yours. Thank you.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dave. Good afternoon, everyone. I'm positive you're all anxious to hear from Dave, so I will try to use your incredibly valuable time with great care and sensitivity. It is clear to me that I'm merely the warm-up band, and you're eager to get t
componenttext:
Thank you, Dave. Good afternoon, everyone. I'm positive you're all anxious to hear from Dave, so I will try to use your incredibly valuable time with great care and sensitivity. It is clear to me that I'm merely the warm-up band, and you're eager to get the main act. 
Today, we're going to briefly discuss how we are planning our market expertise to better redefine our great company, to accelerate change, drive growth and imagine a different future. I believe you've already witnessed some tangible efforts of this, this morning. 
Go to Page 2. Although today is about moving your view beyond our financial pie charts, this particular one holds all the excitement about our new possibilities. This demonstrates how we are adapting to a new reality, utilizing our already industry leadership positions in adjacent markets and driving our single source, end-to-end solution.
Go to Page 3. This is not revolutionary for an already well-managed and financially strong company. We're on our 126-year-old journey of complexity reduction and perpetual integration of our businesses. We're driving efficiencies through a tighter brand, which should deliver more collaboration and more customer focus, resulting in more integrated solutions innovation between our businesses. We are therefore more capable of cross-leveraging our remaining portfolio and making it easier for all to navigate our business. 
Slide 4. So we need to accelerate past our previous transformations, evolving our business and our messaging from doing many things to concentrating our efforts on the critical challenges facing our customers, specifically in the process, industrial, commercial and residential markets. For Automation Solutions, this means being the most trusted partner and problem-solver for our customers during the current business crisis for them. This also becomes a showcase for our Internet of Things initiatives as we build on our legacy of long-term success of network intelligence in the field, we are groundbreaking PlantWeb technology and are unmatched wireless heritage. For our Commercial & Residential business, we can focus on the criticality of human comfort, connected homes, food quality and advancing energy efficiency at home and work as well as sustainability. 
Slide 5. As conglomerates have fallen out of favor, we've quickly transitioned to a more highly focused enterprise. The best example of this has been the new emerson.com debuting on October 1. But all of our communications, both internal and outside, will reflect and promote our new positioning. Talent acquisition migrates from fragmented business units to an Emerson career-centric approach. Our social media has historically been product brand-focused, and now we're trying to expose our deep industry expertise and to humanize our brand. 
Finally, advertising, which previously portrayed us as wide and deep, now can support 2 major businesses and their own deep special expertise. 
Slide 6. So a great example of this was our truly unexpected foundational sponsorship of CERAWeek, which is you probably know as the Davos meeting of the oil and gas industry. As we were developing our new Emerson Automation Solutions positioning, this seemed like a great opportunity to dramatically demonstrate our leadership position in the industry and launch our unique and desperately needed approach for the oil and gas businesses facing a crucial moment in their troubled marketplace. Top quartile solutions were a breakthrough approach for a vulnerable industry, and we tried to optimize our moment in the sun. 
Slide 7. We poured exceptional effort in assets in the Houston-based event with full immersion media and social media training for all the Emerson executives, as we drove a full frontal media approach at the Citi venue and with all the participants. The extraordinary results were the positive outcome of tightly choreographed messaging strategy as well as very well prepared executives. This is Emerson at its best applying full energy in singular focus. 
Slide 8. For Emerson's newly combined Commercial & Residential Solutions business, the opening of our new Helix Innovation Center in Dayton offered a similarly tightly-focused media and promotional event. It was designed to showcase the advantages mostly aligned in these businesses. Innovation Center clearly demonstrates our unique research capabilities around energy efficiency, connected homes and businesses in a real-time simulated environment. This miraculously includes a fully built-in IKEA-furnished house, a commercial kitchen which serves the entire Dayton campus of catering and a convenience store. This all exists under a single roof and allows for monitoring and research under an exceptional array of climate environments and variable conditions. 
Slide 9. From a marketing viewpoint, like CERAWeek, the opening of the Helix allowed for a widely focused media event. We continued our highly publicized STEM support initiative with a survey on the issues of STEM education. For you financial guys, STEM is the acronym for science, technology, engineering and math. We again tapped Internet science superstar, Hank Green, in the backdrop of our innovation center on the University of Dayton campus. It was media magic. We showcased our engineering initiatives and allowed Hank to do a storytelling sorcery to millions of network viewers, social media networkers and even thousands of potential investors. This was astonishingly successful for a B2B initiative where media interest was stoked by the authentic connected story of STEM careers, sustainable research, a science geek and a real university setting. This is not just another product launch event. 
Slide 10. As we all know, digital access and transparency has changed all of our business lives forever. We also know that an extraordinary amount of research and private exploration goes on long before salesman is invited to the party. Your website is the window to your company's soul, and undoubtedly has the ability to expose one's capability to better explain as well as execute one's business. Most multibillion-dollar companies cannot unify and face the challenge of reconstituting their digital presence. The unique inflection point of today's divestitures have swung open an opportunity to begin again. We've been working for 12 months on Phase 1 of our new web presence to launch single taxonomy, single product catalog, single technology approach, resulting in mobile-always all-glass responsive design. This will result in a cleaner, portable, searchable new emerson.com. It will take us 2 more years to complete the technology transition, keep, kill, edit invent. We had over 700,000 pages in our previous environment, but we will be, at the very least, a more nimble, unified player. This is the one thing I believe our competitors would not expect from us and would fear the most, a better, more fully integrated Emerson.
Slide 11. So Dave has generously allowed me to give you a 3.5-minute quick tour of the emerson.com prototype. This is giving you all a sneak preview into our Phase 1 of the new site. I think you will find it as a new vision of our streamlined, tightly focused sales, exemplifying enduring strength and adaptability to change as we rise to the new challenge. 
Here with me, as we thought it was technically safer to videotape the prototypes as it is a little jumpy, and we didn't want to take you out of the webcast, here is emerson.com. Please roll the video.
[Presentation]
Here they go. Okay. The front page is dedicated to introducing our clean design, inviting customers to explore, career seekers to learn and investors to fall in love all over again. It is meant to be a showcase of our great stories and a window to our values. The new site is an exceptional initiative to burst our silence and unify our businesses. In usability resource, our customers said it was usable [indiscernible] and that the images highlight the breadth of our industries and humanize our brand.
As we move to About Us, you'll see we introduced our visitors to our transformation story. This describes how we plan to increase value to both our customers and shareholders with our tight focus on 2 major business segments. Our realignment is about accelerated cultural change inside, customer joy outside and value creation for all. As we wind our visitors down the page, they will encounter a new Social Responsibility Report, access to our educational, I Love STEM, page and extensive -- or much more extensive Join our Team Careers section. I'm also very proud of our more extensive social channels [indiscernible]. You'll see from YouTube -- Twitter to YouTube, we are ready to connect. 
Finally, we head to our investors' happy home. Our Investors page is meant to be a familiar, but improved user experience for all of you. Rollover resources, back year annual reports, profiles and SEC filings are at your mouse tip. Finally, an up-to-the-minute mergers and acquisition updates section will be available, but not currently available in our 30-day-old prototype. 
Emerson Automation Solutions is the doorway to our ever-bonding offering in the industry and process industries. We immediately discussed capital projects, operational effeciency and tour our Internet of things offering on a global scale of a level. We -- our site is founded on an industry-centric approach allowing us to better explain our end-to-end solutions with an industry view.
Our world-famous signature brands are still prominent and easily searchable so every customer can still reach each SKU by bookmark, new easy search and relatable discovery. 
The Emerson Commercial & Residential Solutions business introduces us to the unified concept of optimized performance for connected buildings with energy control. All our products and services form the basis for many cohesive growth opportunities based on connected equipment, home and business monitoring, energy-efficient improvement and infrastructure support. World-class signature brands like Rigid, Sensi and InSinkErator form the basis for scalable solutions and are the bedrock of this B2B business in our only B2C Empire. 
As I introduced earlier, the Helix is the metaphor for Commercial & Residential businesses. Our 5 simulated environments are almost impossible to appreciate from a distance as the building offers us the ability to control the external environment, think winter in Alaska, summer in Dubai, in order to measure the energy efficiency of the home or business inside. Our innovation center has been a terrific real-life laboratory, so the Emerson's most impressive sustainable innovations like InSinkErator [indiscernible] to energy, food waste initiatives to Sensi, Wi-Fi thermostats and groundbreaking compressor health controls. 
So thanks -- thank you very much for your time and attention. And I will hand it back to Dave Farr.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Kathy. I appreciate your time. I wanted to -- the shareholders to understand, the investors to understand where we're trying to take the company going forward. A lot of work will be undertaken here the next 60 days as we get ready to
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Kathy. I appreciate your time. I wanted to -- the shareholders to understand, the investors to understand where we're trying to take the company going forward. A lot of work will be undertaken here the next 60 days as we get ready to launch. It's very important for our employees and our customers to understand what we're trying to do with Emerson and reposition the company into these 2 core business units. 
Clearly, a little over a year ago, we announced our repositioning efforts. We announced that we were going to sell or spin Network Power and sell the Leroy-Somer CT business. Today, we're very excited to announce that we found 2 strong partners to buy these respected businesses. Platinum buying the Network Power business, and a great solution for this business and one that we are excited about for Platinum, the management team, and long term, even potentially us, given that we will have some potential upside if they're successful with our 15% equity ownership down the road. Also, Nidec, a strong Japanese company that we've known for a long time, I know the Chairman for years, is buying our Leroy-Somer CT business and managing that business going forward. Again, a great solution for these 2 businesses with a good outcome for Emerson with over $5 billion of investment value for Emerson and our shareholders and for allowing us to reposition the company. We will have one more transaction in 2017. If you remember, we talked about selling ClosetMaid, and we said we'd do that in '17. In total, we do somewhere between $5 billion and $6 billion in proceeds. And so we're well within what we expected back in February. 
So we look forward to closing these 2 transactions before the end of the calendar year and moving forward as the new Emerson and trying to drive a stronger valuable proposition for our customers and for our shareholders. 
Now the third quarter. Yes, it was a tough quarter, a very tough quarter. June was a very challenging industrial marketplace for us, especially on process. Given the recent announcements of the GDP numbers, it shouldn't surprise any of us. The numbers announced last week from business investment for the last 9 months were negative and declining. Restatements for the last couple of years made it worse. So we're facing a very tough environment. And we saw that very quickly in the month of June as our process transactional business really slowed down as our customers continued to protect cash flow and their investments to make sure they have the cash needed to run the businesses or pay dividends or whatever they're doing. Clearly, a very challenging environment, but an environment where our team across Emerson knows what to do. And we're acting on it very aggressively and making sure we keep our costs in line, making sure we do the right things internally to protect the key investments, but also keep our costs in line to allow us to generate the profits, the cash and the returns we expect at this company. 
In total, profitability for the third quarter was pretty good. We generate operating margins flat with last year at 17.4%. In case you didn't figure that out, 17.4%. We're down underlying sales of over 4%. Cash flow was very strong in the quarter. We're strong in cash flow for the first 9 months. We will continue to generate the cash flow to run the company, to invest and pay money back to our shareholders and do what we need to do. But we have to face the reality of what we see today. It's a tough market. We did see a bounce back in July in our process orders, which is a good sign. But in reality, we are looking at a marketplace right now where people are being very cautious, they're being very careful what they're spending money on, and they're very uncertain relative to what's going on around the world from a political standpoint relative to there's a [indiscernible] business environment standpoint and where things are heading. So we're staying very focused on trying to drive the necessary actions to protect the short-term profitability. At the same time, staying very focused on making the right relevant long-term investments to drive the necessary change that we'll see in this business, this industry, when we come out. We will come out. This industry will come out. But clearly, a challenging marketplace right now and one that we fully understand that we have to deal with. And we will deal with it. 
Now let's think on the positive side of this. We had many people out there doubted that Emerson could take the transaction, the repositioning and get the job done. But the team within corporate, the team within Network Power, the team within LSCT and our external partners did a lot of work the last 12 months and came up with very strong proposition both for our shareholders and for the buyers of these actions and also remaining assets that are being bought. Very pleased with the work there. Not easy to do in a marketplace, by the way, which is quite challenging. So my hats off to the entire team around the world for making this happen. I also want to thank the team for landing a tough quarter, a quarter that was a lot tougher than we started out thinking about it. And in reality, it ended up being very challenging, but we got the job done and delivered pretty good levels of profitability and levels of cash flow. No, it was not what we expected, but still very good in the environment we're seeing. 
From the perspective of the board and the senior management team, we're very focused on the future of the company. We have been repositioning the company, and we continue to reposition the company. It is a very solid company when we get down to the 2 businesses that will remain at the end of the calendar year. And we're very much focused on making the necessary investments internally and through our strategic acquisitions to build upon these 2 businesses to once again return to over $20 billion in sales, profitable sales and profitable returns. The opportunities are there, and we're working on those. Yes, it's a tough environment, but there's no problem within Emerson. We deal with tough environments, that's what we do, it's our DNA. Clearly, would I like to have a better time? Yes. But that's not what we faced today. So we're facing reality. We're very much focused on driving a stronger company, a more profitable company, a faster-growing company and remain an industry leader in the 2 key business units -- business segments that will have when we finish. A tough quarter. Fourth quarter is going to be tough, too. Wasn't that long ago I thought that maybe we'd actually have flat or up sales in the fourth quarter, that's not going to happen. So we're going to have to deal with that. And from our perspective, as we continue restructuring and get ready for a challenging 2017, it will be more favorable coming through a very difficult last 18 months, but still a challenging environment for us. But we are well positioned and will continue to be well positioned to drive levels of profitability that would generate great cash flow and returns. And over time, we'll continue to return to a growth mode that we know when inside Emerson. 
So yes, I look back at the third quarter, a tough one, but we've got a lot done. Within 12 months from the announcement of the concept of our repositioning and selling our Network Power business, LSCT, we did it. We got it announced. We're looking at how reorganized on the company to drive longer-term value, very good. The game is still on. The hard work is still happening. And I want to thank the entire management team globally working so hard here the last 12 months and in this quarter to deliver what we need to deliver to continue to move Emerson forward to remain relevant and an industry leader in the space as we serve today and will continue to serve going forward in 2017 and beyond. 
With that, I open the floor for questions or comments. Thank you.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Andy Kaplowitz with Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Andy Kaplowitz with Citi.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So look, I know it's early, you don't want to give specific '17 guidance. But can you talk about the puts and takes in terms of '17 EPS? You've got the dilution from the [indiscernible] businesses...
componenttext: So look, I know it's early, you don't want to give specific '17 guidance. But can you talk about the puts and takes in terms of '17 EPS? You've got the dilution from the [indiscernible] businesses...

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, thank you. I will not talk about '17. I will not talk about '17. Wait, Andy, let's be realistic here. We're in the process of selling 2 businesses that will happen in our first quarter of '17. We're in the process of going through what I'd call a cont
componenttext: No, thank you. I will not talk about '17. I will not talk about '17. Wait, Andy, let's be realistic here. We're in the process of selling 2 businesses that will happen in our first quarter of '17. We're in the process of going through what I'd call a continued restructuring process. We're in a process of going through an environment where people are still cutting back spending. So I'm going to give you a forecast. I've had a tough time this year. So I mean, I've better a view of 6 months ago than I do now. So from my perspective, I'm not going to give you a forecast of '17. People are trying to guess '17 right now, I think it's a pure guess.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I understand. So just shifting gear then. You're guiding to $90 million to $100 million of restructuring expense this year. You've done, I think, $43 million so far. You know- we know you've mentioned in the past that restructuring takes time. But when we
componenttext: I understand. So just shifting gear then. You're guiding to $90 million to $100 million of restructuring expense this year. You've done, I think, $43 million so far. You know- we know you've mentioned in the past that restructuring takes time. But when we look at restructuring going forward, you're seeing Process Management business have lower decrementals in the quarter than last quarter. How do we look at margin going forward in Process Management? Could the decrementals get a little worse before they get better?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, from our perspective, yes. I think we're going to see from a Process Management standpoint, we'll have a good fourth quarter process because it's always our best quarter. And from our -- we have a lot of restructuring underway in process. A lot of
componenttext: I mean, from our perspective, yes. I think we're going to see from a Process Management standpoint, we'll have a good fourth quarter process because it's always our best quarter. And from our -- we have a lot of restructuring underway in process. A lot of things have been announced and will be starting to book or started to book already. So as we expect, it will be close to the $90 million global restructuring in that fourth quarter. Clearly, you have timings when things get pushed and shoved, but we're going to continue the restructuring there in the fourth quarter, but also in the first half for process automation. It looks to me right now the process automation from a profitability standpoint are going to be going down into the operating level, probably around the high 17, low 18 EBIT margins, obviously lower because of restructuring. And they'll bounce back in to that 20 level, but will not bounce back in '17 based on what we see right now. I do start to see the growth coming in the process will drive that leverage back up. So we are in the mode [ph] right now, we're trying to protect and minimize the downfall and profitability. And so what we're looking at right now probably from profitability is somewhere between 200, 250 basis points, I would say, deterioration and profitability at the operating level line of the process business for 2016. And that we'll stabilize that as we get into that -- into '17.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, Dave. And then if you look back, you remember, you gave the order growth curve to us in May and you talked about it potentially going positive in July? And I know you talked about it sort of being delayed. How do you think about that order
componenttext: That's helpful, Dave. And then if you look back, you remember, you gave the order growth curve to us in May and you talked about it potentially going positive in July? And I know you talked about it sort of being delayed. How do you think about that order growth curve now? I know you said it's very hard to forecast, but is it fair to say it's just sort of pushed out, maybe 6 to 9 months? Any commentary on orders as we go forward here?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The order curves that we see today have trended pretty much in line where I thought they'd trend except for Process. On the Process segment, we've been bouncing between this minus 12% to minus 14% underlying order rate now for over a year. And until -- we
componenttext: The order curves that we see today have trended pretty much in line where I thought they'd trend except for Process. On the Process segment, we've been bouncing between this minus 12% to minus 14% underlying order rate now for over a year. And until -- we anticipate, including myself, I made the call, no one else did, I made this call, that I thought that it would start lifting up towards minus single digit. It has not happened. So based on what I see right now, the rest of the businesses have continued to trend upwards and would be pulling us up to positive, and would pull us up earlier to positive, but until Process Management starts seeing, I would say, a lift in the order pace, which, right now, is running this minus 12%, minus 13% range, until we start seeing that move off that range and we'll communicate that, so once it goes into this minus 5% to minus 10%, then you're going to start seeing the total Emerson lift comp. But right now, Process is such a big piece. It's down at a level that we have not seen the lift to pull us up. So that's where we see it right now. I see no indication that we'll see that going into single-digit underlying order pattern in the rest of this fiscal year, which is the fourth quarter. So most likely, we'll start seeing as we move out of this quarter going into the first quarter and second quarter of fiscal '17.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steven Winoker with Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steven Winoker with Bernstein.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, you invited questions or comment. So I am actually going to take a leap here and say congratulations on getting a sale done, which I know we've been debating for a long time. So congrats on that.
componenttext: Dave, you invited questions or comment. So I am actually going to take a leap here and say congratulations on getting a sale done, which I know we've been debating for a long time. So congrats on that.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. A lot of hard work by a lot of people out there, Steve that you should be thanking not me. I mean, I am just -- there are other people who did a lot of work on that, I know that's not easy -- and do it right for their organization, which is ver
componenttext: Thank you. A lot of hard work by a lot of people out there, Steve that you should be thanking not me. I mean, I am just -- there are other people who did a lot of work on that, I know that's not easy -- and do it right for their organization, which is very important.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And you had to still agree to and get it done. The midpoint for the fourth quarter implied, I think, sequentially is about a 5 -- just over 5% sequential step-up. It is a little bit more than we've seen historically. And given all the order rates y
componenttext: Right. And you had to still agree to and get it done. The midpoint for the fourth quarter implied, I think, sequentially is about a 5 -- just over 5% sequential step-up. It is a little bit more than we've seen historically. And given all the order rates you keep giving us, it certainly makes me just want to understand a little bit, is there-- are there any bright spots in here that are making you think that this would be just a little bit better than usual from 3 to 4Q?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Based on the -- if you look at our underlying order pattern, we've been -- and total Emerson, we've been running underlying around the 4%, the 4.5%, 5%, if you look at the pure underlying order rate. So now right, what we're seeing is if that pattern cont
componenttext: Based on the -- if you look at our underlying order pattern, we've been -- and total Emerson, we've been running underlying around the 4%, the 4.5%, 5%, if you look at the pure underlying order rate. So now right, what we're seeing is if that pattern continues where we've been seeing, then we should be able to reach this from the standpoint sequentially from the sales. We are also seeing -- on a positive standpoint, we are seeing -- we had a lot -- we had some inventory liquidation in some of our channel in the month of June and May and June in some of the commercial residential, we expect that that -- some of that will return in the fourth quarter. We also expect some of our compressor-type of business, which is the heat and the refrigeration markets, we expect a little bit of lift in that which will help us as we go into the fourth quarter. We're not expecting much from the process automation. If you look at the underlying business, we're down last year of the fourth quarter around 10% of sales for process. We'll be expected to be down again around 10%, again for the fourth quarter. So we're seeing the other businesses are seeing a little lift. And that's what's going to pull us up. And we are banking the fact that process does not have a leg down. So I was very pleased to see process came in, in preparation for today's board meeting and shared -- showed us the July orders the way they work they do a 4, 4.5, so we know the July orders. And they bounce back to a run rate that they got back into the average they've been seeing for the last 5 or 6 months and way above what we saw in June. So we did see a bounce back there. So that's how we look at it right now, Steve.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then if you look at just MRO versus CapEx type of demand within process and industrial, what -- or just overall automation, any -- at least, a little more commentary on the MRO side? A little more stabilization there?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then if you look at just MRO versus CapEx type of demand within process and industrial, what -- or just overall automation, any -- at least, a little more commentary on the MRO side? A little more stabilization there?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really. We've seen very weak -- North America has been the real challenge for us, it'd be Canada, U.S. and Mexico. The MRO business, the trans -- what we call the transactional business, had a very, very weak June. As people really -- some of our cust
componenttext: Not really. We've seen very weak -- North America has been the real challenge for us, it'd be Canada, U.S. and Mexico. The MRO business, the trans -- what we call the transactional business, had a very, very weak June. As people really -- some of our customers curtailed spending. They're doing the turnaround of the facilities and changes, the facilities and maintenance, but they're doing it very, very carefully and really cutting back on the expense at how much money is being spent. So that was -- that has not seen an improvement. We expected that to stabilize, but it's not yet. That will be a key sign for us. And I think that is also reflection that you see in the GDP -- when you disconstruct [ph] the GDP in the United States the last 3 quarters, you'll see that business investment continues to deteriorate. And that's one of the areas we're seeing right now is that day-to-day MRO type of business. And that's hurt us in the space.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can I sneak one more in? Given your prior comments -- prior commentary about where to deploy the capital going forward, and especially now that you're through this big milestone, are you thinking still -- you talked about a couple -- 1 or 2 transforma
componenttext: And can I sneak one more in? Given your prior comments -- prior commentary about where to deploy the capital going forward, and especially now that you're through this big milestone, are you thinking still -- you talked about a couple -- 1 or 2 transformational deals versus bolt-ons, what should investors -- are you leaning -- do you think we should expect 1 bolt-ons versus transformational? Or it's really up in the air? Or what are you thinking?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We continue to do a little bolt-on. We've done a couple of smaller transactions -- the unique software transactions in the commercial residential business in the last 30 -- 30 days, 40 days. We are continuing to look for strategic investment in either the
componenttext: We continue to do a little bolt-on. We've done a couple of smaller transactions -- the unique software transactions in the commercial residential business in the last 30 -- 30 days, 40 days. We are continuing to look for strategic investment in either the automation business or the commercial residential business. So in discussions with the board today, we're very much focused on driving a trend -- what we call a -- a more strategic type of deal -- a bigger deal, included with the balance sheet strength, we can do that. But we are still very much focused on that. And our focus is to get that done some time in the next 3, 4, 5, 6 months. I mean, we're not going to do anything stupid, but we're looking at where we can invest to make a stronger core Industrial Automation business or a core automation solutions business in this tough marketplace. So we're going to work it hard. We're not going to step back and wait.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Julian Mitchell with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Julian Mitchell with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up on the issue of the stepped-up restructuring. So if we think about the sort of remaining co, automation solutions segment, is the idea that the restructuring you've announced today, that should be sufficient to keep margins sort of flat
componenttext: Just following up on the issue of the stepped-up restructuring. So if we think about the sort of remaining co, automation solutions segment, is the idea that the restructuring you've announced today, that should be sufficient to keep margins sort of flat in that business over the next 12 months, even as sales decline sort of a single-digit rate?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, our goal is -- within the automation business and automation goods -- commercial & Residential Solutions business restructuring is really starting to tail off. Bob Sharp and Jim Lindemann have really done a very good job. They got ahead of this, and
componenttext: Yes, our goal is -- within the automation business and automation goods -- commercial & Residential Solutions business restructuring is really starting to tail off. Bob Sharp and Jim Lindemann have really done a very good job. They got ahead of this, and that business is doing better. So our goal here is, between this year and the first 6 months of automation solutions business, is again spend restructuring [indiscernible] order and price spends somewhere between $50 million and $60 million next year. And the goal is to maintain the profitability level of this business, plus or minus 10 for 2. That is the goal. We're trying to find where we could find that bottom without -- Julian, without as I tell my board, I will not jeopardize the future of that franchise. Because it is a franchise. But we clearly are working that equation right now relative -- as the business has continued to weaken, as we look at probably next year, as I've said, probably a low single digit negative growth in the automation solutions business. How do we protect that profitability at the level we finished this year? And that's what the game is, and that's what you're trying to structure. That's how the -- how we're working the equation right now.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then just a follow-up around the sort of gross margins impact from price versus from material cost. I guess, for you, for everyone, that's been a tailwind for 12, 18 months in particular. When you look in the next 12 months, where input co
componenttext: Understood. And then just a follow-up around the sort of gross margins impact from price versus from material cost. I guess, for you, for everyone, that's been a tailwind for 12, 18 months in particular. When you look in the next 12 months, where input costs are now and what pricing is doing, particularly for large projects, how do you see the price cost delta shifting, if at all?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know from our aspect, it has been a positive for us. If you look our GP margins, we had a -- I mean our GP margin's core is what, frankly, were up this year -- this quarter. I think our GP margin was up this quarter?
componenttext: You know from our aspect, it has been a positive for us. If you look our GP margins, we had a -- I mean our GP margin's core is what, frankly, were up this year -- this quarter. I think our GP margin was up this quarter?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we have one more good quarter of it, Julian, to be honest. And then my feeling is what you've heard me talked about. I think that shift's going to come and the wind's going to come against us a little bit. And I firmly believe that we are going to
componenttext: I think we have one more good quarter of it, Julian, to be honest. And then my feeling is what you've heard me talked about. I think that shift's going to come and the wind's going to come against us a little bit. And I firmly believe that we are going to start seeing that squeeze, and we will not have the positives and then we'll have to fight pretty hard to maintain a neutral balance. But I wouldn't be surprised if we don't have a quarter or 2 where the wind goes against us. But right now, we're in a mode where we're still positive, but I think there's a period coming, maybe early '17, where it goes against me for a couple of quarters. But we're working that hard because when we -- yes, we're up to -- Frank Dellaquila says we're up 2/10 of the GP for the quarter. So that -- your assessment's right. I think, give us another quarter, and then we'll probably get 2 or 3 quarters coming out to be more challenging. And we'll probably be neutral or slightly negative.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: But pricing itself, you and your competitors, is that changing much or not really versus 6 month ago?
componenttext: But pricing itself, you and your competitors, is that changing much or not really versus 6 month ago?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pricing is not changing. What's happening right now, the pricing -- I think we talked about pricing around the point negative -- on average negative 0.5, a negative 6, negative 0.7 for the year. We're well within that boundary right now. And the net mater
componenttext: Pricing is not changing. What's happening right now, the pricing -- I think we talked about pricing around the point negative -- on average negative 0.5, a negative 6, negative 0.7 for the year. We're well within that boundary right now. And the net material inflation, it has been good for us. And it's been good for all the people. So the pricing is staying well within that boundary. I think, next year, we're probably -- I mean if I took a snapshot right now, Julian, to think about next year, I think it'll be slightly negative. It won't be quite as negative as this year. But our net material inflation won't be as positive, and we do have that switch coming on where you also need to squeeze a little bit. So that's what I see right now. But people are behaving. We got other issues out there from manufacturing standpoint like, too much capacity and stuff like that.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gautam Khanna with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gautam Khanna with Cowen and Company.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I may have missed it, but could you elaborate on what the tax leakages from the 2 divestitures, if any?
componenttext: David, I may have missed it, but could you elaborate on what the tax leakages from the 2 divestitures, if any?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The tax -- okay, I mean I'll let Frank talk about the tax leakage a little bit.
componenttext: Yes. The tax -- okay, I mean I'll let Frank talk about the tax leakage a little bit.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we've got gross proceeds, as we told you earlier today, of about $5.2 billion, the net proceeds will probably come in around $4.3 billion, $4.4 billion. So we've got a bit of tax leakage on both of them. A lot of moving parts, especially around th
componenttext: Yes. So we've got gross proceeds, as we told you earlier today, of about $5.2 billion, the net proceeds will probably come in around $4.3 billion, $4.4 billion. So we've got a bit of tax leakage on both of them. A lot of moving parts, especially around the Network Power deal in terms of where we're recognizing gains and losses where we have basis. But that's about the net of it right there.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one other one. We've heard a lot about the M&A pipeline on the AF's business. Can you talk about what you're looking for in the CNRS business? What types of technologies or geographies that you're looking at in? And any sense for what the size of
componenttext: And just one other one. We've heard a lot about the M&A pipeline on the AF's business. Can you talk about what you're looking for in the CNRS business? What types of technologies or geographies that you're looking at in? And any sense for what the size of some of those opportunity might in fact be?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Most of the opportunities within the Commercial & Residential Solution, I'll use the world name, so I'll pick abbreviation. I've got Kathy, my Head of Marketing, and she's beating over the top of my head with my own baseball bat. From our perspective
componenttext: Yes. Most of the opportunities within the Commercial & Residential Solution, I'll use the world name, so I'll pick abbreviation. I've got Kathy, my Head of Marketing, and she's beating over the top of my head with my own baseball bat. From our perspective, what we're looking forward's is sensing -- we're looking for sensing type of technologies to allow us to create a bigger solution within our core product that we have there today. We're looking for software, we're looking for monitoring, we're looking for the transformation that we did in the profits, roll back 20 years ago, when we created a very strong component business and created sensing solutions, the software, and that's where we're taking the position for the commercial residential. The business acquisitions, most of them right now, will be probably in the $20 million to $100 million range. There might be another $100 million, $200 million. No big significant acquisitions in, for what I would say, the next 12, 18, 24 months. Bob Sharp and his team is driving the solution strategy around us right now. So they're early days into understanding on how to create that. One of thing is, Bob is coming from the process world and understanding that. So I'm expecting him to create a more of a solutions type of environment around this and deleverage the core assets, leading assets we have in that space. So -- but it's going to be smaller sensing solution software type of acquisitions, and companies you probably never even heard of or thought of, to be honest.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Joe Ritchie with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Joe Ritchie with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, I've got a congratulations on getting the sales done and for the amount that you got them done. I guess, as I think about your capital allocation for already it's -- clearly we've been talking about the M&A. But can you maybe touch on the dividend o
componenttext: Dave, I've got a congratulations on getting the sales done and for the amount that you got them done. I guess, as I think about your capital allocation for already it's -- clearly we've been talking about the M&A. But can you maybe touch on the dividend once again? And I know it's kind of like a holy grail for you. But I'm trying to get a sense for whether you're planning to set aside any of the capital from the net proceeds to fund the dividend going forward, and how to think about buyback in that context as well?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks. First of all, thank you very much for recognizing the sale. I appreciate that. As I've been communicating for over a year on our -- sort of our utilization of cash flow going forward, yes, the dividend's important. So that's just important n
componenttext: Okay. Thanks. First of all, thank you very much for recognizing the sale. I appreciate that. As I've been communicating for over a year on our -- sort of our utilization of cash flow going forward, yes, the dividend's important. So that's just important not to us per se, but to our shareholders. And from our perspective, where we are right now, with the shrinking of the company down to say around $15 billion, and the cash flow is coming down along those lines, we will be [indiscernible] our dividend, as we've discussed at the board level, from the next couple of years. The goal is obviously to grow the company both organically and through acquisitions to rebuild the cash flow base that we're losing from the divestitures. But right now, as you think about our company, you think about our free cash -- let's think about our free cash flow next year, and let's say we take the dividend up marginally a little bit like we did this year. Our dividend coverage, our cash flow -- the free cash flow to dividend coverage is going to go around the mid 60% level. And -- so our goal is to figure out how to keep that -- peak at that mid-60s, maybe higher 60s, and then move it back down in the range of 40% to 50%. As I've told the shareholders, however, let's say that we're not able to find significant strategic acquisitions. We're in -- we're not able to get the growth necessary to get back up to the size of the earnings and cash flow base that we had just a couple of years ago. Then we will, as a board, we'll have to consider, do we cut the dividend? But that is not where we sit right now. Right now, we have the capability, both in funding internally and doing the dividend, and will dial back the share repurchase. And this year, we are going to end up around $600 million of share repurchase. Next year, we'll probably be somewhere in the $100 million and $200 million range, just basic covering what -- any stock that we're putting out there for employees and -- but we'll dial that back. The intention of the board, as we've discussed a lot over the last 12 months, the use of proceeds that work in our balance sheet, to go out and to continue do aggressively, and make investments within the 2 core spaces we're maintaining or keeping the company. And that's where our focus is going to be.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's really helpful. In -- I guess maybe one last question. I know it's probably too early to talk about 2017.
componenttext: Got it. That's really helpful. In -- I guess maybe one last question. I know it's probably too early to talk about 2017.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No way -- go ahead, go ahead.
componenttext: No way -- go ahead, go ahead.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to ask it anyway. I guess, if you are thinking about just the underlying trends that you're seeing in process today, if those underlying trends were to hold steady through the year and as we progress into 2017, can you guys grow margins giving t
componenttext: I'm going to ask it anyway. I guess, if you are thinking about just the underlying trends that you're seeing in process today, if those underlying trends were to hold steady through the year and as we progress into 2017, can you guys grow margins giving the price cost commentary earlier as well as you have the restructuring actions that you're taking in that business?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- just to be very honest here, I think -- given the current trends, the underlying growth rate of our automation business next year will be slightly negative. It'll be low single-digit negative sales. From that perspective, with the restructuring
componenttext: I think -- just to be very honest here, I think -- given the current trends, the underlying growth rate of our automation business next year will be slightly negative. It'll be low single-digit negative sales. From that perspective, with the restructuring we're doing, we're going to do everything possible to protect our profitability as we finish this year in that environment. And that's in -- and so that's what I see right now. Until I see our customer base willing to invest more for productivity, invest for next-generation capacity or whatever it takes, then it's going to be a tough environment. So I don't see that. On the commercial residential, we do see underlying growth, and we do see a little bit of improvement in profitability. Next year, the focus of that business will be the integration of some of the various businesses. As we've talked about streamlining and creating a very strong global, integrated business. And so that's where that focus is going to be. So next year, I would say that business will be -- we'll have a positive underlying growth. And most likely, we'll see little bit of continued margin improvement in which -- and the business is running at pretty good level of profitability right now.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, as we walk through these transactions that we will start closing, we're looking at bringing back all the proceeds, because we'll see -- we'll receive a significant amount of proceeds offshore. And then we normally bring back $400 million to $500 million of cash very efficiently every year anyway. So we understand the issue of the dividend and the share repurchase, but we think we have it covered.

componenttext: Yes, one thing we do with our finance committee is we very clearly lay out the cash flow needs over a couple of years. And where that might be coming from, so we try to get ourselves surprised and boxed. But these are for us to see the new. But we understand that issue.

componenttext: No. So there would not be any of that. There will be no minority interest. We have no board seat. What we have is, if the business does well -- and we'll be retaining a 15% subordinate equity fees. If the business does well, and something happens and they make the return, then we -- then obviously we'll get a piece of that on the upside. So that gives us a little bit of capability. If something does go well, and a lot of the efforts we put in the last couple of years, here we have a chance of making something down the road. Maybe my successor or whoever has a chance to have a little bit more money coming out of that for our own shoulders at some point in time. But no, no minority interest on the balance sheet on this one.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That makes sense. Lastly, is there a timeline, Dave, where you would say, now we've sort of accomplished the M&A for this. I mean, in other words, you sort of have given yourself a 2-year window on the dividend. Does that imply that the execution of
componenttext: Okay. That makes sense. Lastly, is there a timeline, Dave, where you would say, now we've sort of accomplished the M&A for this. I mean, in other words, you sort of have given yourself a 2-year window on the dividend. Does that imply that the execution of replacing the lost earnings is over 2 years? Or I mean, you would want it to be front end loaded, right? But except that M&A markets -- it's a little bit pricey. I'm how curious how you would like us to think about the timeline perhaps of deployment of proceeds to do these acquisitions?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Yes, from my -- from our perspective it's, Frank and I, as we review with the board and also the finance committee, we see that where the 2 years come from. The fact that we don't get a map or sort of like a road map to figure out how to get th
componenttext: All right. Yes, from my -- from our perspective it's, Frank and I, as we review with the board and also the finance committee, we see that where the 2 years come from. The fact that we don't get a map or sort of like a road map to figure out how to get that. Our return and our coverage interest -- our coverage from the dividend on free cash flow coming back down towards the 50% level. And so that's why we say 2 years since we don't have a road map that through acquisitions or faster internal growth, then the pressure is going to be building. Both of us, as a management team and the board and our shareholders and say, "Hey, what -- how long can you maintain that high level of dividend payout without damaging the company?" So that's why we look at that and say a 2-year window, you know, a nice round number to talk about. That's why we say that.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I guess, Dave, in terms of your comments around process. I mean, obviously, you talked about perhaps about July orders. But obviously we're now in a bear market hold again, given recent trading. So I guess, what gives you confidence that we're not going to see something kind of worse going forward?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have confidence. I mean, from our perspective, just go read the transcripts from when the oil and gas companies have reported. All we do is we could -- we look at our business, we look at what's going on in transaction, look at the day-to-day orde
componenttext: I don't have confidence. I mean, from our perspective, just go read the transcripts from when the oil and gas companies have reported. All we do is we could -- we look at our business, we look at what's going on in transaction, look at the day-to-day order book and what comes in, we have good systems, we can see that. The fact that, I look at the stability and the flattening of certain things, and we make the call. So that type of confidence level I have. I know of no customers out there saying "All the things are great. We're looking at increasing spending." But we have a very broad, diverse business, global business in lot of industries. And so that's how we make that call. And I was just -- I am encouraged by the fact that we did see a bounce back in July because June was a very -- I mean knocking-over-the-head type of month for our process business. So that's where I'm coming from. But we'll see.

componenttext: Okay. And then the final question is, I mean, from a capital allocation standpoint, you're caught up between a rock and hard place here. And from that standpoint, you've got companies that are probably having eroding fundamentals right now and you have to take a look at them in the public equity market that in the main is still rising, still high valuations. I mean, is there a case to be made to kind of baton the hatches here? Shift capital allocation and then, just get a better sense of where we are in the down cycle before pursuing something more aggressive on the strategic front?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we obviously look at everything, but it -- we'll make that call based on what assets are potentially out there for us to make a call on. I mean it's -- I think that if you have unique opportunities, you have to take those opportunities. If you thi
componenttext: I mean, we obviously look at everything, but it -- we'll make that call based on what assets are potentially out there for us to make a call on. I mean it's -- I think that if you have unique opportunities, you have to take those opportunities. If you think about our business, in automation business, we're involved with, they're few and far between assets you can actually interact with. So you do what you have to deal with. But our -- let's just put it this around that, looking to go out and do something really quick and crazy with a $4 billion, which I don't have yet. But I think, from our perspective, we see the opportunity and we see a situation, we're going to take advantage of the situation right now. It's a tough market place out there. And you try to find -- ever tried to guess bottoms when to buy stocks or buy things, you're going to lose. That's a loser strategy. We're going to buy assets we think we can make money. And so I look at people that sold the day of Brexit and the day after Brexit. I would call that very short-term thinking.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: So I know you've clarified that you're not going to give any '16, '17 guidance. componenttext: Exactly. Exactly. I think that -- yes, it's not a huge transaction that will -- our people have been pretty busy right now on this one. So we'll get -- we'll launch that from January '17. The exact -- I think we talked about $5 billion to $6 billion, and we'll be right about range with this one, too. Then we're done. Thank you.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Deane Dray with RBC.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, hopefully, you could expand a bit more on the potential divestitures. And as I was going through Kathy's slides, you still have a legacy exposure to data centers with Liebert, and I just wanted to hear from you what sort of linkages you think that b
componenttext: Dave, hopefully, you could expand a bit more on the potential divestitures. And as I was going through Kathy's slides, you still have a legacy exposure to data centers with Liebert, and I just wanted to hear from you what sort of linkages you think that business has -- it certainly does with climate, but beyond the climate when it gets where else does Liebert fit within the business on a go forward?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Liebert is part of the Network Power business, which is being divested. So there is no -- if you look at our Network Power business, which is, as you think about the business, and there you have Liebert, you have [indiscernible], you have as ASCO power, y
componenttext: Liebert is part of the Network Power business, which is being divested. So there is no -- if you look at our Network Power business, which is, as you think about the business, and there you have Liebert, you have [indiscernible], you have as ASCO power, you have Avocent, you have Invensys. Businesses that we've had for a long time or made an acquisition, that's the compromise -- that's the composition of the business that are being divested. So most businesses will make up the Network Power business, which is being divested and bought by Platinum today and run by Scott Barbour. And then the Leroy-Somer CT business, which was the, what we call, the odd Industrial Automation businesses that was left out with those business we've had it for a long time will also -- those are being sold to Nidec in a separate transaction. So once we're down to that, the only business left that doesn't fit within our automation solutions business is, our business ClosetMaid business, which is a storage business we bought many, many years ago and did very well with. And we -- there's no reason to keep that. That's we're moving that out. And then, at that point in time, all the business will fit in very nicely and have a lot of core strength between commercial, residential and solutions and automation. And maybe Craig, come back and come in and see, we'll set you some diameters to go through it and see if you can see the 2 business segments and how they're being fit together.
