componenttext: No. It's not from an accounting sense an equity position. It’s a subordinated interest, which, under the right circumstances, could be a very good payout for us down the road.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That makes sense. Lastly, is there a timeline, Dave, where you would say, now we've sort of accomplished the M&A for this. I mean, in other words, you sort of have given yourself a 2-year window on the dividend. Does that imply that the execution of
componenttext: Okay. That makes sense. Lastly, is there a timeline, Dave, where you would say, now we've sort of accomplished the M&A for this. I mean, in other words, you sort of have given yourself a 2-year window on the dividend. Does that imply that the execution of replacing the lost earnings is over 2 years? Or I mean, you would want it to be front end loaded, right? But except that M&A markets -- it's a little bit pricey. So I'm just curious how you would like us to think about the timeline perhaps of deployment of proceeds to do these acquisitions?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Yes, from my -- from our perspective it's, Frank and I, as we review with the board and also the finance committee, we see that where the 2 years come from the fact that we don't get a map or sort of like a road map to figure out how to get tha
componenttext: All right. Yes, from my -- from our perspective it's, Frank and I, as we review with the board and also the finance committee, we see that where the 2 years come from the fact that we don't get a map or sort of like a road map to figure out how to get that. Our return and our coverage interest -- our coverage from the dividend on free cash flow coming back down towards the 50% level. And so that's why we say 2 years since we don't have a road map that through acquisitions or faster internal growth, then the pressure is going to be building. Both of us, as a management team and the board and our shareholders and say, "Hey, what -- how long can you maintain that high level of dividend payout without damaging the company?" So that's why we look at that and say a 2-year window, you know, a nice round number to talk about. That's why I say that.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert McCarthy with Stifel.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, Dave, in terms of your comments around process. I mean, obviously, you talked about perhaps a bounce July orders. But obviously we're now in a bear market for oil again, given recent trading. So I guess, what gives you confidence that we're
componenttext: Yes, I guess, Dave, in terms of your comments around process. I mean, obviously, you talked about perhaps a bounce July orders. But obviously we're now in a bear market for oil again, given recent trading. So I guess, what gives you confidence that we're not going to see something kind of worse going forward?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have confidence. I mean, from our perspective, just go read the transcripts from any oil and gas companies that have reported. All we do is we could -- we look at our business, we look at what's going on in transaction, look at the day-to-day orde
componenttext: I don't have confidence. I mean, from our perspective, just go read the transcripts from any oil and gas companies that have reported. All we do is we could -- we look at our business, we look at what's going on in transaction, look at the day-to-day order book and what comes in, we have good systems, we can see that. The fact that, I look at the stability and the flattening of certain things, and we make the call. So that type of confidence level I have. I know of no customers out there saying "Oh, things are great. We're looking at increasing spending." But we have a very broad, diverse business, global business in lot of industries. And so that's how we make that call. And I was just -- I am encouraged by the fact that we did see a bounce back in July because June was a very -- I mean knock-you-over-the-head type of month for our process business. So that's where I'm coming from. But we'll see.

componenttext: Okay. And then the final question is, I mean, from a capital allocation standpoint, you're kind of between a rock and hard place here. And from that standpoint, you've got companies that are probably having eroding fundamentals right now and you have to take a look at them in the public equity market that in the main is still rising, still high valuations. I mean, is there a case to be made to kind of batten the hatches here? Shift capital allocation and then, just get a better sense of where we are in the down cycle before pursuing something more aggressive on the strategic front?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we obviously look at everything, but it -- we'll make that call based on what assets are potentially out there for us to make a call on. I mean it's -- I think that if you have unique opportunities, you have to take those opportunities. If you thi
componenttext: I mean, we obviously look at everything, but it -- we'll make that call based on what assets are potentially out there for us to make a call on. I mean it's -- I think that if you have unique opportunities, you have to take those opportunities. If you think about our business, in automation business, we're involved with, they're few and far between assets you can actually interact with. So you do what you have to deal with. But -- let's just put it this way, I’m not looking to go out and do something really quick and crazy with a $4 billion which I don't have yet. But I think, from our perspective, we see the opportunity and we see a situation, we're going to take advantage of the situation right now. It's a tough marketplace out there. And you try to find -- ever try to guess bottoms when to buy stocks or buy things, you're going to lose. That's a loser strategy. We're going to buy assets we think we can make money. And so I look at people that sold the day of Brexit and the day after Brexit. I would call that very short-term thinking.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: I just said in the call a couple of minutes ago, I think what we said the impact will be about the same, maybe a little bit more, maybe about the same. But I think if you look at the Network Power and Leroy-Somer [indiscernible], it's about the same number. Delta is about the same. It's just one's has done better, one's done worse. So that's about what we're seeing right now.

componenttext: Exactly. Exactly. I think that -- yes, it's not a huge transaction that will -- our people have been pretty busy right now on this one. So we'll get -- we'll launch that from January '17. The exact -- I think we talked about $5 billion to $6 billion, and we'll be right about range with this one, too. Then we're done. Thank you.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Deane Dray with RBC.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, hopefully, you could expand a bit more on the potential divestitures. And as I was going through Kathy's slides, you still have a legacy exposure to data centers with Liebert, and I just wanted to hear from you what sort of linkages you think that b
componenttext: Dave, hopefully, you could expand a bit more on the potential divestitures. And as I was going through Kathy's slides, you still have a legacy exposure to data centers with Liebert, and I just wanted to hear from you what sort of linkages you think that business has -- it certainly does with climate, but beyond the climate when it gets where else does Liebert fit within the business on a go forward?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Liebert is part of the Network Power business, which is being divested. So there is no -- if you look at our Network Power business, which is, as you think about the business, and there you have Liebert, you have Chloride, you have ASCO power, you have Av
componenttext: Liebert is part of the Network Power business, which is being divested. So there is no -- if you look at our Network Power business, which is, as you think about the business, and there you have Liebert, you have Chloride, you have ASCO power, you have Avocent, you have Invensys. Businesses that we've had for a long time or made an acquisition, that's the compromise -- that's the composition of the business that are being divested. So most businesses will make up the Network Power business, which is being divested and bought by Platinum today and run by Scott Barbour. And then the Leroy-Somer CT business, which was the, what we call, the odd Industrial Automation businesses that was left out with those business we've had it for a long time will also -- those are being sold to Nidec in a separate transaction. So once we're down to that, the only business left that doesn't fit within our automation solutions business is our ClosetMaid business, which is a storage business we bought many, many years ago and did very well with. And we -- there's no reason to keep that. That's we're moving that out. And then, at that point in time, all the business will fit in very nicely and have a lot of core strength between commercial, residential and solutions and automation. And maybe Craig, come back and come in and see it sometime and go through it and see if you can see the 2 business segments and how they're being fit together.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's helpful. Just looks as though that slide hadn't been updated, because you still have data center thermal management included on the umbrella of the businesses.
componenttext: No, that's helpful. Just looks as though that slide hadn't been updated, because you still have data center thermal management included on the umbrella of the businesses.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. Because that's within here. Okay, now I got the question, Dean. So you're right, within the Helix, our engineering center, we actually have a cooling data center there which we're monitoring and what that -- from that standpoint, that was buil
componenttext: Okay, okay. Because that's within here. Okay, now I got the question, Dean. So you're right, within the Helix, our engineering center, we actually have a cooling data center there which we're monitoring and what that -- from that standpoint, that was built in when -- obviously, Network Power is part of it. And we'll work with that down the road to help them. But that's part of cooling. But it's just more of a compression thing. That's all will be in sensing thing. That will not be in our core part. That -- they do have that capability within the Helix today because our customers want to look at cooling, precision cooling or humidity, whatever it is. And that's nothing to do with the business we're keeping. It's just with that engineering center there in Dayton, Ohio. A good question, thank you.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a last question, I don't need to spin you up, but you did bring up the thought that there could be some of the business investment hesitancy because of political uncertainty. And how meaningful do you think that is across your businesses today?
componenttext: Just a last question, I don't need to spin you up, but you did bring up the thought that there could be some of the business investment hesitancy because of political uncertainty. And how meaningful do you think that is across your businesses today?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean I don't think -- I mean I -- from my perspective in North America, I'm sure there's some hesitation relative to spending but really -- and you think about, it really boils down to the overall economy's not growing. 1% growth for the last 2 or 3 qua
componenttext: I mean I don't think -- I mean I -- from my perspective in North America, I'm sure there's some hesitation relative to spending but really -- and you think about, it really boils down to the overall economy's not growing. 1% growth for the last 2 or 3 quarters or 4 quarters is not very exciting. And I think that that's created an environment where businesses are being very, very cautious at spending money. The political environment around the world is more of a function of what's going on within Europe, our elections here, what's going on in Japan, it's just -- there's a lot of uncertainty relative to, well from the government standpoint, just what -- where the direction is the government? Are we going to try to create negative interest rates for the world? Are we going to try invest and grow the world? And right now, I see more of an environment where we want to create negative interest rates and give people free money, and there's no incentive to invest. That's the whole environment, I'd say.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Shannon O'Callaghan with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Shannon O'Callaghan with UBS.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just in terms of this June and July stuff with process. I mean there's parts of the oil and gas world seems to be stabilizing during that period of time, but other parts seems to be still getting worse. I mean as you talk to some of the customers and took
componenttext: Just in terms of this June and July stuff with process. I mean there's parts of the oil and gas world seems to be stabilizing during that period of time, but other parts seems to be still getting worse. I mean as you talk to some of the customers and took some of that feedback in June, I mean were there -- were you able to make any sense of the parts that were stabilizing versus the parts taking another leg down?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I've -- from what we're seeing, what we saw was clearly they're doing the maintenance, they're doing the turnaround situations, but they clearly are being told to spend less on it. And that's what we're seeing right now. And from the standpoint of a June
componenttext: I've -- from what we're seeing, what we saw was clearly they're doing the maintenance, they're doing the turnaround situations, but they clearly are being told to spend less on it. And that's what we're seeing right now. And from the standpoint of a June -- June's normally a very big month for our process industry because of all the turnaround situations over the summer months. And I think that our customer base just got a little bit more cautious in that month. And hopefully, with this maybe they're getting through that period right now, they're going to feel and go back to a little bit more of a normal pace we've been seeing. But June was such a shocker to us relative to how much they decided to contract. But I just think people are being super, super cautious. And bosses are probably saying, hey, we did it for $1 last couple of years, could you do this now for $0.50? And so I think that's what's going on in this environment right now.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just as you think about investing in the process business both organically and via M&A, I mean, Emerson was a real trendsetter in terms of Digital Communication and asset management of devices, et cetera. And now there's a lot of activity g
componenttext: Okay. And then just as you think about investing in the process business both organically and via M&A, I mean, Emerson was a real trendsetter in terms of Digital Communication and asset management of devices, et cetera. And now there's a lot of activity going on in that space. I mean, do you think there's anything you need to do differently there? Or are you still comfortable with the control platform and you just think you want to add more devices to it? Maybe just give a sense of where you think you are there.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: From a -- from the control platform or from diagnostics sensing, stuff like that, we continue to invest. We continue to buy technologies. We continue to do internal investment in those technologies. Nothing real big in that space. As we continue to make s
componenttext: From a -- from the control platform or from diagnostics sensing, stuff like that, we continue to invest. We continue to buy technologies. We continue to do internal investment in those technologies. Nothing real big in that space. As we continue to make sure that we stay, keep a leading position as we go forward here. So a lot of our investment dollars are still phased in that space right there. We will continue to look at our acquisitions relative to offering a broader package relative to our solution. So bringing more capability to the end market relative to the capabilities brought from control, from instrumentation, from valves, whatever it takes -- measurement out there. So we'll continue to look at trying to add to that capability, but we continue to be a leading investor relative to your first question, relative to sensing, control and diagnostics, and we'll continue to do that going forward because we have no intention of losing that. So that's the fine line we walk relative to where we slowed down our investments, when we don't slow down our investments.

componenttext: A question on process. David, you've seen a deeper trough manifest here. How does that inform your view of expectation for steeper recovery at some point versus kind of just the more absolute baseline reset?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: My opinion is, the deeper we go, the longer we stay down here, the faster the snapback. I've been here once before, I saw it. And so the longer -- the more pain you have, the better in the end. No fun in having the pain up front, but the better the snapba
componenttext: My opinion is, the deeper we go, the longer we stay down here, the faster the snapback. I've been here once before, I saw it. And so the longer -- the more pain you have, the better in the end. No fun in having the pain up front, but the better the snapback. So it's right now it's a deeper pain going down, it’s longer pain going down and that tells me one thing that spending will have to bounce back at a faster rate. And now it's all about this industry.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no, Steve, Steve. When they buy the business, they'll write the check for $4 billion. And then if -- they're going to run the business. And if the business does well, and we made a lot of investments in that business and you could see it's been pr
componenttext: No, no, no, Steve, Steve. When they buy the business, they'll write the check for $4 billion. And then if -- they're going to run the business. And if the business does well, and we made a lot of investments in that business and you could see it's been progressing a comeback in the business as well, and down the road, if things do really well and they have a chance to sell the business or take it public or whatever they do with it, and there's an upside from there with their returns, then we have a chance to get a little bit more money down the road too ourselves. But up front, today, the day they take this company, they're going to pay us $4 billion cash, right up front. So we get the money. And typically, we'll work the cash balances around the world. As you said, there are cash around the world. And we will leave what we consider adequate cash for business, but the rest of that cash belongs to Emerson and our shareholders.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one last question that's just on, I guess, kind of the cultural direction here. I mean you guys walked through the website on a conference call which we've kind of never really seen that before. So obviously, you're trying to put a foo
componenttext: Okay. And then just one last question that's just on, I guess, kind of the cultural direction here. I mean you guys walked through the website on a conference call which we've kind of never really seen that before. So obviously, you're trying to put a foot forward when it comes down to the transformation of the company. GE's got these commercials out there, even though it's like, literally, 2% of sales for them. I'm just wondering like how -- is there like something going on in the industrial world where there's -- is this kind of an internally driven thing? Or is there some consultants running around with -- are you trying to pitch this story? Just seems like everybody is talking about IOT at the same time, and to varying degrees, what is your percentage of sales? Because I think you guys have a decent amount in software, better than the other guys, but I haven't seen it reflected.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have a lot there. We're not buzzing IOT. In reality, there's no consultant running around. I've got Kathy, and she's got a little minion here. And she's right here next to her. It's a dynamic duo team here. Steve, there’s no consultant, so I thi
componenttext: Yes. We have a lot there. We're not buzzing IOT. In reality, there's no consultant running around. I've got Kathy, and she's got a little minion here. And she's right here next to her. It's a dynamic duo team here. Steve, there’s no consultant, so I think that, that why we did this today is very important. This webcast is listened to by a lot of our employees, too. And one of the key issues from our perspective right now, we're communicating to you, we're communicating to our customers and internally. And what's going on right now, our customers are looking for what are we going to look like, how is this thing look like going forward when we come out in October. So I asked Kathy to come in and to talk about it. There's no buzzwords here. I mean we're very much into Internet of Things and we've been involved in this for a long time going back to the initial Internet thing called PlantWeb, which I used to present when I was running the process business. So I think that it's just people like to talk about it and we felt it very important for you to understand, and for our investors to understand, and then also for our employees to understand, where we're trying to take this in the next 2 to 3 months as we unfold this transaction.

componenttext: Not at this time. Our consideration is invest in growing the business again and not liquidating the business. So investment profile of the board is such that we feel that we have opportunities out there, and we'll continue to have the opportunities out there in the next couple of years. And we've gone through a whole process to say, where do we want to focus? And so our focus is in these 2 areas there, and we're going to look to go out and buy assets and leverage those 2 businesses, which are 2 very strong global, profitable businesses, and that's what we're going to do. I'm not in the mode of buying stock back and taking the company private.

I want to thank everybody. We're wrapped up here. Again, I want to thank the organization around the world, in particular around the Network Power team, Leroy-Somer CT team and work working with the Platinum folks and Network Power and Nidec on the Leroy-Somer CT. headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] The conference is being recorded today, November 1, 2016. Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain fo
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] The conference is being recorded today, November 1, 2016. Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain forward-looking statements, including the company's outlook for the remainder of the year. Information on factors that could cause actual effects to vary materially from those discussed today is available at Emerson's most recent annual report on Form 10-K, as filed with SEC. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Craig Rossman, Director of Investor Relations at Emerson. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, William. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; and Frank Dellaquila, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Today's call will summarize Emerson's fourth quarter and fiscal year 2016 re
componenttext:
Thank you, William. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; and Frank Dellaquila, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Today's call will summarize Emerson's fourth quarter and fiscal year 2016 results. A conference call slide presentation will accompany my comments and is available on Emerson's website. A replay of this conference call and slide presentation will be available on the website for the next 90 days. 
In the fourth quarter, results for the Network Power, Leroy-Somer and Control Techniques businesses were reported in discontinued operations. Considering this and to aid in comparisons to prior quarters, we provided results both on a continuing operations basis and on an adjusted basis, which include these discontinued operations and exclude such items such as separation costs for consistency. A further explanation of the reporting formats can be found on Slide 2. Detailed bridges can also be found in the appendix to this presentation. 
Please turn to Slide 3 for a summary of the fiscal year results. Fiscal year sales of $20.2 billion decreased 9% versus the prior year with underlying sales down 6%. The fiscal year results reflected a more challenging economic environment than we expected as we entered the year as the company has faced difficult conditions in its key served markets for 7 consecutive quarters. Within our industrial businesses, the most significant factors have been the impact of -- on energy-related customer spending from persistently low oil and gas prices as well as weak general industrial and emerging market spending. Across our other businesses, we did find bright spots related to generally more favorable market conditions in U.S. construction, data center spending, particularly cloud-based and co-location customers, telecommunications infrastructure and global air conditioning and refrigeration. 
Adjusted earnings per share decreased 6% to $2.98. As a result of the continuation of difficult market conditions, restructuring spending totaled $112 million for the fiscal year, exceeding our previous guidance of $90 million to $100 million. The completion of the actions also positions us for what we expect to be a challenging 2017. 
Finally, solid earnings conversion and improved trade working capital performance resulted in strong operating work -- operating cash flow generation of $2.9 billion or $3.1 billion, which was 15.1% of sales, excluding $179 million of separation costs. 
Turning to Slide 4. Net sales of $5.5 billion were down 6% with underlying sales down 5% in the quarter. Served market conditions in the fourth quarter remained generally consistent to previous quarters with weak oil and gas and general-industrial spending outweighing favorable data center, telecommunications, air conditioning and refrigeration spend. Adjusted earnings per share of $0.96 increased 3%. For the quarter, working capital improvement drove operating cash flow generation of $957 million. 
Turning to Slide 5. Favorable materials cost containment, restructuring benefits and solid operational execution led to gross profit of 41.7%, which was up 100 basis points, and EBIT margin of 16.8%, up 60 basis points versus the prior year. 
Turning to Slide 6. The continuation of a low growth environment led to underlying sales decreases in all geographies for the fiscal year. Fourth quarter underlying sales were generally representative of the full year, but improved in some regions, such as Asia, China and the United States. 
Turning to Slide 7. Total segment margin was up 140 basis points to 17.1%, primarily driven by benefits from restructuring actions and operational execution. Capital spending was held to $169 million, equal to the prior year. 
Turning to Slide 8. Process Management sales decreased 11% as spending levels in energy-related markets remain low for both capital and operational expenditures, while power and life sciences customers continue to provide growth opportunities. Restructuring spending in the quarter was $54 million, slightly above the prior year. Segment margin decreased 280 basis points primarily due to volume deleverage, partially offset by savings from restructuring actions. The automation businesses will remain under pressure through the majority of fiscal 2017, with the possibility of orders recovery in the second half, assuming stability in oil and gas prices. 
Turning to Slide 9. Industrial Automation sales decreased 7%, resulting from a continuation of low levels of spending in upstream oil and gas and weak but slightly improving conditions in general-industrial markets. Segment margin increased 190 basis points to 16.3%, primarily due to business mix, benefits from restructuring actions and lower restructuring spend in the quarter. The divestitures of the Leroy-Somer and Control Techniques businesses remain on track to close by the end of the calendar year. Looking ahead to 2017, general industrial markets will remain challenging with slightly improving conditions as the year progresses. 
Turning to Slide 10. Network Power underlying sales were flat in the quarter, supported by favorable demand in power products, thermal management and service. Strong growth in North America was led by cloud-based and co-location data center customers as well as telecommunication spending by mobile and broadband providers. Segment margin improved 650 basis points to 13.1%, benefiting from favorable mix, savings from restructuring actions and gross profit improvement programs. The Network Power divestiture also remains on track for completion by the end of the calendar year. 
Turning to Slide 11. Climate Technologies sales increased 6%, driven by strong growth in U.S. residential and commercial air conditioning as well as refrigeration and residential air conditioning markets in China. Segment margin increased 320 basis points to 21.1%, primarily due to volume leverage, savings from restructuring actions and material cost containment, partially offset by lower pricing. The 2017 outlook for global demand in air conditioning and refrigeration markets supports our expectation for low single-digit growth for our Climate businesses. 
Turning to Slide 12. Commercial & Residential Solutions underlying sales were equal to the prior year as growth in food waste disposers and wet/dry vacuums offset declines in other businesses. Segment margin improved 370 basis points to 25.9% from the benefits of restructuring actions and the impact of the InterMetro divestiture. Favorable conditions in U.S. construction markets are expected to support our outlook for low single-digit growth in fiscal 2017. 
Turning to Slide 13. Fiscal year 2016 was a more difficult -- was more difficult than we had expected, impacted by a significant and unprecedentedly long global industrial downturn that we expect to continue into 2017. Our automation business will remain under pressure from these market headwinds, while our commercial businesses will benefit from favorable conditions in global air conditioning and refrigeration and from construction markets in the United States and Asia. Considering these factors, we provide the following guidance for fiscal year 2017.: net and underlying sales will be down 1% to 3% with the Automation Solutions platform down 4% to 7% and the Commercial & Residential Solutions platform up 2% to 4%. The Automation Solutions platform will be comprised of our current Process Management segment and the remaining businesses from the Industrial Automation segment, while the Commercial & Residential Solutions platform will be comprised of the businesses within our current Climate Technology and Commercial & Residential Solutions segment. Earnings per share are expected to be in a range of $2.35 to $2.50, which compares to earnings per share on a continuing basis and including divestiture gains of $2.45 in 2016 and $2.81 in 2015. The 2017 EPS guidance also includes any impact from the pending acquisition of Pentair Valves & Controls business. 
And now I'll turn it over to Mr. David Farr.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Craig. And in case you guys don't realize, Craig is rooting for the Cleveland Indians tonight to win and take the World Series. So he's not totally paying attention right now. He's focused on the Cleveland Indians. I want to thank eve
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Craig. And in case you guys don't realize, Craig is rooting for the Cleveland Indians tonight to win and take the World Series. So he's not totally paying attention right now. He's focused on the Cleveland Indians. I want to thank everybody for joining us today. Again, it's a good way to finish a very challenging global industrial world. It was not easier, but a very challenging year nonetheless. And I think we continue to execute [indiscernible] are positioned in the right condition for better growth in the future. I want to thank all the employees, the corporate leaders, the team members who support our effort this year. I mean we got a lot done in a very tough global business environment, which has been challenging for us for the last 2 years. And with a good finish on the fiscal '16 and the fourth quarter, even though sales were down, margins were close to record levels from last year. We had strong cash flow, a good conversion. In the quarter, we also announced the sale -- cash sales for Network Power, cash sale for Leroy-Somer CT, generating over $5.2 million -- billion [ph] of cash and an agreement to purchase the Pentair Valves & Controls business for $3.15 billion. As Craig mentioned, most likely, we'll get the divestitures done by the end of this quarter. We clearly are driving -- trying to get the Valves & Controls business closed by the end of this quarter. We still have to get global government approvals on that acquisition, and we're moving forward with that. That acquisition is uniquely strategic to us relative to our end markets. Our solutions package and our ability to really integrate that and fit it well within our broad global customer offering. And so we're very excited about the opportunity there to generate future growth, earnings and cash flow. 
We executed for the second year on restructuring. Restructuring number was down from the prior year because we had very high levels of restructuring in fiscal 2015, but still over $100 million of restructuring throughout the year in 2016, and the savings are flowing through. We nearly maintained a 17% [ph] operating profit this year despite sales being down 9%, which is quite a major task given the big dropoff that we saw in the Automation Solutions business. We had strong cash flow again this year, better than last year when you take out the cost of doing the repositioning. Excellent conversion. So we're exiting the year with 2 strategic divestitures, 1 unique strategic acquisition, strong balance sheet, good cash position. And we have a very good vision, where we see things unfolding here for the next 12 months. 
You now have the new GAAP P&L and balance sheet for Emerson. I'm sure you'll have a lot of questions about it. We will supply 5 years of history in the end report. We'll also give you a very good 2014, too, and I think, 3-year details, and give you a chance to start to understand the new Emerson. Also, we'll start giving out the sales and orders relative to our platform, the 2 platforms, the Automation Solutions and then also the Commercial & Residential Solutions. 
So we'll start giving some information. Craig has the information. Start feeding it out to you, and we'll get more to you as we go forward here in the 10-K. And then also we will give more as we report our first quarter in fiscal '17. We made a decision to give you a little bit more insight to what we see for next year, given what the new company is structured with the new P&L looks like, the new balance sheet looks like. Right now, we see underlying sales down 1% to 3%, with Automation Solutions being still in a challenging mode, down 4% to 7%, which will be third year in a row Automation Solutions is down. Our Commercial & Residential business has turned the corner and has grown, and we expect that will continue to grow 2% to 4% next year. Both will deliver solid margins. Operating margins in both will be better. Restructuring around the Automation Solutions will continue, but at a little lower level, excluding our integration of Pentair Valves & Controls. Some minor restructuring going on underneath the Commercial & Residential Solutions, but primarily we're making significant investment solutions in the infrastructure to create best cost locations, to create a more efficient structure within the new Commercial & Residential underneath Bob Sharp and Jim Lindemann. A lot of integration work going on there. And then eventually, when we get clearance from the governments, we'll get integration work with Pentair Valves & Controls. We're ready to go. We already have our day 1 through 6 months plans ready to implement and working very, very hard on. So a lot underway relative to our execution around this acquisition. So we feel good about how we finish the year, feel good about how we're going in to our position relative to our repositioning effort. 
With EPS, it's all about how do we maintain -- or have a slight increase in EPS next year. We gave you the range of $2.35 to $2.50, but we're very much focused and we delivered some moderate, low single -- [indiscernible] single growth -- and the next -- underlying sales and execute better margins and deliver a little better earnings per share. We're very much focused on running this business now that we have the repositioning effort under way. 
It's been a tough market. There's not a lot of growth out there. It's a challenging market, but we know where we have to go. We've got -- from our perspective, from the management team, we downsized around the world both in the operating units and also the core -- corporate units. We have a very solid team ready to execute around our plan for 2017 and 2018 and beyond. 
Restructuring, our cost position is pretty good shape right now. There's always more restructuring to do, but we've got the majority of the big heavy-lifting behind us when you exclude the Pentair Valves & Controls, but we've really got our position from our perspective in good shape. 
We're very much focused on trying to again bring in some additional acquisitions in 2017. We will end -- from the 2 pre-positioning and acquisition, we'll end up with over $4.5 billion of cash, position in the right place to invest, and so we'll continue to look on at the small bolt-on strategic-type acquisitions rebuild our base, as we talked about back to $20 billion within this 5-year time period, getting our operating cash flow back to over $3.2 billion, which allow us to drive modest increase in dividends and get that free cash flow to dividend payout ratio back under 50%. [ph] We've showed that plan. We did that in Morgan Stanley conference a couple of weeks ago -- a couple of months ago. We are on course to make sure we execute around that vision. So that's what we're all about. 
I want to thank the organization for the work they've done the last 12 months. We have changed a lot in Emerson the last 12 months, from the change in the businesses, from the restructuring, to delivering very solid earnings and cash in a very challenging year, to improving our cost structure, to making a bigger acquisition, hopefully, we'll get finalized at the end of this calendar year and then going forward, in the new company, yes, it's a smaller company. It's a very profitable company, but a company that's well positioned, I think, to grow and recover as a global investment start happening again. So I like where we are right now. We had a good session with the board today, talking about how we wrapped up the year, where we're going to go forward. But I think we're really good shape. We have a very, very difficult first quarter. We had a very good first quarter last year. The Automation Solutions business is looking at probably down 10% sales in the first quarter. If you remember -- if you've been watching this -- the orders for last several -- in 6 or 8 months, the orders have been down around the 10%, 12%, 13% range. They've got to get through that. And so we have a very difficult first quarter from Automation Solutions. And we know that, and we're built for that. We'll try to get some restructuring done. But that's the facts at this point in time. That's built into our forecast, and the year will get better as we go forward. But clearly, it's -- we've got to get through the next 2 or 3 months here, finish that divestitures, make acquisitions and move forward with the new company. So with that, I'll open up the door and the windows in the phone lines and let people talk. Ask any questions you want. No one gave me the questions ahead of time. I tried to call CNN, but unfortunately, they didn't return my phone call. So I don't have the questions ahead of time. And Craig will still focus on reading to them box score from the baseball game, which they lost Internet, that they didn't give me any questions here. So with that, we'll open up the phone lines and take questions. Thank you.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: So built into the plan next year is about $100 million -- this year, I should say. Although pre-savings, a lot of that is carryover of actions already taken. And we've got, as Dave said, about $50 million [ph] of new spend in the plan. And given the timing and the nature of the actions, we'll see if that happens to flow through the year.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the key here, Julian, is Automation Solutions. Clearly, right now, as you look at -- in the early stage of October, they did -- they were slightly better on orders in October. Automation Solutions were pretty much in line to what they were last month
componenttext: Yes, the key here, Julian, is Automation Solutions. Clearly, right now, as you look at -- in the early stage of October, they did -- they were slightly better on orders in October. Automation Solutions were pretty much in line to what they were last month at that we put out there. I mean -- I'm sorry, commercial and residential solutions -- I apologize. Right now, we're not seeing -- we're saying late third quarter, we'll start seeing a positive Automation Solutions. And so we'll start bottoming up and coming out of the new calendar year. That will be the key issue to watch. And from our perspective right now, we -- we're hoping to have -- obviously positive Automation Solutions orders by that number above the line, by the time [indiscernible] this year. And that's where the bet is right now. And that's how we see everything laying out basically from our customers in our initial reactions. So that $15 billion collection right there is that, was that number turned up right now we say it's going to start getting better in early calendar year of 2017, but we will not go positive until late on the Automation Solutions standpoint until late '17. That's rate is.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is that true of the sort of the MRO piece within process?
componenttext: Is that true of the sort of the MRO piece within process?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. MRO's got to lead us up. I mean small projects what we'd call brownfield projects, the additions into our current facility, they will come, but that will come later. We've got to start seeing some turnaround. We're starting to see some early indicati
componenttext: Yes. MRO's got to lead us up. I mean small projects what we'd call brownfield projects, the additions into our current facility, they will come, but that will come later. We've got to start seeing some turnaround. We're starting to see some early indication right now some of the international markets. The market we have not seen stabilize right now is North America. And so that's the marketplace that we have to see, that stability, and we have to see them starting to spend some MRO in this North America market. And how long can they keep deferring that? I think we will not get clarity until that first calendar quarter from our major investors as they fish out their fiscal year, as they see the cost structure. So that's why I think the first fiscal quarter, which is the fourth calendar quarter, will be very, very difficult because I think our customer base will be tight, tight, tight with cash and be concerned. So that's where I see it right now, Julian.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Our next questioner today is Andrew Kaplowitz with Citigroup.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so China. I mean it looks like it turned a bit for you in the quarter, especially in the climate markets. Could you see an end to inventory destocking in climate? Or conditions to simply get better? And what do you think for 2017 in China?
componenttext: Well, so China. I mean it looks like it turned a bit for you in the quarter, especially in the climate markets. Could you see an end to inventory destocking in climate? Or conditions to simply get better? And what do you think for 2017 in China?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: There is not one simple -- I mean, China is a big country -- big market. Clearly, what we see right now are some of the investments around the environment, some of the investments around energy efficiency. We're seeing the Climate Technology investment or
componenttext: There is not one simple -- I mean, China is a big country -- big market. Clearly, what we see right now are some of the investments around the environment, some of the investments around energy efficiency. We're seeing the Climate Technology investment or the [indiscernible] -- no, I mean Commercial & Residential Solutions, those markets are picking back up for us. They've continued here early on in this fiscal quarter -- first quarter. So we see that market turn. Now obviously, after being down roll negative for a while, you get a nice bounce. And that's where we are right now. So we're expecting moderate growth in China in our Commercial & Residential Solutions business for 2017. Our orders in Automation Solutions have stabilized in China. Again, you keep in mind the markets we serve in China, not necessary in the big down -- oil and gas -- new fields and things like that. We're looking at the efficiency. We're looking at power plants. We're looking at programs to help incremental capacity and save energy and things like that. Those markets are starting to -- are actually starting to solidify in China. So we are cautiously optimistic about China, that we will see low single-digit positive growth in 2017. Now answer that question, if ever, I might give a different answer. But right now, that's what we're seeing based on our indication of orders in the last couple of months in our customers. So I feel good about that better market a feel good about will be Europe. If you look at the new Emerson, the Automation Solutions and commercial and residential, our European -- Europe grew last year, and I think will grow again this year. Those are the 2 positive markets. And then it gets real short after that.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful, Dave. So look, you've obviously done a lot of restructuring in the last couple of years. You've done a great job of holding margin, as you said. At some point, as you know, you started cutting into the bone a bit. How much more low-h
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful, Dave. So look, you've obviously done a lot of restructuring in the last couple of years. You've done a great job of holding margin, as you said. At some point, as you know, you started cutting into the bone a bit. How much more low-hanging fruit do you have if these markets don't improve? How much more can you hold margin? I mean, you've got that again for '17 got the climbing [ph] sales and new [indiscernible] hold margin again? Can you talk about that, Dave?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can talk about that. The key issue -- let's talk -- break it down in 2 pieces, and then I'll give you total perspective from a CEO industry perspective, okay? On the Commercial & Residential Solutions, Bob Sharp and Jim Lindemann laid out a plan. T
componenttext: Yes, I can talk about that. The key issue -- let's talk -- break it down in 2 pieces, and then I'll give you total perspective from a CEO industry perspective, okay? On the Commercial & Residential Solutions, Bob Sharp and Jim Lindemann laid out a plan. They're integrating these businesses today, and we see some opportunities in between the creases, let's say, to improve plant efficiency, plant cost, distribution, things like that. So we see the ability to bid -- to point out a cost structure, improve the profitability by a point over the next couple of years, get some working capital out, take some of that money, invest it, try to get to grow that business, but also that some of that money through -- flow through. So there, we're looking at like emerging -- putting the pieces together, some efficiencies that we have today by separate business by putting together. But once that's done, it's got -- we've got to grow because the cost structure would be very, very, very good. From an Automation Solutions standpoint, we probably have $40 million, $50 million of the core company left. And then you got some very, very difficult issues there. From -- you start going after things you don't want to go after to jeopardize the future, technology innovation and the value base of this company. The acquisition of Pentair Valves & Controls gives us a chance to do -- to go after even more. And that's why we're going to be looking at $50 million to $75 million in the first year, depending on when we get this done on the restructuring. And there's potentially -- we'll do even more than that in the next 2 years. So the acquisition of Pentair Valves & Controls gives us a chance to refresh opportunities for us to integrate again a much larger business. You take the $7 billion Automation Solutions business today. You add $1.6 billion in there to get -- to do things. Now if the economy doesn't grow and we continue struggle for growth, hence, you're going to see -- acquisitions. That's seeing acquisitions. U.S. companies have been going through a lot of restructuring, taking costs out. We're running at levels at pretty high levels of profitability for the level of sales we have. And hence, that's why you're seeing acquisitions. That's why you're going to see that continue, I think, in the short term, unless there's some kind of growth in '17, which I don't see at this point in time. So if this thing keeps going and get sloppy, then we're going to have to add to our acquisition pool. And that's why we're going to be looking at an additional $3 billion to $4 billion of acquisitions over the next 2 or 3 years to continue to feed our chance to reposition, restructure and drive top line growth through acquisitions that is the core economic growth, we do not see coming through for the next couple of years. That's what this CEO sees from a cost perspective and growth perspective.

componenttext: So Automation Solutions is down 4% to 7%. Obviously, how do we think about the legacy sort of Industrial Automation [indiscernible] flat this quarter? We got some components of that segment performing very well. Process, I'm assuming will below the 4% to 7%. So how do we think about the various moving pieces within that portfolio? And then Valves & Controls, obviously comes [indiscernible] acquisition line, but is it kind of down 4% to 7% the same for that portfolio? Or is that a bit later cycle?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. That's -- Nigel, think about the chart that we showed you -- I gave you when we did the valves -- Pentair Valves & Controls chart, with the $260 billion market. We broke it out in 3 pieces. You had the process, the hybrid [indiscernible] discrete. You
componenttext: No. That's -- Nigel, think about the chart that we showed you -- I gave you when we did the valves -- Pentair Valves & Controls chart, with the $260 billion market. We broke it out in 3 pieces. You had the process, the hybrid [indiscernible] discrete. You think about -- you know the chart? I get -- we handed out. The process side will be worse than negative 4% to 7%, and the hybrid/discrete business base will be flat growth next year. And therefore, that's how we get the 4% to 7% combined, okay? We're looking at the marketplace at $206 billion [ph] marketplace that we showed you. We did a Valves & Controls acquisition. The process piece will be down more than 4% to 7%, and the other hybrid piece will be flat or slightly up, maybe 1%, plus or minus 0 -- plus or minus 1%. And that's why the process business will be a little bit more negative than we said the 4% to 7%, to your point.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the Pentair portfolio, does that come in at a similar kind of organic decline as the Emerson process business? Or...
componenttext: Okay. And then the Pentair portfolio, does that come in at a similar kind of organic decline as the Emerson process business? Or...

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think as you -- as I said when we did the acquisition, look at it of more pessimistic view with that this is going to look like for the next 12 to 18 months. One, the order pace is not been very good. Secondly, there's going to be a lot of disruption in
componenttext: I think as you -- as I said when we did the acquisition, look at it of more pessimistic view with that this is going to look like for the next 12 to 18 months. One, the order pace is not been very good. Secondly, there's going to be a lot of disruption integration more going on. I think that will negative this business -- negatively impact of business for the 12 to 18 months. Once it comes on board, it will be the same growth rates at the overall process business, but I think the next -- I think as you look at '17 and '18, I think they're going to be a little bit less than the underlying, what we call, process automation business. It's -- and we're going to be creating that problem ourselves, probably.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a quick one, Dave. The comments on acquisitions are honestly very interesting. You made it very, very clear that you've done with the portfolio disposal. You've got one more coming up. But looking at the markets, there's a fair amount of consolid
componenttext: And then a quick one, Dave. The comments on acquisitions are honestly very interesting. You made it very, very clear that you've done with the portfolio disposal. You've got one more coming up. componenttext: No. I think that -- within our tool business space right now, there's some good leverage across some of the other core automation and solutions businesses. headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know me. I'll give you my interpretation. I'll give you what I feel, okay, Steve? I give you what I have at this point in time. I fundamentally believe right now we are -- about as close as we've been for a while relative to price cost pressures, seei
componenttext: You know me. I'll give you my interpretation. I'll give you what I feel, okay, Steve? I give you what I have at this point in time. I fundamentally believe right now we are -- about as close as we've been for a while relative to price cost pressures, seeing pricing, as you know, has been basically flat for us, I think, last year, last 2 years, basically slightly up, slightly down, 0.1, 0.2. Now we've been able to offset that with stronger net material inflation. I -- what I see coming into us right now, either this quarter or next quarter, is our price cost ratio pressures are going to build. And so we're factoring into higher cost reduction efforts within the company because I wouldn't be surprised if we do not go red for 1 or 2 quarters on our price cost ratios in 2017. I've told people at the Fed this same issue. There is inflation brewing relative to specific skill set. Material deflation is slowing down. It's not starting come up. And our pricing capability is not that strong right now because there's plenty of capacity out there. there's not a lot of demand. So the pressure is building on this whole price cost scenario. So what we're building in right now, in our plan is basically to stay neutral because I think if you let it run its course, we're going to be slightly red in our price cost situation. We have to increase our cost reductions. And it's going to be primarily around cost reduction. The productivity is tough. We're probably 1% or 2% next year in productivity. We're better than the U.S. economy, but there's not a lot of growth out there. So it's extremely hard to get a lot more productivity without some additional growth. So right now, we're having to ramp up our cost reductions around sort of discretionary things and keep the place kind of tight. So that's how I see unfolding next year. We're going to get -- we've got that savings that we've -- from the restructuring we did last year, earlier this year. But in order to hold our margins, improve our profitability next year, we're going to have to come up with more stronger discretionary cost savings because I think price cost will be working against us. That's my call. I'm sure you've not heard that from anybody, but that's my call.

componenttext: We've now have had the opportunity to talk to our customer base about this. I mean the most strategic opportunity for us is that we can get them into a lot bigger customers that they couldn't get into themselves. We can get them on to large projects which we win, which they never won because they don't have the control system or the whole package. We can now offer a much larger service package. We can service a whole host of our products for customers. So now we can be this sort of core service organization for them. So leverage across total portfolio. No people -- all they wanted was think about, "That's [indiscernible] it's a very now they can you guess oh yes, that's not that strategic, but what we're talking about this when we go to bid for projects, when we go out for the type of package as we get with a large -- our large global customer base, we now offer them a much larger solution both from an upfront and service and tie that technology together. So we see a lot more growth synergies from that leverage of our organization on a global basis than a person who only thinks about a valve company stand-alone operation. And I think, in 5 years, people will look back and say, "Hey, you did get a lot more growth than we thought you would". That's what I see right now.

componenttext: No, it's not. It's not incremental price pressure. Again, it relates to -- again, we talked about this before. Most of the OEMs are on some type of kind of contractual matrix-type pricing. So as commodities go up or, down. Pricing is adjusted. In this environment, when commodities are low, pricing is -- goes down to match that. There's a bit of a lag occasionally, but that's what the impact is.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do I need to like break my left leg, rip it off, or give it to you or something like that? Or my right leg? Or -- going back, seriously, I was being [indiscernible] people on the phone listening. I did not tell Rob to [indiscernible] buy stock [indiscerni
componenttext: Do I need to like break my left leg, rip it off, or give it to you or something like that? Or my right leg? Or -- going back, seriously, I was being [indiscernible] people on the phone listening. I did not tell Rob to [indiscernible] buy stock [indiscernible] All those people from the SEC have no sense of humor. So '17. There's 2 numbers you need to think about for '17. This is driven into our heads across the organization. $2.5 billion operating cash flow and $2 billion free cash flow. A number that's pretty tight to our modeling, and we're going to manage according -- as the organization is talking about it. And so if we can beat it, we can beat it. But that would put us at 62% [ph] of dividend to free cash flow cover, okay? Then as we move into '18 and '19, we're not assuming any big breakout or anything like that, but we're trying to get back into adding about $100 million of cash -- $150 million of operating cash flow per year. Now our plan is to continue to keep the dividend going up modestly, as I told the people, $0.02. We'll have share repurchase of around $500 million per year. That allows us to basically keep the dividend -- the actual payments flat to slightly down. And so we'll see, as we get into, right now, 2020, 2021, we'll be back down towards that 50% [ph] level. If we do not make any more acquisitions [indiscernible] that's what's going to happen. If we make any additional acquisition on top of Pentair, our game plan is to get that number back, our operating cash flow back up to $3.2 billion, spending around $600 million of capital. That get us back in the high 40s free cash flow to dividends from that perspective. So our model right now says that we'll continue to make acquisitions. We'll continue to integrate them, generate cash flows. We'll continue to buy stock back and continue to increase our dividend modestly. So that's what we're looking at right now, and our model looks at, do we do nothing other than Pentair that does that, we'll get closer to 50. If we do some additional deals, which we want to do, then we'll obviously get back under 50% [ph] in the next 5 years.

In the oil -- our customer base did a quick evaluation in the spring-summer about oh my God, how do I protect my capital structure, how do I protect all these things with a much lower oil price, so they cut capital much deeper than they said originally. That they had told us in January-February get the early indications from them. So that's what happened there. Now we go forward here. Now we're out here sitting in late in the year, and we're sitting here in the November time period, oil pricing and the gas prices have been stabilizing here for several months. And the trend line has been a little bit better. It does go up and down. They have now gone a year behind relative to their whole capital structure. Some of the big projects had to get done. They cut really heavily on the day-to-day spending. And I think you're going to see that stability in the pricing, if it stays that way, and within the range, then you'll see some more money go back into the capital -- day-to-day capital. And that's the difference.

componenttext: If you listen to me talk in the last couple of times, I said Europe is weaker. I always say Europe will grow. We grew this year. I think it'll grow less in 2017 than it did in 2016. That's -- but I've been telling -- openly been telling people, and then everyone heard me talk, been saying Europe is definitely weakened. Europe is definitely growing. The euro is weaker, so it's getting -- help our European operation. The euro went back down into 1 09 to 1 10, and it gets back up to 1 15, make it tougher, but it's definitely going to weaken. And I think the hoopla around Brexit is hoopla. And so I think it's -- from my perspective, Europe will grow next year, but it won't be as much growth as this year.

componenttext: I think based on what we're seeing in order patterns, based on our customer inputs, based on what we're seeing the last couple of months, and as I said earlier, I think China will grow low single-digit, from 0 to 2% -- 3% and that's where I see it right now. And if someone asked me the question a couple of calls back about, in February, what would make you feel better to your forecast, I think that China, Asia Pacific is the #2 thing I would say. After 1, 2 and 3 after Automation Solutions order, but China order pace and sales pace will be the #2 thing in that case.

componenttext: Incrementally, the biggest pockets is we've -- we're freeing up capital to go into the Commercial & Residential Solutions business relative to the whole efficiency thing I was talking about earlier, so we're basically have several new facilities being built in the best-cost locations. We're laying out some facilities. We're going to consolidate facilities. So of that core business, $50 million [ph] is going to go to discontinued operations business, around that number. And then we'll have $450 million going to the Emerson remaining businesses and a big chunk of that will be going into that work around, that Jim Lindemann Bob Sharp are doing relative to commercial and residential organization. The -- we also have some capacity going into our compressor business. And some best-cost locations and then the other big chunks -- there's nothing really big in Automation Solutions from the standpoint of, it's just restructuring. And the restructuring and you do plant moves and stuff like that, you have to spend capital. So that's where the big chunks are, Deane.

componenttext: The -- it really breaks down in different segments, but clearly, inventory is within, what I'd call, our sort of air conditioning book, the commercial and residential channel is pretty tight right now. They got a couple environmental things trends going their way right now. So hopefully, they make [indiscernible] for this quarter because we knows what's going to happen next quarter there. So that's where we are right now.

componenttext: Steve, I think that, for me, our business is really [indiscernible] some investment were really [indiscernible] We have some stuff that hasn't really get a drive sales. How much do I have left over?" That's how they're going to be calculating. And I think that those are the numbers I'm watching right now, and that stability is critical to me.
