headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Real question. Can we -- how tough will holding profitability in that sector in the fourth quarter level, given the declines that we're looking at? I mean, it's going to be a tale of 2 halves. First half, tough. And hopefully, you get -- build that
componenttext: Okay. Real question. Can we -- how tough will holding profitability in that sector in the fourth quarter level, given the declines that we're looking at? I mean, it's going to be a tale of 2 halves. First half, tough. And hopefully, you get -- build that in the second half. How tough is holding the profitability in the first half in Automation Solutions as we go through it?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Anything can happen. It's going to come down the first half. It's -- we -- restructuring, we got more restructuring. Mike Train got a lot more restructuring done in the last 3 or 4 months in Automation Solutions. As you know our restructuring number went
componenttext: Anything can happen. It's going to come down the first half. It's -- we -- restructuring, we got more restructuring. Mike Train got a lot more restructuring done in the last 3 or 4 months in Automation Solutions. As you know our restructuring number went up. But volumes is going to be down 10% in the first quarter. And Mike is a good business leader, but he ain't that -- he can't work miracles. So it's going to come down, and then we should start seeing that come back up as we move in the second quarter. So our -- we're all hands on deck in this first quarter right now because Automation Solutions got a very difficult -- the order patterns have been weak for a while, and we know the mix is not going to be good. So Bob's businesses are trying as hard as possible. But the Automation Solutions is going to be a tough number. So I think that's going to be the big issue for us. We're going to be definitely very weak in the first quarter in profitability, and we'll start coming back. Because the restructuring is getting done, and we just -- the volume is dropping so hard in this first quarter.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So -- but you should still be a double-digit team kind of number, I suspect.
componenttext: So -- but you should still be a double-digit team kind of number, I suspect.

componenttext:
I mean, it's not -- yes, it's still going to be -- it'll still be better than most people are making on Automation Solutions, but it's not an Emerson standard. And they've got the restructuring done, so the same things are flowing through. But it'll -- it's going to be definitely second half because of the way that sales will flow for that business anyway. 
And with that, we're going to wrap it up. I want to thank everybody. Appreciate the -- me punching at you a couple of jokes here and there. And I'm sorry, I picked on you too much, Rossman, but even so enamored with those Cleveland Indians, I haven't gotten a lot of Q&A out of you lately. 
So thank you, everybody. Take care. We'll see everybody around, and we'll definitely see everybody in February at our Investors Conference. Take care now. Bye.

componenttext: The conference has now concluded. Thank you all for attending today's presentation. You may now disconnect your lines.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] The conference is being recorded today, November 1, 2016. Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain fo
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to Emerson's investor conference call. [Operator Instructions] The conference is being recorded today, November 1, 2016. Emerson's commentary and responses to your questions may contain forward-looking statements, including the company's outlook for the remainder of the year. Information on factors that could cause actual effects to vary materially from those discussed today is available at Emerson's most recent annual report on Form 10-K, as filed with SEC. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Craig Rossman, Director of Investor Relations at Emerson. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, William. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; and Frank Dellaquila, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Today's call will summarize Emerson's fourth quarter and fiscal year 2016 re
componenttext:
Thank you, William. I'm joined today by David Farr, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Emerson; and Frank Dellaquila, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Today's call will summarize Emerson's fourth quarter and fiscal year 2016 results. A conference call slide presentation will accompany my comments and is available on Emerson's website. A replay of this conference call and slide presentation will be available on the website for the next 90 days. 
In the fourth quarter, results for the Network Power, Leroy-Somer and Control Techniques businesses were reported in discontinued operations. Considering this, and to aid in comparisons to prior quarters, we have provided results both on a continuing operations basis and on an adjusted basis, which includes these discontinued operations and excludes such items such as separation costs for consistency. A further explanation of the reporting formats can be found on Slide 2. Detailed bridges can also be found in the appendix to this presentation. 
Please turn to Slide 3 for a summary of the fiscal year result. Fiscal year sales of $20.2 billion decreased 9% versus the prior year, with underlying sales down 6%. The fiscal year results reflected a more challenging economic environment than we expected as we entered the year as the company has faced difficult conditions in its key served markets for 7 consecutive quarters. Within our industrial businesses, the most significant factors have been the impact of -- on energy-related customer spending from persistently low oil and gas prices as well as weak general industrial and emerging markets spending. Across our other businesses, we did find bright spots related to generally more favorable market conditions in: U.S. construction; data center spending, particularly cloud-based and co-location customers; telecommunications infrastructure; and global air conditioning and refrigeration. 
Adjusted earnings per share decreased 6% to $2.98. As a result of the continuation of difficult market conditions, restructuring spending totaled $112 million for the fiscal year, exceeding our previous guidance of $90 million to $100 million. The completion of the actions also positions us for what we expect to be a challenging 2017. 
Finally, solid earnings conversion and improved trade working capital performance resulted in strong operating work -- operating cash flow generation of $2.9 billion or $3.1 billion, which was 15.1% of sales, excluding $179 million of separation costs. 
Turning to Slide 4. Net sales of $5.5 billion were down 6%, with underlying sales down 5% in the quarter. Served market conditions in the fourth quarter remained generally consistent to previous quarters, with weak oil and gas and general industrial spending outweighing favorable data center, telecommunications, air conditioning and refrigeration spend. Adjusted earnings per share of $0.96 increased 3%. For the quarter, working capital improvement drove operating cash flow generation of $957 million. 
Turning to Slide 5. Favorable materials cost containment, restructuring benefits and solid operational execution led to gross profit of 41.7%, which was up 100 basis points, and EBIT margin of 16.8%, up 60 basis points versus the prior year. 
Turning to Slide 6. The continuation of a low-growth environment led to underlying sales decreases in all geographies for the fiscal year. Fourth quarter underlying sales were generally representative of the full year, but improved in some regions, such as Asia, China and the United States. 
Turning to Slide 7. Total segment margin was up 140 basis points to 17.1%, primarily driven by benefits from restructuring actions and operational execution. Capital spending was held to $169 million, equal to the prior year. 
Turning to Slide 8. Process Management sales decreased 11% as spending levels in energy-related markets remained low for both capital and operational expenditures, while power and life sciences customers continue to provide growth opportunities. Restructuring spending in the quarter was $54 million, slightly above the prior year. Segment margin decreased 280 basis points primarily due to volume deleverage, partially offset by savings from restructuring actions. The automation businesses will remain under pressure through the majority of fiscal 2017, with the possibility of orders recovery in the second half, assuming stability in oil and gas prices. 
Turning to Slide 9. Industrial Automation sales decreased 7%, resulting from a continuation of low levels of spending in upstream oil and gas and weak but slightly improving conditions in general industrial markets. Segment margin increased 190 basis points to 16.3%, primarily due to business mix, benefits from restructuring actions and lower restructuring spend in the quarter. The divestitures of the Leroy-Somer and Control Techniques businesses remain on track to close by the end of the calendar year. Looking ahead to 2017, general industrial markets will remain challenging, with slightly improving conditions as the year progresses. 
Turning to Slide 10. Network Power underlying sales were flat in the quarter, supported by favorable demand in power products, thermal management and service. Strong growth in North America was led by cloud-based and co-location data center customers as well as telecommunication spending by mobile and broadband providers. Segment margin improved 650 basis points to 13.1%, benefiting from favorable mix, savings from restructuring actions and gross profit improvement programs. The Network Power divestiture also remains on track for completion by the end of the calendar year. 
Turning to Slide 11. Climate Technologies sales increased 6%, driven by strong growth in U.S. residential and commercial air conditioning as well as refrigeration and residential air conditioning markets in China. Segment margin increased 320 basis points to 21.1%, primarily due to volume leverage, savings from restructuring actions and material cost containment, partially offset by lower pricing. The 2017 outlook for global demand in air conditioning and refrigeration markets supports our expectation for low single-digit growth for our Climate businesses. 
Turning to Slide 12. Commercial & Residential Solutions underlying sales were equal to the prior year as growth in food waste disposers and wet/dry vacuums offset declines in other businesses. Segment margin improved 370 basis points to 25.9% from the benefits of restructuring actions and the impact of the InterMetro divestiture. Favorable conditions in U.S. construction markets are expected to support our outlook for low single-digit growth in fiscal 2017. 
Turning to Slide 13. Fiscal year 2016 was a more difficult -- was more difficult than we had expected, impacted by a significant and unprecedentedly long global industrial downturn that we expect to continue into 2017. Our automation businesses will remain under pressure from these market headwinds, while our commercial businesses will benefit from favorable conditions in global air conditioning and refrigeration and from construction markets in the United States and Asia. Considering these factors, we provide the following guidance for fiscal year 2017. Net and underlying sales will be down 1% to 3%, with the Automation Solutions platform down 4% to 7% and the Commercial & Residential Solutions platform up 2% to 4%. The Automation Solutions platform will be comprised of our current Process Management segment and the remaining businesses from the Industrial Automation segment, while the Commercial & Residential Solutions platform will be comprised of the businesses within our current Climate Technology and Commercial & Residential Solutions segments. Earnings per share are expected to be in the range of $2.35 to $2.50, which compares to earnings per share on a continuing basis and including divestiture gains of $2.45 in 2016 and $2.81 in 2015. The 2017 EPS guidance also includes any impact from the pending acquisition of Pentair's Valves & Controls business. 
And now I'll turn it over to Mr. David Farr.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Craig. And in case you guys don't realize, Craig is rooting for the Cleveland Indians tonight to win and take the World Series. So he's not totally paying attention right now. He's focused on the Cleveland Indians. I want to thank e
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Craig. And in case you guys don't realize, Craig is rooting for the Cleveland Indians tonight to win and take the World Series. So he's not totally paying attention right now. He's focused on the Cleveland Indians. 
I want to thank everybody for joining us today to -- again, it's a good way to finish a very challenging global industrial world. It was not an easy year, but a very challenging year nonetheless. And I think we continue to execute and get our position in the right condition for better growth in the future. I want to thank all the employees, the corporate leaders, the OCE members for their support and their effort this year. I mean, we got a lot done in a very tough global business environment, which has been challenging for us for the last 2 years. And with a good finish on the fiscal '16 in the fourth quarter, even though sales were down, margins were close to record levels from last year. We had strong cash flow and good conversion. In the quarter, we also announced the sale -- cash sale for Network Power, cash sale for Leroy-Somer and CT, generating over $5.2 million -- $5.2 billion of cash and an agreement to purchase the Pentair Valves & Controls business for $3.15 billion. As Craig mentioned, most likely, we'll get the divestitures done by the end of this quarter. We clearly are driving, trying to get the Valves & Controls business closed by the end of this quarter. We still have to get global government approvals on that acquisition, and we're moving forward with that. That acquisition is uniquely strategic to us relative to our end markets, our solutions package and our ability to really integrate that and fit it well within our broad global customer offering. And so we're very excited about the opportunity there to generate future growth, earnings and cash flow. 
We executed for the second year on restructuring. The restructuring number was down from the prior year because we had very high levels of restructuring in fiscal 2015, but still over $100 million of restructuring throughout the year in 2016, and the savings are flowing through. We nearly maintained a 17% operating profit this year despite sales being down 9%, which is quite a major task given the big drop-off that we saw in the Automation Solutions business. We had strong cash flow again this year, better than last year when you take out the cost of doing the repositioning. Excellent conversion. So we're exiting the year with 2 strategic divestitures, 1 unique strategic acquisition, strong balance sheet, good cash position. And we have a very good vision, where we see things unfolding here for the next 12 months. 
You now have the new GAAP P&L and balance sheet for Emerson. I'm sure you'll have a lot of questions about it. We will supply 5 years of history in the end report. We'll also give you a very good 2014, too, and I think -- and 3-year details, and give you a chance to start to understand the new Emerson. Also, we'll start giving out the sales and orders relative to our platform, the 2 platforms, the Automation Solutions and then also the Commercial & Residential Solutions. 
So we'll start giving some information. Craig had the information. I'll start feeding it out to you, and we'll give more to you as we go forward here in the 10-K. And then also, we'll give more as we report our first quarter in fiscal '17. 
We made a decision to give you a little bit more insight into what we see for next year, given what the new company is structured, what the new P&L looks like, what the new balance sheet looks like. Right now, we see underlying sales down 1% to 3%, with Automation Solutions being still in a challenging mode, down 4% to 7%, which will be the third year in a row the Automation Solutions is down. Our Commercial & Residential business has turned the corner and has grown, and we expect that will continue to grow 2% to 4% next year. Both will deliver solid margins. Operating margins in both will be better. Restructuring around the Automation Solutions will continue, but at a little lower level, excluding our integration of Pentair Valves & Controls. Some minor restructuring going on underneath the Commercial & Residential Solutions, but primarily we're making significant increased investments in the infrastructure to create best cost locations, to create a more efficient structure within the new Commercial & Residential underneath Bob Sharp and Jim Lindemann. A lot of integration work going on there. And then eventually, when we get clearance from the governments, we'll get integration work under Pentair Valves & Controls. We're ready to go. We already have our day 1 through 6-month plans ready to implement and working very, very hard on. So a lot under way relative to our execution around this acquisition. So we feel good about how we finished the year, feel good about how we're going in to our position relative to our repositioning effort. 
With EPS, it's all about how do we maintain or have a slight increase in EPS next year. We gave you the range of $2.35 to $2.50, but we're very much focused, can we deliver some moderate, low single -- negative single growth -- in earning -- underlying sales and execute better margins and deliver a little bit better earnings per share. We're very much focused on running this business now that we have the repositioning effort under way. 
It's been a tough market. There's not a lot of growth out there. It's a challenging market, but we know where we have to go. We've got -- from our perspective, from the management team, we downsized around the world, both in the operating units and also the core corporate units. We have a very solid team really to execute around our plan for 2017 and 2018 and beyond. 
Restructuring, our cost position is pretty good shape right now. There's always more restructuring to do, but we've got the majority of the big heavy lifting behind us when you exclude the Pentair Valves & Controls. But we've really got our position from our perspective in good shape. 
We're very much focused on trying to, again, bring in some additional acquisitions in 2017. We will end -- from the 2 pre-positioning [ph] and acquisition, we'll end up with over $4.5 billion of cash, positioned in the right place to invest and so we'll continue to look on at the small bolt-on strategic-type acquisitions to rebuild our base, as we've talked about, back to $20 billion within this 5-year time period; getting our operating cash flow back to over $3.2 billion, which allow us to drive modest increase in dividends and get that free cash flow to dividend payout ratio back under 50%. We've showed that plan. We did that in the Morgan Stanley conference a couple of weeks ago -- a couple of months ago. We are on course to make sure we execute around that vision. So that's what we're all about. 
I want to thank the organization for the work they've done in the last 12 months. We have changed a lot in Emerson in the last 12 months, from the change in the businesses, from the restructuring to delivering very solid earnings and cash in a very challenging year, to improving our cost structure, to making a big acquisition, and hopefully, we'll get finalized at the end of this calendar year. And then moving forward in a new company, yes, it's a smaller company. It's a very profitable company, but a company that's well positioned, I think, to grow and recover as global investments start happening again. So I like where we are right now. We had a good session with the board today, talking about how we wrapped up the year and where we're going to go forward. But I think we're in really good shape. We have a very, very difficult first quarter. We had a very good first quarter last year. The Automation Solutions business is looking at probably down 10% sales in the first quarter. If you remember -- if you've been watching this -- their orders -- for the last several 6 or 8 months, their orders have been down around the 10%, 12%, 13% range. They've got to get through that. And so we have a very difficult first quarter from Automation Solutions. And we know that, and we're built for that. We'll try to get some more restructuring done. But that's the facts at this point in time. That's built into our forecast, and the year will get better as we go forward. 
But clearly, it's -- we've got to get through the next 2 or 3 months here, finish the divestitures, make the acquisition and then move forward with the new company. 
So with that, I'll open up the door and the windows and the phone lines and let people talk. Ask any questions you want. No one gave me the questions ahead of time. I tried to call CNN but, unfortunately, they didn't return my phone call. So I don't have the questions ahead of time. And Craig was so focused on reading the damn box score from the baseball game, which they lost the other night, that he didn't give me any questions either. So with that, we'll open up the phone lines and take questions. Thank you.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: It's going to be -- on an incremental savings standpoint, I mean, the numbers we laid out -- and we have those, we laid them out -- sorry, let me have to give you the numbers, Julian. We'll give you the numbers before we get off this call here. But we laid out, again, exact numbers of restructuring saves. On the restructuring number that -- we're going to spend around $50 million in the core company and somewhere between $50 million to $70 million once we start getting the Valves & Controls business. And we need to get approval on integrated. So go ahead, Frank. You go ahead and tell.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So built into the plan next year is about $100 million -- this year, I should say. Although pre-savings, a lot of that is carryover from actions already taken. And we've got, as Dave said, about $50 million of new spend in the plan. And given the timing a
componenttext: So built into the plan next year is about $100 million -- this year, I should say. Although pre-savings, a lot of that is carryover from actions already taken. And we've got, as Dave said, about $50 million of new spend in the plan. And given the timing and the nature of the actions, we'll see about half of that flow through in the year.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just on the top line. So your continuing sales organic guidance is a decline of about 2% at the midpoint. The orders on a continuing basis are falling in September about 8% to 9% organically. So maybe just give us some help around when you
componenttext: Great. And then just on the top line. So your continuing sales organic guidance is a decline of about 2% at the midpoint. The orders on a continuing basis are falling in September about 8% to 9% organically. So maybe just give us some help around when you think those orders may level out and particularly in that Process automation piece.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the key here, Julian, is Automation Solutions. I mean, clearly, right now, as we look at early stage of October, they did -- they were slightly better in orders in October. Automation Solutions were pretty much in line to what they were last month th
componenttext: Yes, the key here, Julian, is Automation Solutions. I mean, clearly, right now, as we look at early stage of October, they did -- they were slightly better in orders in October. Automation Solutions were pretty much in line to what they were last month that we put out there. I mean -- I'm sorry, Commercial & Residential Solutions, I apologize. Right now, we're not saying -- we're saying late third quarter, we'll start seeing positive Automation Solutions. And so they'll start bottoming out and coming up in the new calendar year. That will be the key issue to watch. And I mean, from our perspective right now, we -- we're hoping to have, obviously, positive Automation Solutions orders by that number above the line, by the time we get out of this year. And that's where the bet is here right now. That's how we see everything laying out, basically, from our customers and our initial reactions. So that $15 billion collection right there is at -- where does that number turn up? Right now we're saying it's going to start getting better in the early calendar year of 2017, but we will not go positive until late -- on the Automation Solutions standpoint until late '17. That's where it is.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is that true of the sort of the MRO piece within Process?
componenttext: And is that true of the sort of the MRO piece within Process?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. MRO's got to lead us up. I mean, small projects, what we'd call brownfield projects, these additions into a current facility, they will come, but that will come later. We've got to start seeing some turnaround. We're starting to see some early indica
componenttext: Yes. MRO's got to lead us up. I mean, small projects, what we'd call brownfield projects, these additions into a current facility, they will come, but that will come later. We've got to start seeing some turnaround. We're starting to see some early indication right now in some of the international markets. The market we have not seen stabilize right now is North America. And so that's the marketplace that we have to see that stability and we have to see them starting to spend some MRO in this North America market. And how long can they keep deferring that? I think we will not get clarity until that first calendar quarter from our major investors as they fish out their fiscal year, as they see their cost structure. So that's why I think the first fiscal quarter, which is the fourth calendar quarter, will be very, very difficult because I think our customer base will be tight, tight, tight with cash and be concerned. So that's where I see it right now, Julian.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next questioner today is Andrew Kaplowitz with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next questioner today is Andrew Kaplowitz with Citigroup.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, so China, I mean, it looks like it turned a bit for you in the quarter, especially in climate markets. Could you see an end to inventory destocking in climate? Or is it conditions will simply get better there? And what do you think for 2017 in China?
componenttext: So, so China, I mean, it looks like it turned a bit for you in the quarter, especially in climate markets. Could you see an end to inventory destocking in climate? Or is it conditions will simply get better there? And what do you think for 2017 in China?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: There is not one simple -- I mean, China is a big country, big market. Clearly, what we see right now are some of the investments around the environment, some of the investments around energy efficiency. We're seeing the Climate Technology investments or
componenttext: There is not one simple -- I mean, China is a big country, big market. Clearly, what we see right now are some of the investments around the environment, some of the investments around energy efficiency. We're seeing the Climate Technology investments or the Automation Solutions -- no, I mean Commercial & Residential Solutions, those markets are picking back up for us. They've continued here early on in this fiscal quarter -- first quarter. So we see that market turn. Now obviously, after being down real negative for a while, you get a nice bounce. And that's where we are right now. So we're expecting moderate growth in China in our Commercial & Residential Solutions business for 2017. Our orders in Automation Solutions have stabilized in China. Again, you keep in mind the markets we serve in China, not necessarily in the big down -- oil and gas -- new fields and things like that. We're looking at efficiency. We're looking at power plants. We're looking at programs to help incremental capacity and save energy and things like that. Those markets are starting to -- are actually starting to solidify in China. So we are cautiously optimistic about China, that we will see low single-digit positive growth in 2017. Now ask me that question in February, I might give you a different answer. But right now, that's what we're seeing based on our indication of orders the last couple of months with our customers. So I feel good about that. The other market I feel good about will be Europe. If you look at the new Emerson, the Automation Solutions and Commercial & Residential, our European -- Europe grew last year, and I think it will grow again this year. Those are the 2 positive markets. And then it gets real short after that.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful, Dave. So look, you've obviously done a lot of restructuring in the last couple of years. You've done a great job of holding margin, as you said. At some point, as you know, you start cutting into the bone a bit. So how much more low-
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful, Dave. So look, you've obviously done a lot of restructuring in the last couple of years. You've done a great job of holding margin, as you said. At some point, as you know, you start cutting into the bone a bit. So how much more low-hanging fruit do you have if markets don't improve? How much more can you hold margin? I mean, you've got that again for '17 where you got declining sales and it looks like you're going to hold margin again. So can you talk about that, Dave?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can talk about that. The key issue -- let's talk -- break it down in 2 pieces, and I'm going to give you a -- I mean, I'm going to give you a total perspective from a CEO industry perspective, okay? On the Commercial & Residential Solutions, Bob Sh
componenttext: Yes, I can talk about that. The key issue -- let's talk -- break it down in 2 pieces, and I'm going to give you a -- I mean, I'm going to give you a total perspective from a CEO industry perspective, okay? On the Commercial & Residential Solutions, Bob Sharp and Jim Lindemann laid out a plan. They're integrating these businesses today, and we see some opportunities in between the creases, let's say, to improve plant efficiency, plant cost, distribution, things like that. So we see the ability to basically get a point out of a cost structure and improve the profitability by a point over the next couple of years, get some working capital out. Take some of that money, invest it, try to get -- to grow that business, but also let some of that money through -- flow through. So there, we're looking at, by merging -- putting the business together, some inefficiencies [ph] that we have today by separate business by putting together. But once that's done, it's got -- we've got to grow because the cost structure will be very, very, very good. On an Automation Solutions standpoint, we probably have $40 million, $50 million of the core company left. And then you got some very, very difficult issues there. From the -- starting to go after things you don't want to go after sort of jeopardizes the future technology innovation [ph] and the value base of this company. The acquisition of Pentair Valves & Controls gives us a chance to do -- to go after even more. And that's why we're going to be looking at $50 million to $75 million in the first year, depending on when we get this done on the restructuring. And there's -- potentially, we'll do even more than that in the next 2 years. So the acquisition of Pentair Valves & Controls gives us a chance to refresh opportunities for us to integrate again a much larger business. You take the $7 billion Automation Solutions business today, you add $1.6 billion in there to -- you get -- you have the chance to do things. Now if the economy doesn't grow and we continue to struggle for growth, hence, you're going to see -- you're going to continue to see acquisitions. That's why you're seeing acquisitions. U.S. companies have been going through a lot of restructuring, taking costs out. We're running at levels -- pretty high levels of profitability for the level of sales we have. And hence, that's why you're seeing acquisitions. That's why you're going to see that continue, I think, in the short term, unless there's some kind of growth in '17, which I don't see at this point in time. So if this thing keeps going and gets sloppy, then we're going to have to add to our acquisition pool. And that's why we're going to be looking at an additional $3 billion to $4 billion of acquisitions over the next 2 or 3 years to continue to feed our chance to reposition, restructure and drive top line growth through acquisitions because the core economic growth, we do not see coming through for the next couple of years. That's what this CEO sees from the cost perspective and growth perspective.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next questioner today is Nigel Coe from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next questioner today is Nigel Coe from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I did send my questions to Craig. He's lying. He's got them. So Automation Solutions is down 4% to 7%. Obviously, how do we think about the legacy sort of Industrial Automations stuff flat this quarter? You got some components of that segment performi
componenttext: And I did send my questions to Craig. He's lying. He's got them. So Automation Solutions is down 4% to 7%. Obviously, how do we think about the legacy sort of Industrial Automations stuff flat this quarter? You got some components of that segment performing very well. Process, I'm assuming would be below the 4% to 7%. So how do we think about the various moving pieces within that portfolio? And then Valves & Controls obviously comes in as an acquisition line, but is the kind of down 4% to 7% the same for that portfolio? Or was that a bit later cycle?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. That's -- Nigel, think about the chart that we showed you -- that I gave you when we did the Valves -- Pentair Valves & Controls chart, with the $260 billion market. We broke down in 3 pieces. You remember that you had the Process, you had the Hybrid
componenttext: No. That's -- Nigel, think about the chart that we showed you -- that I gave you when we did the Valves -- Pentair Valves & Controls chart, with the $260 billion market. We broke down in 3 pieces. You remember that you had the Process, you had the Hybrid and then you had the Discrete. You think about -- you remember that chart? I get -- we handed it out. The Process side will be worse than negative 4% to 7%, and the -- our Hybrid/Discrete business will basically be flat -- will be flat growth next year. And therefore, that's how we get the 4% to 7% combined, okay? We're looking at the marketplace, that $206 billion marketplace that we showed you when we did the Valves & Controls acquisition. The Process piece will be down more than 4% to 7%, and the other Hybrid piece will be flat or slightly up, maybe 1%, plus or minus 0, plus or minus 1%. And that's why the Process business will be a little bit more negative than we said the 4% to 7%, to your point.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then the Pentair portfolio, does that come in at a similar kind of organic decline as the Emerson Process business? Or...

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think as you -- as I said when we did the acquisition, I have a little bit more pessimistic view of what that business is going to look like in the next 12 to 18 months. One, their order pace has not been very good. Secondly, there's going to be a lot o
componenttext: I think as you -- as I said when we did the acquisition, I have a little bit more pessimistic view of what that business is going to look like in the next 12 to 18 months. One, their order pace has not been very good. Secondly, there's going to be a lot of disruption and integration work going on. I think that will negative this business -- negatively impact this business for 12 to 18 months. Once it comes onboard, it will be in the same growth rate as the overall Process business, but I think the next -- I think as you look at '17 and '18, I think they're going to be a little bit less than the underlying, what we'd call, process automation business. It's -- and we're going to be creating that problem ourselves, probably.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then a quick one, Dave. The comments on acquisitions are obviously very interesting. You made it very clear that you're done with the portfolio disposals, and you've got one more coming up. But looking at the tools markets, there's been a fair amount of consolidation talk about -- in the tools market. You've got a great plumbing tools business, high multiples of getting paid. Does that make you kind of rethink about your portfolio as maybe perhaps 1 or 2 more sales to accelerate your acquisitions into Automation?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think that from within our tool business space right now, there's some good leverage across some of the other core automation and solutions businesses. There's some good leverage there. So if there's no strategic leverage between the Commercial & Re
componenttext: No. I think that from within our tool business space right now, there's some good leverage across some of the other core automation and solutions businesses. There's some good leverage there. So if there's no strategic leverage between the Commercial & Residential and Automation Solutions, we will get out of that business. But right now, the portfolio is remaining -- other than the 1 storage business, there's some good leverage in this, leverage of channel, leverage of technologies and leverage of things that we can do that we will stay pat.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know me. I'll give you my interpretation. I'll give you what I feel, okay, Steve? I'll give you the best feel I have at this point in time. I fundamentally believe right now we are about as close as we've been for a while relative to this price-cost p
componenttext: You know me. I'll give you my interpretation. I'll give you what I feel, okay, Steve? I'll give you the best feel I have at this point in time. I fundamentally believe right now we are about as close as we've been for a while relative to this price-cost pressures. Being pricing, as you know, has been basically flat for us. I think, last year, the last 2 years, basically slightly up, slightly down, 0.1, 0.2. Now we've been able to offset that with stronger net material inflation. I -- what I see coming into us right now, either this quarter or next quarter, is our price-cost ratio pressures are going to build. And so we're factoring into higher-cost reduction efforts within the company because I wouldn't be surprised if we do not go red for 1 or 2 quarters on our price-cost ratios in 2017. I've told people at the Fed this same issue. There is inflation brewing relative to specific skill set. Material deflation is slowing down; it's not starting to come up. And our pricing capability is not that strong right now because there's plenty of capacity out there and there's not a lot of demand. So the pressure is building on this whole price-cost scenario. So what we're building in right now in our plan is, basically, to stay neutral because I think if you let it run its course, we're going to be slightly red on our price-cost situation. We have to increase our cost reductions. And it's going to be primarily around cost reduction. Productivity is going to be tough. We'll probably be 1% or 2% next year on productivity. We're better than the U.S. economy, but there's not a lot of growth out there. So it's extremely hard to get a lot more productivity without some additional growth. So right now, we're having to ramp up our cost reductions around sort of discretionary things and keep the place kind of tight. So that's how I see that unfolding next year. Now we're going to get -- we've got the savings that we've -- from the restructuring we did last year, early this year. But in order to hold our margins, improve our profitability next year, we're going to have to come up with more, stronger discretionary cost savings because I think price-cost will be working against us. That's my call. I'm sure you've not heard that from anybody, but that's my call.

componenttext: I'm telling you we ask you the same question over and over again, so it's... So Pentair Valves & Controls, you talked about it being uniquely strategic to generate future growth for the company. Clearly, there are a lot of people -- a lot of people in the market who are having more skepticism about understanding that. Since you've had more time with it, is there anything in there you can kind of point to that sort of provides a little more encouragement to you and maybe to investors that, "Hey, this is something that people should appreciate more than they do?"

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've now had the opportunity to talk to our customer base about this. I mean, the most strategic opportunity for us is that we can get them into a lot bigger customers that they couldn't get into themselves. We can get them onto large projects which we w
componenttext: We've now had the opportunity to talk to our customer base about this. I mean, the most strategic opportunity for us is that we can get them into a lot bigger customers that they couldn't get into themselves. We can get them onto large projects which we win, which they never won because they don't have the control system or the whole package. We can now offer a much larger service package. We can service a whole host of our products for our customers. So now we can be this sort of core service organization for them. The leverage across the total portfolio. Now people -- all they want to do is think about, "That's a dumb valve." Then that's a very narrow thinking. You can say, "Oh, yes, that's not that strategic." But what we're talking about is when we go out and bid for projects, when we go out for the type of packages we get with the large -- our large global customer base, we now will be able to offer them a much larger solution, both from the upfront and the service and tie that technology together. So we see a lot more growth synergies from that leverage of our organization on a global basis than a person who only thinks about a valve company stand-alone operation. And I think in 5 years, people will look back and say, "Hey, you did get a lot more growth than we thought you would." But that's what I see right now.

componenttext: So a couple of questions. First, I just wanted to maybe better understand the comment on lower price in the Climate Tech in the quarter. Was this just surcharge-related linked to material cost? Or was it actual incremental price pressure or something we should be concerned about?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Gautam, it's not. It's not incremental price pressure. Again, it relates back to -- again, we talked about this before. Most of the OEMs are on some type of kind of contractual matrix-type pricing. So as commodities go up or down, pricing is adjusted.
componenttext: No, Gautam, it's not. It's not incremental price pressure. Again, it relates back to -- again, we talked about this before. Most of the OEMs are on some type of kind of contractual matrix-type pricing. So as commodities go up or down, pricing is adjusted. So in this environment, when commodities are low, pricing is -- goes down to match that. There's a bit of a lag occasionally, but that's what the impact is.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Earnings is earnings, but cash is cash, okay? So from that standpoint, could you talk, Dave, about your cadence for operating cash and free cash flow generation over the next couple of years? And kind of what are your -- given what you're planning for a d
componenttext: Earnings is earnings, but cash is cash, okay? So from that standpoint, could you talk, Dave, about your cadence for operating cash and free cash flow generation over the next couple of years? And kind of what are your -- given what you're planning for a difficult environment, what are -- can you give investors some confidence that the dividend remains sacrosanct in the context of this transitional period?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: For '17, there's 2 numbers you need to think about for '17. This was driven into our heads across the organization: $2.5 billion operating cash flow and $2 billion free cash flow. A number that's pretty tight to our modeling, and we're going to manage acc
componenttext: For '17, there's 2 numbers you need to think about for '17. This was driven into our heads across the organization: $2.5 billion operating cash flow and $2 billion free cash flow. A number that's pretty tight to our modeling, and we're going to manage according -- as the organization is talking about it. So if we can beat it, we can beat it. But that would put us at 62% of dividend to free cash flow cover, okay? Then as we move into '18 and '19, we're not assuming any big breakout or anything like that, but we're trying to get back into adding about $100 million of cash to $150 million of operating cash flow per year. Now our plan is to continue to keep the dividend going up modestly, as I told the people, $0.02. We'll have share repurchase of around $500 million per year. That allows us to basically keep the dividend -- the actual payments flat or slightly down. And so we'll see as we get into -- right now, 2020, 2021, we'll be back down towards that 50% level. If we do not make any more addition -- acquisitions, that's what's going to happen. If we make additional acquisitions on top of Pentair, our game plan is to get that number back, our operating cash flow back up to $3.2 billion, spending around $600 million of capital. That gets us back into high 40s free cash flow to dividends from that perspective. So our model right now says that we'll continue to make acquisitions. We'll continue to integrate them, generate cash flows. We'll continue to buy stock back and continue to increase our dividend modestly. So that's what we're looking at right now. And our model looks at: Do we do nothing other than Pentair? And if that does that, we'll get closer to 50%. If we do some additional deals which we want to do, then we'll obviously get back under 50% in the next 5 years.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just as a follow-up. I mean, obviously, Julian asked kind of a line in the same question for Automation Solutions in terms of the order trends, the cadence for the year. But usually, kind of how you lay out the year is basically you guide fiscal
componenttext: And then just as a follow-up. I mean, obviously, Julian asked kind of a line in the same question for Automation Solutions in terms of the order trends, the cadence for the year. But usually, kind of how you lay out the year is basically you guide fiscal 1Q and then get a peek into next year kind of for your full year guidance. You've given us the full year guidance now, given all the puts and takes. I guess, looking at kind of known unknowns going into February, Dave, I mean, what are the 3 or 4 key things that you want to come in hat in hand in February to have a better sense of kind of the macro variables so you can have a better sense of whether you can actually grow earnings next year? What are you -- what are the kind of 3 or 4 things we should be looking for given your increased line of sight February versus now?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: The #1 issue, the #2 issue and 1, 2 and 3 will be the trend line of process or Automation Solutions orders, in particular North America orders. We need that chart. We need that line coming up like I thought we could do last year. I made the call, and I wa
componenttext: The #1 issue, the #2 issue and 1, 2 and 3 will be the trend line of process or Automation Solutions orders, in particular North America orders. We need that chart. We need that line coming up like I thought we could do last year. I made the call, and I was wrong. We need that line coming up towards that flatline, that 0 line, and that's going to be very -- that's #1, 2 and 3. And so I hadn't totally mapped -- I don't see how the next couple of months -- right now is when a lot of things happen. As we close out our fiscal year, the first couple of months are tough with our customer base. So I want to see what happens here, October, November, December and January in order pace. That will give me a clear idea how much is flushed in the system, and then we need to see that trend line coming up. If we do not see a pretty good slope of those orders, in particular in North America, then we'll have a hard, hard time growing earnings next year. But that's the top couple of issues right there. The second issue will be -- from our perspective will be -- or the third or fourth issue will be I'm watching the commercial/residential in Asia. If Asia continues to grow for us in the commercial/residential and then we -- because I think we'll see a pretty good transition of growth in North America. I think we'll still see a pretty good growth there. If Asia continues to grow for us in commercial/residential solutions, then I'll feel good about that segment holding up throughout 2017. So that will be the key thing I'm watching for those guys, and then clearly, Automation Solutions order trending line up and the lines pointing towards hitting that cross point sometime late in our fiscal 2017. And that's what we'll be watching like a hawk, and we're [indiscernible] so.

componenttext: Two questions. The first one, just back to process and just trying to kind of figure out the secret decoder ring here for what the turn might look like. Are you seeing MRO turning in other regions outside the U.S.? So is there something to glean from the pace of activity in other areas that give us a little bit of road map to think about how North America and the U.S. market can play out?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think the other markets really have anything to do in North America. MRO in Europe, MRO in Asia Pacific has been decent, trending -- Europe has been positive, and Asia Pacific is starting to trend the right way. They don't really drive North Ameri
componenttext: I don't think the other markets really have anything to do in North America. MRO in Europe, MRO in Asia Pacific has been decent, trending -- Europe has been positive, and Asia Pacific is starting to trend the right way. They don't really drive North America. That's the wild card we got to watch. That's -- when we start saying North America Automation Solutions, so get the phrase right there, Automation Solutions, trending the right way. That has been the key phrase for us. If you don't see us saying that, then we're really going to start struggling. And we will not be able to deliver what we laid out in that range earlier this year, but I really feel like we will.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I was thinking a handoff from CapEx to MRO and how that played out in other areas is maybe...

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a different game plan here. North America, the way that -- the multinationals can do, they -- because they have a lot more control in North America, they cut here deeper. And they -- it's just the way it is. When you think about labor and restru
componenttext: Yes, it's a different game plan here. North America, the way that -- the multinationals can do, they -- because they have a lot more control in North America, they cut here deeper. And they -- it's just the way it is. When you think about labor and restructuring, there's always more in North America because we have a lot more flexibility. That's the same thing here. So around MRO, there is no decoder rings relative to U.S.A. [ph], relative to what happens in Europe, what happens in Latin America, what happens in -- or Asia Pacific. It's a whole different game, okay?

componenttext: We never got into that business because there was a good reason for it, so I'm passing that one. A lot of hype around water and filtration. And we're highly focused right now on trying to get all the approvals for -- if you think about, we've got 2 major divestitures and a major acquisition underway. There are a massive number of approvals we have to get around the world on 3 of those capabilities. So right now, we sort of got our tools down. There are opportunities out there. We're working them, but we'll really gear back up once we get all these approvals done. But there are other cases out there. I wouldn't worry about that.

componenttextpreview: It's stability here. I think it's the stability between the mid-40s up to mid-50s right now. I think that's what -- they just need to see where they are. Our customer may need to see where they are from a cash flow standpoint or a cost structure standpoin
componenttext: It's stability here. I think it's the stability between the mid-40s up to mid-50s right now. I think that's what -- they just need to see where they are. Our customer may need to see where they are from a cash flow standpoint or a cost structure standpoint. This industry -- our end customer industry has been going through a lot of restructuring also for the last 18 months, and so they're trying to get stabilized like we're trying to get stabilized. So I think the key issue for me, John, is stability. And we see a little bit of stability, though. It's drifted back down again in the oil side. But I mean, the key thing for us is see some stability around that, not some high-level mark. And I think that way, these guys can plan their cash flow. They can plan their capital allocation from a dividend standpoint or a share -- whatever they're trying to do and then allocate back to capital. And I'm hoping that we'll see some more capital reallocate back to MRO versus some finishing off of projects like they had last year, okay?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So is there a way to then sort of drill down into ultimately the reasons that you feel that -- sort of going back to February, right, when we thought things were going to turn and they ultimately didn't. Why is it that things are going to turn in the seco
componenttext: So is there a way to then sort of drill down into ultimately the reasons that you feel that -- sort of going back to February, right, when we thought things were going to turn and they ultimately didn't. Why is it that things are going to turn in the second half of '17? Is it just because we've been in a downturn for much longer? Or you actually are seeing more stability? Or what is it? Obviously, the comparison issues, I get. But I think you're talking more on the fundamental side, so I'm just kind of get back to what the -- what are the vehicle drivers...

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, you got to go back and think about where the price of oil was. It was not -- it was trending. There was a -- it was in the 50s, and they made a call that it was going to go in the 20s, and it went down into $30. In the oil -- our customer base did a
componenttext: John, you got to go back and think about where the price of oil was. It was not -- it was trending. There was a -- it was in the 50s, and they made a call that it was going to go in the 20s, and it went down into $30. In the oil -- our customer base did a quick evaluation in the spring, summer about: “Oh my God, how do I protect my capital structure?” How do I protect all these things with a much lower oil price? So they cut capital much deeper than they said originally, that they had told us in January, February where we get the early indications from them. So that's what happened there. Now we go forward here. Now we're out here sitting in late in the year, and we're sitting here in the November time period. Oil pricing and the gas prices have been stabilizing here for several months, and the trend line has been a little bit better. It does go up and down. They have now got a year behind them relative to their whole capital structure. Some of the big projects had to get done. They cut really heavily on the day-to-day spending, and I think you're going to see that stability in the pricing. If it stays that way and within a range, then you'll see some more money go back into the day-to-day capital, and that's the difference.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, perfectly clear. Dave, you're sounding reasonably sort of constructive on the European markets, and I know you're a steward of geopolitical events. Are you not -- I mean, a couple of companies have called out European softening even of late. Are you n
componenttext: No, perfectly clear. Dave, you're sounding reasonably sort of constructive on the European markets, and I know you're a steward of geopolitical events. Are you not -- I mean, a couple of companies have called out European softening even of late. Are you not a little bit concerned about Brexit now actually moving forward, possibly causing a European improvement scenario to fizzle? Or...

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you listened to me talk in the last couple of times, I said Europe will be -- is weaker. All I said, Europe will grow. We grew this year. I think it'll grow less in 2017 than it did in 2016. That's -- but I've been telling -- openly, I've been telling
componenttext: If you listened to me talk in the last couple of times, I said Europe will be -- is weaker. All I said, Europe will grow. We grew this year. I think it'll grow less in 2017 than it did in 2016. That's -- but I've been telling -- openly, I've been telling people -- and if anyone's hear me talk, they're heard me say Europe is definitely weakened. Europe is definitely growing. The euro is weaker, so that again is going to help our European operation. The euro went back down into $1.09 to $1.10. If it gets back up to $1.15, that'll make it tougher. But it's definitely going to weaken. And I think the hoopla around Brexit is hoopla. And so I think it's -- from my perspective, Europe will grow next year, but it won't be as much growth as this year.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just lastly, do you think China -- do you feel that China in terms of the levels it's achieved, is it sustainable? Or is it -- because some are sort of concerned this is just a function of Chinese stimulus that then goes away. I'm just -- it sounds li
componenttext: And just lastly, do you think China -- do you feel that China in terms of the levels it's achieved, is it sustainable? Or is it -- because some are sort of concerned this is just a function of Chinese stimulus that then goes away. I'm just -- it sounds like you've got a little more conviction in the China market right now.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think based on what we're seeing in order patterns, based on our customer inputs, based on what we start seeing the last couple of months, as I've said earlier, I think China will grow low single digit, from 0 to 2%, 3%. And that's where I see it right
componenttext: I think based on what we're seeing in order patterns, based on our customer inputs, based on what we start seeing the last couple of months, as I've said earlier, I think China will grow low single digit, from 0 to 2%, 3%. And that's where I see it right now. And if someone asked me the question a couple of calls back about in February, what would feel -- make you feel better relative to your forecast, I think that China, Asia Pacific is the #2 thing, I would say. After 1, 2 and 3 were our Automation Solutions orders. But China order pace and sales pace will be the #2 thing in that case.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and low single digit seems like a pretty reasonable hurdle. Good stuff.
componenttext: Yes, and low single digit seems like a pretty reasonable hurdle. Good stuff.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: $447 million is the new Emerson. We'll be flat basically on a comparable basis there. We have an obligation. We still own -- accounting, we had the disc ops, but we still own the businesses. So I'm actually still getting cash, and I'm having to spend mone
componenttext: $447 million is the new Emerson. We'll be flat basically on a comparable basis there. We have an obligation. We still own -- accounting, we had the disc ops, but we still own the businesses. So I'm actually still getting cash, and I'm having to spend money. Contrary to what the county told me, I still own these businesses, and I still got the deed of control. Yes, there had been discontinued operations. But I will get the cash, and we will get -- we have some capital spending obligations. So it's going to be around $500 million next year with that from that perspective, okay?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Where is that money being spent? If you had just kind of big buckets, how would you describe that?
componenttext: Where is that money being spent? If you had just kind of big buckets, how would you describe that?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Incrementally, the biggest pockets is we've -- we're freeing up capital to go into the Commercial & Residential Solutions business relative to the whole efficiency thing that I was talking about earlier, so we basically have several new facilities being b
componenttext: Incrementally, the biggest pockets is we've -- we're freeing up capital to go into the Commercial & Residential Solutions business relative to the whole efficiency thing that I was talking about earlier, so we basically have several new facilities being built in best cost locations. We're relaying out some facilities. We're going to consolidate some facilities. So of that core business, $50 million is going to go to discontinued operations business, around that number. And then we'll have $450 million going to the Emerson remaining businesses. And a big chunk of that will be going into that work around -- that Jim Lindemann and Bob Sharp are doing relative to Commercial & Residential organization. The -- we also have some capacity going into our -- for our compressor business in some best cost locations. And then the other big chunks -- there's nothing really big in Automation Solutions from a standpoint of -- it's just restructuring. And when you do restructuring and you do plant moves and stuff like that, you have to spend capital. So that's where the big chunks are, Deane.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you did not get the memo that everyone got, that everyone is supposed to be cutting CapEx next year?
componenttext: So you did not get the memo that everyone got, that everyone is supposed to be cutting CapEx next year?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: We've cut it pretty hard the last 18 months, and we actually generate pretty good cash flow, too, Deane. You didn't get that memo?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. It's fabulous cash flow. I just think it's impressive that you're adding capacity in this environment, and that's a pretty bullish sign. So...
componenttext: No. It's fabulous cash flow. I just think it's impressive that you're adding capacity in this environment, and that's a pretty bullish sign. So...

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they key issue, Deane, and I think you and I have talked about this, if we do not add -- spend some money, you will not get productivity. And that's one of the signs it's a nasty loop right now. People in the industry, if you do not spend, you will
componenttext: Well, they key issue, Deane, and I think you and I have talked about this, if we do not add -- spend some money, you will not get productivity. And that's one of the signs it's a nasty loop right now. People in the industry, if you do not spend, you will not drive productivity, and that's where we're spending money. And we are growing some of our businesses, and so they need capacity.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Have -- a number of building product companies have -- kind of had squishy numbers, outlooks or particularly as it relates to more of the residential side of things here going into year-end. Just curious, I mean, the order growth was decent in September o
componenttext: Have -- a number of building product companies have -- kind of had squishy numbers, outlooks or particularly as it relates to more of the residential side of things here going into year-end. Just curious, I mean, the order growth was decent in September on a trailing 3-quarter basis. It seems like maybe you saw something different. But just curious, underlying, particularly North American market, how you characterize the state of the market right now in terms of order momentum and what you're seeing as you're going into year-end right now.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- it really breaks down in different segments. But clearly, inventory is within on the, what I'd call, our sort of air conditioning. Both the commercial and the residential channel is pretty tight right now. They had late heat. And so that channel ha
componenttext: The -- it really breaks down in different segments. But clearly, inventory is within on the, what I'd call, our sort of air conditioning. Both the commercial and the residential channel is pretty tight right now. They had late heat. And so that channel has gotten pretty tight, so some work going on there. So I would expect us to have a good first fiscal quarter there as they get the channel to where they need it, Rich. The other thing going on right now is there's a lot of changes relative to the efficiencies, to the refrigerants and new products coming out from our customer base. So there's a lot of work being done in that, which is driving some incremental growth for us. We're seeing that both in efficiency stuff going on in China. We see that across Asia, and we're seeing that in Europe. So we're -- well, anytime you start seeing a lot of changes in some of the new targets come out relative into the HFCs and the efficiencies, we get a benefit from that a little bit earlier than most people because they have to build up ahead of time. So we've seen a decent pattern of growth. And then our housing business has held up reasonably well, but it's definitely stalled where it was. The growth rate has definitely stalled. And then a couple of our businesses within the Commercial & Residential Solutions business actually get benefit from, what I would call environmental problems like flooding and bad weather and stuff like that. There's been some across North America here in the last couple of months. And so it's -- things have gone our way there for a change. And so I think Bob and his team got great cost structure right now, all the restructuring so they're driving very good margins. They got a couple environmental things and the trends going their way right now. So hopefully, they make hay for this quarter because who knows what's going to happen next quarter there, so that's where we are right now.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And does the -- the global summit a few weeks ago with the changes in the Montreal protocol, I mean, does that have any tangible benefit in the next couple of years? Or is that more out toward the beginning of next decade?
componenttext: And does the -- the global summit a few weeks ago with the changes in the Montreal protocol, I mean, does that have any tangible benefit in the next couple of years? Or is that more out toward the beginning of next decade?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a -- Europe and U.S., we reviewed that with the board today, in fact. U.S. and Europe is -- definitely in the next 2 years, we'll start seeing some benefit there. The good thing about it was is they now come down on what they would -- they've agree
componenttext: That's a -- Europe and U.S., we reviewed that with the board today, in fact. U.S. and Europe is -- definitely in the next 2 years, we'll start seeing some benefit there. The good thing about it was is they now come down on what they would -- they've agreed to certain standards and certain targets. So now our customer base, including us, can work on solutions to get there. And so that's a good sign. That will help us. And we've been, as you know, one of the reasons we made the Helix investment the last couple of years up there in Dayton is because we know we're going to have to help to drive some of these solutions, and that will help us probably late '17 but more '18 and '19. Asia wants the way -- if you look at the standards, they're still out another 10 years. So that -- our gut right there, they will stay with old technologies. We'll just drive the older technologies, not the newer technologies. But that definitely helps us because it's getting them set into the right direction for us.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on Valves & Controls with this -- the portfolio there. From an intelligence standpoint, you kind of talked a little bit about this earlier in the call. And you did a pervasive sensing acquisition, I think, early -- relates early October. An
componenttext: Okay. And then on Valves & Controls with this -- the portfolio there. From an intelligence standpoint, you kind of talked a little bit about this earlier in the call. And you did a pervasive sensing acquisition, I think, early -- relates early October. And I know that's an area of focus for you. How quickly can you increase the intelligence in the Valves & Controls portfolio? And...

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it will take us 2 to 3 years to really have an impact, but we'll -- there's a lot of things around their actuation stuff. There's a lot of things around some of their safety in the Crosby area. There are areas that we can bring in some technology
componenttext: I think it will take us 2 to 3 years to really have an impact, but we'll -- there's a lot of things around their actuation stuff. There's a lot of things around some of their safety in the Crosby area. There are areas that we can bring in some technology which we have, we could port over to them. So it'll take us -- there's a lot of things you have -- you have standards you have to meet and pass, so it's going to take 2 to 3 years. But within its planning cycle, we'll start getting some benefit from that.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the free cash flow, so I guess if CapEx is not adjusting out of the disc ops, how much of the free cash flow is coming from the disc ops? And then I assume that basically whatever cash you're going to lose there for the year forward would be replaced b
componenttext: On the free cash flow, so I guess if CapEx is not adjusting out of the disc ops, how much of the free cash flow is coming from the disc ops? And then I assume that basically whatever cash you're going to lose there for the year forward would be replaced by the kind of a solid cash accretion you're getting from Pentair, which I think is around $100 million to start for this year. Is that kind of the right equation?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think to cut it through simple, Frank and I, we -- because first of all, we don't own Pentair Valves & Controls, as you well know. I think we're going to be slightly north -- when you push and shove everything back and forth, north -- slightly nort
componenttext: Yes, I think to cut it through simple, Frank and I, we -- because first of all, we don't own Pentair Valves & Controls, as you well know. I think we're going to be slightly north -- when you push and shove everything back and forth, north -- slightly north of $2.5 billion with Pentair. I think we can hold capital $500 million with Pentair-type stuff in there, with pluses and minuses across the whole company. So there's not much cash flow coming from the companies we're selling in the stub period, but we do have capital spending obligations. So I think, overall, I feel good that we will meet or slightly exceed the $2.5 billion operating cash flow. I have a lot of control over capital, as you can imagine. And so the $2 billion next year is a number that we've got locked in stone, and I told the board we will be monitoring that on a monthly basis. And we'll be keeping the board informed, and therefore, we'll keep you guys informed because that's a very important number to us. We want to make the 62% dividend to free cash flow ratio the worst that we see in my tenure. And so -- and then we'll start driving that back down in 2019.

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on process. How much of that do you think is -- you mentioned North America MRO, et cetera. How much of that do you think is kind of pulled along with the chain of U.S. land rig count? I don't know how you -- maybe you don't classify i
componenttext: Okay. And then just on process. How much of that do you think is -- you mentioned North America MRO, et cetera. How much of that do you think is kind of pulled along with the chain of U.S. land rig count? I don't know how you -- maybe you don't classify it that way, but obviously, that's an area that people are a lot more optimistic on for next year. How much of a variable is that in kind of the trends in the automation -- I didn't say Process automation, the industrial automation business?

headline: Emerson Electric Co., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, I think that, for me, the way -- our business is mixed up because we're not really down well stuff. We have some stuff, but that's not going to drive our sales. What you really want to watch for us is the stability around the pricing of oil and the
componenttext: Steve, I think that, for me, the way -- our business is mixed up because we're not really down well stuff. We have some stuff, but that's not going to drive our sales. What you really want to watch for us is the stability around the pricing of oil and the pricing of gases and within this range of the $45 to $55 range for oil and their equivalent level to gas. That is the -- that number is very, very important to my customer base. Rig count is more down the road for us, and that means their overall health of the industry, that will help us, too. But the near term, if I'm thinking '17, stability in the price of oil and gas is pretty important relative to what I see our end customers will spend. And when they do their capital allocations, Steve, from based on: "Okay, I have to spend this much money for share repurchase, this much for dividend, this much for capital. How much do I have left over?" That's how they're going to be calculating, and I think that those are the numbers I'm watching right now. And that stability is critical to me.
